There are regions in Ukraine and Romania where people cannot afford to pay for the transportation of domestic waste. The nearby Tisza offers an easy option. The flood basin stores the garbage and the spring flood takes away most of it - for free. The situation is very depressing at places like at the connection of the White and the Black Tisza. The countless PET bottles, plastic bags and other garbage are swept away by the annual ﬂood of the river and turns the otherwise beautiful Tisza into a moving dumpsite. Tens of thousands of PET bottles are drifting on the surface. In severe cases more than 50 percent of the surface is covered with trash, a phenomenon aka the annual PET Bottle Flood. After the flood the shorline is covered with plastic bags and PET bottles. Some places - like the Jandi Island in Hungary - are so badly affected that the height of plastic piles can reach several meters and increasing. 


Tisza is a river. It's here:




We think it should look like this:




Instead, in many places it looks like this:


PET Cup is inspiring
When seeing this, we knew that something can be done to stop this repeating wave of pollution. The collection of the trash however, is a depressing and sad activity. How to turn it into something more useful, inspiring and entertaining? How to reach an impact big enough to change people's mind on this issue in Hungary and abroad? We think the answer is to turn it's own weapon against the pollution, which is - 
the PET bottle itself:


With the strong support of local communities PET Cup starts with well-organized "hunts" for PET bottles and other items made of plastic and thrown in the river:


The PET Cup continues with a boat-building competition where PET boats are built from the garbage:




As soon as they're on the water, PET pirates raise the battle against PET pollution to another level:



They attack the strongholds of PET bottles sometimes several meters high:



Collecting thousands of PET bottles in the course of a single day: 



Or a bit less, but still they do their best:

At the end of the one-week long boat race the best PET boat is about to win the not-so-beautiful trophy made of garbage:


The PET Cup:



And of course, every PET boat is to be recycled:




Who we are and what we do?We are environmental filmmakers working for a Budapest-based NGO called the Filmjungle Society. Funded in 1996 Filmjungle Society had become the most productive production unit in the country making award-winning wildlife and conservation documentaries for national and international audience. Filmjungle Society happens to be the brainparent of the PET Cup. Our knowledge in edutainment seems to be very useful when it comes to bringing together communities and directing public attention to important issues. Oohhh, that sounds sooo official. 



Cutting the long story short, we make film(s) about the whole thing:

We are professionals:

We have the equipment and determination:

And we always put the camera in the best possible hands:




What we're up to?
In 2013 altogether 4 PET boats covered more than 100 kilometres on the river, collected nearly 10.000 PET bottles, a 3 part documentary series was produced and the event was covered in two languages (Hungarian and English) on Facebook. In 2014 we want to cover the same distance, but we want more PET boats to build, more bottles to collect, more videos to make and reach a bigger audience than ever before. The 2nd PET Cup will be held between 15-23 of August, 2014. During and after the event a small film crew is about to produce short videos for the Internet.



Where the funds will go








For the 2nd PET Cup we need a total amount of 6500 USD. Feeding the PET Pirates and guaranteeing their safety are the two main costs we have to count with. To document the PET Cup a 2-member camera team is also needed which will produce short videos on and after the event. If our budget allows we will invite artists and musicians who can show the PET pirates and the local audience how many ways garbage can be used. Before launching the PET boats we need to get permissions and we need a bit of money for building and construction materials as well. If we do not reach the required amount, the funds will go into securing the PET pirates while on water and into filming activities. If we over-reach the goal we will start to edit the hundreds of hours of HD footage obtained during the 1st and 2nd PET Cup into a feature documentary.
Your donation will be received by Filmjungle.eu Society. This non-profit NGO have been producing conservation documentaries and wildlife films for more than 15 years. It's award winning list of films include titles such as 'Sharks in my Viewfinder', 'Invisible Wildlife Photographer', 'Budapest Wild', 'Wolfwatching', 'Antarctica - Life in the Frozen Oasis'. Filmjungle has its own channel on Vimeo with a wide collection of VOD content. If you decide to support the PET Cup, Filmjungle can provide you personal access to some of its contents, including the doc-series on the 1st PET Cup (with English subtitles). 
  The Impact 

Cleaning the Tisza: with your help we will collect more than 10.000 bottles out of the river and make sure they will get recycled - just like the entire PET fleet (approx. 15 thousand PET bottles). 
Bringing closer communities: by visiting villages and inviting local people to join our efforts PET Cup offers a unique opportunity to do something against the pollution. 
Public awareness: the aim of the PET Cup is to direct public attention towards the Tisza river in Eastern Europe where pollution have grown too big for us to ignore. We believe that short videos, the social media - along with feature articles and television documentaries - will spread the message through borders.

Entertaining and educating: by combining the environmental actions with a boat-race PET Cup can set up an example. How can we treat a serious environmental issue and have fun at the same time.

  Other Ways You Can Help 
Please help us to make some noise about our campaign by sending the link to your friends or posting to your social media sites (you could also use the Indiegogo share tools as well). Please follow the PET Cup. Simply watching it will make you smile.

story:
Short Summary

 

Radio equipment for transmit the signal requires electrical power in order to operate. The installed equipment requires about 1,2 kW electrical power during normal use.When operating , devices heat-up and since they are housed in a container, require cooling during the summer.

Therefore, the container housing the equipment must be  cooling. The cooling unit consume an additional 3,5 kW el. power.

Autonomous BS no need colling.

What We Need & What You Get

 

We have a land for build an 36m mast and we have permission for that.

We have a lot of expences and every € , is required. We want to prove that the   principle of work ok and rent BS. Do not  have  to pay electrical connection.

 

The Impact

 

1,2 kW x24h x 365 days x 1500 masts = 15.768.000kWh for radio equipment

3,5kW x 24h x 200 days x 1500 masts= 25.200.000 kWh for cooling

 

Risks & Challenges

This  Pilot project have no risk!

If our idea do not work correctly the mast will be used as  an regular mast with windturbine and solar pannel and  not need to be cooling. We can return a money  from the lease. The idea is based on the principles of wind catcher work in Egypt.

Autonomous BS no need colling.   What We Need & What You Get We have a land for build an 36m mast and we have permission for that.
We have a lot of expences and every € , is required. We want to prove that the   principle of work ok and rent BS. Do not  have  to pay electrical connection.    The Impact 1,2 kW x24h x 365 days x 1500 masts = 15.768.000kWh for radio equipment

story:
The residents of Closter, a small town in northern New Jersey, need your help. What is going on in our Borough is a travesty that we feel helpless to prevent. It is affecting the safety and wellbeing of thousands of Borough residents.

Background

The Brooks Farm in Closter, the oldest continuously operating family farm in New Jersey, dates back to the 18th Century. It is also listed as a National Landmark recognized for its significance in American History and is also protected by the NJ State as a Historical site. In 2004 the State paid over $2.5 million to the then-owner of the farm for the conservation, preservation and development rights so that future generations would continue to enjoy it.

Stop the Greed

This changed abruptly when the farm was sold to a large chain of plant manufacturers in early 2012. Masquerading as a farm, this industrial enterprise is rapidly erasing this pristine chapter of the State’s history all while hiding behind the protection of the Right to Farm Act. In a short span of a few weeks they cut close to a hundred centuries old trees, began massive construction of industrial retaining walls to contain a huge amount of brought in soil affecting protected C1 streams, pounded the soil using heavy industrial equipment making it virtually impervious, re-graded the property, etc. No plans were presented to municipal authorities nor were any permits requested as the Act’s protections preempt local jurisdiction. The enterprise in development is being planned to support the supply chain of the wholesale and retail operations of the plant factory and will create heavy commercial traffic in the quaint historic district of town with all safety, environmental, flooding, and water contamination and pollution concerns stemming from it.

There has been a loud outcry from our residents to enforce our ordinances in order to protect their health, safety and welfare and yet we are superseded by the Farm Act. The Borough and a group of concerned residents filed a complaint with the County Board of Agriculture. In addition, the residents filed a lawsuit for restraining further development of the property until complaints are adjudicated.

A portion of the tax dollars of the residents of the Bergen County and the State of New Jersey were spent supposedly to preserve this land but instead have been used to subsidize the corporation's purchase of the property (tax dollars paid about 2/3 of the price of the land, corporation paid 1/3).

What We Need

We need your help and contributions so we can continue with our efforts to save this 302 year old farm from the hands of corporate greed. Unfortunately, the time and tireless effort of many concerned residents of Closter are not simply enough in this matter. Fighting corporations does not come at a low cost, and we are in desperate needs of funds to pay the group's attorney. It is a battle that needs to be fought in the courts, and as most know, legal fees are no bargain.

Any donations you can give would be greatly appreciated.

story:
Family, Friends, and supporters of International Environmental Education: 

I have a unique opportunity to go to Siberia come July 26-August 9 for less than the price of a plane ticket (!), thanks to the Tahoe-Baikal Institute.

The trip is a 2-week journey to Lake Baikal in Russia to work on environmental research and action projects at the biggest, oldest, and deepest lake in the world. 

Lake Baikal holds 20% of the world's fresh water and is a vital resource for our planet!

I have been teaching environmental education regarding sister lakes Tahoe and Baikal over the past year in Tahoe and this would take me to do the same in Baikal and further develop as an international environmental educator and  leader. 

I am also in the process of writing a grant for an alternative energy project in Baikal in the coming year, so this would be especially relevant.

This indiegogo is a pilot project to be used as an example for TBI program participants to fund their own program tuitions in the future. Upon success, I will create a how-to on crowd funding for TBI's programs. 

 

The funds I'm raising would go to:

$750 toward 2-week trip, visa, airfare, food, and lodging (heck of a deal!). 

$350 for travel pocket change.

$500 toward the Tahoe-Baikal Institute while we're at it! They have been instrumental towards my growth as an environmental leader this year. 

 

The Impact

Why is this project valuable?

As a Russian decendent myself, this is a once-and-a-lifetime (and super inexpensive!) opportunity for me to go to Siberia to research, study my passion, exchange information, and educate others on the successes, trials, and trubulations of Lake Tahoe(Lake Baikal's sister lake).  The trip will be helpful in continuing with the alternative energy push we have ignited as well, modernizing TBI's programs and helping create energy soverignty in the regions in which we work.

 

I have had the opportunity to travel to Brazil, Costa Rica, and Panama for environmental education and research projects as well,  so this will expand my lense on international environmental development and education. 

 

I appreciate your support for this project! Feedback is welcome!

Please help me make this dream a reality. We have 20 days to make this happen!

I am doing this fundraiser the Tahoe-Baikal Institute, which is a 501c3- tax deductable. :)

 

 

Thank you!!

 

Talia Shea

story:
EcoValuePoints carbon-based coupons earn you money and lower the CO2 footprint with each $ you spend. It pays to save the planet.

Technology alone is not going to solve the problem of global warming. It will take culture change and incentives that motivate everyone, and that can be done best with the help of commerce and industry.

Currently, individuals can make only small, almost symbolic efforts to lower their carbon footprint: buying a carbon offset here, buying an energy-saving product, riding a bike there. While businesses have focussed their efforts on reducing the carbon impact of their supply chains and processes, their marketing departments have no real tools that can harness their customers' desire to be ecologically effective, and most are "greenwashing" -- offering a veneer of "green" talk.

EcoValuePoints changes all that, for both consumers and businesses.
If we succeed and create the thriving coalition of businesses and individuals we seek, we can offset the carbon footprint of a city the size of San Francisco or Boston every year -- and maybe more.

EcoValuePoints is the only program that pays consumers for reducing carbon emissions. It is tied to their buying habits (whether or not their purchase is "green").

We buy tons of carbon “emission credits” and offsets in bulk at auctions and remove them from markets as “permits to pollute." We convert them into redeemable Points (coupons). Points are sold to OEM, service enterprises, and marketers (EcoSponsors) to be attached electronically to their offers to increase sales, retain customers, and to support their social responsibility missions. Points are an alternative form of currency, each worth $0.02 to the consumer, while removing two pounds of C02 from the atmosphere.

1 Point = at least $.02 AND removes 2 pounds of CO2 per dollar of retail sale

EcoSponsors can award multiple Points, for special sales and promotions. Consumers can earn, accumulate and track their EVP Points at our website, and redeem them for future savings, products, or donate their value to charity.

A Tested, Award-Winning & Patented Program

  • Pilot-tested at Boston University, Babson College, and Harvard Business School 
  • Won a finalist position in the international MassChallenge Accelerator program (www.MassChallenge.org)
  • Finalist in Harvard Business School New Venture Competition
  • Granted U.S. Patent No. 8527335 for the process 

The EVP process is completely transparent and verifiable -- no hint of greenwashing. Every ton of offset we buy at Government regulated Cap & Trade auctions has a unique serial number, and each 2-pound coupon we create can be tracked back to the original offset. In all cases, the carbon is removed from the offset market and can never be used by utilities and manufacturers exceeding pollution standards to avoid making the investments needed to clean up their dirty operations.

The goal of this campaign is to 
1) Fund the development of the database needed to manage all these tons, pounds and transactions. 
2) Fund the development of a world-class e-commerce website that will allow consumers and businesses to track their Points, and to post EcoSponsor offers and redemption options.
3) Fund the development of mobile apps to access that website on the go.

Please pledge today so we can all breathe easier tomorrow!

Risks and challenges

The technology involved in this project is the easy part. We will outsource the initial website, database, and mobile development to highly accomplished vendors in the field who have provided us with quotes, and require about six weeks to build... but this needs your funding help in the amount of $80,000. The largest challenge is building the EcoSponsor coalition to purchase our Points to promote their offers, thus expanding your redemption options beyond the existing limited network of Affiliates.

We have assembled a stellar team of experienced executives and marketers, and are pitching many retailers, manufacturers, service providers, and direct marketers to become EcoSponsors. While there is no guarantee of success, given the social merit of the program, the imperative to reduce carbon emissions, our successful startup track record, and our patented process, we expect to prevail.

We all will breathe easier because carbon will be removed for every dollar you pledge.

Credits: 
Our awesome video was the graduating practicum project by students at the Boston University Center for Digital Imaging Arts. (http://www.cdiabu.com). 
Hire these guys!

Video Team: 
• John McNeil (Producer) mcneilj15@gmail.com 
• Henry Lockwood henrylockwood1713@gmail.com 
• Nick Todisco radondofilms@gmail.com 
• Jesse Cook jessercook3@gmail.com 
• Kirk Duda k.duda2@gmail.com

3D Animation Team: 
• Jason Shulkin - Team lead, 3D effects, animation, modeling, texturing, rendering & compositing. http://www.jasonshulkin.com 
• Brian Colby - modeling, texturing, rigging, 2D/3D animation, and compositinghttp://www.briancolby3d.com/ 
• Joe White - animation, story boarding, camera compisitionhttp://mrjoewhite.tumblr.com/ 
• William Scott - modeling, texturing, design http://wscott3dart.blogspot.com/

story:
Diario is our neighbor in a village of 600 people in the mountains of Veracruz, Mexico. We are Jim and Mindy, creators of "Solar Haven" in Arizona, but now retired for health reasons to the more temperate climate of southern Mexico. We are the only Americans living in our village. Click HERE for many photographs showing what life is like here.

Diario is mildly intellectually handicapped but he spends all day helping others.  He travels far and wide soliciting donations door-to-door for various charities in towns throughout the region.  He walks countless miles every week. Rarely can he afford to take the bus to other towns and must either walk or hitchhike. He is one the poorest residents in our village. His wife has left him, and he is raising one boy by himself.

Diario's shack is delightfully breezey in summer with the all the gaps between the sticks. In Winter, however, the cracks just let in the wind and cold air. His shack does not have a proper door or windows, just tarps hung over the openings. Diario has colds and/or bronchitis most of the Winter. We give him paracetamol and cough syrup, but they are hardly a subsitute for a more substantial and warm place to live.

He is a simple soul with a heart of gold and a smile so big and so genuine that it warms you from head to toe. He is a very friendly guy and just loves to chat. He keeps a watchful eye on our place and alerts us immediately if anything is out of the ordinary. A dearer or more loyal friend we could not have.

We are uniquly qualified to build an inexpensive, natural house.  Before coming to Mexico, we built our own staw bale house and lived off the grid with solar and wind power.

We ran weekend workshops and had a live-in internship program for two years. Our home was featured on the the "National Solar Home Tour" for four years. Our web-site, which sees about 800 visitors a day, has a huge amount of do-it-yourself information on natural building techniques and renewable energy systems.

We were surprised when we got to Mexico to find that virtually every house in towns big and small is built with concrete blocks.  Cement is not an earth-friendly building material and takes enormous amounts of energy to produce...



The building budget of a family here is often used up with just the cost of the blocks and the supporting concrete posts and rebar. It makes us very sad to see so many unfinished houses, usually with just the foundation and walls standing. They are everywhere -- so much time and energy and money wasted and dreams shattered.



Building a small "earthbag" house for Diario will demonstrate a much less expensive and earth friendly alternative. Earthbag building is becoming common in many countries and uses free materials from the family land itself (earth) for the walls and roof. With so little cash invested in materials and with a Mexican family doing most of the work themselves, there can be more money available to finish the house with a doors and windows, plumbing and wiring. A plastered earth-bag house, with its two-foot thick walls, will withstand hurricanes and earthquakes and is far better insulated than a concrete block house.

By building a dome structure, there is no need for buying separate roofing materials like tin sheets. Many roofs here are flat poured-concete but they add a huge expense to building the house. They then sag, and eventually leak after a few years. Tin roofs don't insulate at all and are easily blown off in a strong wind. We don't know of a single tin roof in town that doesn't leak in a heavy rain. A dome house also provides room for installing a sleeping loft. This is a big plus for large Mexican families though the kids will probably squabble over who gets the groovy bedroom.

Earthbag construction lends itself to both conventional houses with vertical walls and to dome houses...


A conventional house is most suited to Diario's land which is long and narrow.

An earth bag home is constructed from bags filled with earth from land on or near the proposed house or in the case of our project with the local “gravel” which is a lightweight volcanic rock called “scoria”. Because of the countless air pockets in the gravel, an earthbag house built with scoria has the very high insulation value (R-45), equivalent in fact to a straw bale house!

 With double-strands of barbed wire laid between the courses to stabilize them, each course well tamped, and a heavy finish coat of plaster to cover the walls and roof... 

  ... the resulting house is strong, energy efficient, and uses much less of the earth's resources to make.  It is much more likely to be finished given the limited financial resources of our neighbors and is the kind of construction virtually everybody in the family can lend a hand with.

The main expenses for this project house are:

- two large dump-truck loads of scoria gravel
- 2 rolls of barbed-wire
- gunny sacks from the local feed store
- custom-welded heavy iron tamping tools (2)
- 20 sacks of lime for plastering
- dump truck load of sand, also for plastering
- windows and a door
- electrical supplies
- plumbing supplies
- wages for four locals for two months:  to build the foundation, to fill the bags, stack up courses of bags and tamp them, to lay out double strands of barbed-wire between courses, to set in the doors and windows in place, and to plaster both the inside and outside of the house.

 

While Jim is partially disabled now and can not assist with the physical labor of filling earthbags, he is an able organizer, supervisor, correspondent, writer, videographer, and web designer. Mindy, having worked for seven years building Solar Haven in the U.S. is experienced in carpentry, plumbing, electrical work, and plastering.

Please help fund this earth-bag house for Diario. You will be giving him a house he badly needs and one he never dreamed he could have. You will be giving him a house we think he truly deserves.

AND you will be helping our neighbors see for themselves that there really IS a way to build a great little house of their own and not run out of money before finishing it.  Ideas don't make much of an impression on the local folks. They must SEE it and experience it -- find out the walls really won't fall down and in fact are hell-for-stout and find out that it really is cool inside an earthbag house while all the other houses in town are not.  They will learn that we built the place for way less than any other house in town. Perhaps they may have even gotten curious and helped us fill and stack a bag or two and realized how easy it is.




We should mention that Hurricane Karl two years ago took down concrete block houses that were poorly constructed and, in fact, removed all or part of every tin roof in our village including Diario's of course.


An earthbag house is far stronger and would still be standing.

There is no reason to continue building houses with expensive concrete blocks which require so much energy to produce and are so destructive to the environment -- not when there is still earth and gravel and sand to be used instead and many hands available to do the work. An earthbag house just makes sense for the needs of the people of Mexico, for the environmental needs of our planet, and of course for our dear neighbor Diario.

Here are kids at Project Somos in Guatemala where a large earthbag center has recently been completed for abandoned or orphaned children.



"THE PROJECT TEAM"

 JIM AND MINDY PHYPERS

 Long before Jim and Mindy married 31 years ago, they both loved animals and wild places, exploring and hiking. Through out their marriage they dreamed of living simply and self-sufficiently and as close to the natural world as possible. Out on four remote acres in the desert of Arizona and then in the mountains of Veracruz, Mexico they got their chance and have dedicated themselves to living sustainably and trying to guide others to do the same.

 AMIT SCHANDILLIA

 Amit currently lives in Mumbai, India. He will be joining us soon as our first SolarHaven2 intern. This is an un-paid, six-month volunteer position, but we provide all meals and lodging.  He is very eager to get started with building the earthbag demonstration house and help us install the first componets of our solar electric system. He says he has always wanted to visit Mexico and over the years has gradually taught himself to speak Spanish. He has now created a sizable web site devoted to tips on how to learn Spanish (www.alwaysspanish.com).  He will be taking primary responsibility for supervising the local workers as they respond so much better to taking directions from a male, and his superior Spanish will come in mighty handy. He is hoping to take what he will learn about earthbag building back to India and become involved in a similar project there. 

 RODRIGO COOPER

 Rodrigo presently lives in Portland, Oregon but until recently lived in Veracruz, Mexico for 19 years and ran a free medical clinic in another small mountain town in our area. While he needs to remain in the U.S. now for medical reasons, his heart is still in Mexico. He is like a brother to Jim and is 1000% behind the goals for SolarHaven2. He is an absolutely invaluable resource for everything about the Latino culture and to help us determine the best ways to approach our neighbors with our admittedly radical ideas. Once the earthbag project is underway, he plans to visit for awhile and "start barking orders" as he put it. These will be most welcome, however, as Rodrigo has a life-time of building experience.

OTHER DEDICATED SUPPORTERS

 

INCENTIVES:

$5 - Personal letter of gratitude

$10 - Personal letter of gratitude plus ten photographs of our village and some of our neighbors

$15 - Personal letter plus 10 photos plus an MP3 recording of our five dogs howling "thank you" (or something like that) and we'll say hi, too  -- the Chachalacas and Melodious Blackbirds in the back yard also chimed in

$75 - Ten chapters in PDF format from our new book: "Living in a Small Village in Rural Mexico" -- a photo-essay with 500 color photographs

$125 - A high-fidelity, stereo music CD of Jim and Mindy playing relaxing popular, folk, and classical music for recorder, auto-harp, and synthesizer


$200 - Ten chapters from our book, and when the project is completed, a 20-30 minute high-definition video of all phases of building the earth-bag house and of the fun

First Donation of $2500 or more...

"A Week-long Vacation in Paradise"

for you and your significant other in our mountain village in Veracruz, Mexico and living in a beautifully restored 1971 vintage Airstream Land Yacht travel trailer (32')

- we live in the real "Old Mexico" few tourists ever see

- three meals a day -- guaranteed home-cooked tamales, garnachas, tostadas, and empañadas using tortillas made by hand with corn grown in our village -- bottled water, fresh fruit juices

- trips to the open-air market (Mercado) in another larger town in the area


- swimming and bathing in a secluded mountain pool with two waterfalls (short but steep trail)



- a trip to one of the tourist attractions in the area such as the "Lencero Hacienda" once owned by General Santa Ana


- or the world-famous Carrizal Hot Springs with seven pools built in the 1880's

 THE FINE PRINT:

1- we are sorry but we can not include the plane tickets to get you here

2 - we are a non-smoking/non-drinking family

3 - hope you like dogs -- we have five (plus four cats)

4 - we bathe in the waterfall pool pictured above -- our bathroom does not have a shower -- well, it does but it is stuffed with storage boxes

5 - for a detailed look at what life is like in our village, click HERE


IF WE EXCEED OUR PROJECT GOAL OF $6500:

First we want to buy Diario some furniture. He has only two matts on the floor for he and his son at present. Outside there is a small table to prepare food on and a fire-pit.

Then we would like to introduce simple efficient "rocket stoves" in our village and place one in as many homes as funds permit. Right now everyone wastes large amounts of wood cooking in an open fire-box. Many hours a week are spent scrounging for it. Housewives scour the hills locally while the men go far out into the countryside with their burros (or mules) to cut wood and haul it home.

 

The wood is burned in an open elevated firebox with bricks at the side to support a grill and cooking pots. Much of the heat goes out, not up, and wastes much firewood.

 
 
A rocket stove is a simple device to direct the heat of a fire directly to the cooking pots. They also burn the wood more completely with less smoke and ashes. Less smoke means healthier families and clearer air. They are very inexpensive to make.


Far less wood is required for cooking which translates into less time collecting firewood and more family time. It also means fewer trees cut down and burned and thus less denuding of the forest cover.

We must mention that deforestation was one of the main reasons for the collapse of the Mayan civilization as well as that of the Anasazi people and the Easter Islanders. (see: "Collapse: How societies choose to fail or succeed" by Jared Diamond, 2005).

There is a big job for us to do in our village but we can't do it without your help!!

 "Muchas gracias, amigos" !!!!!
story_txt:
Diario is our neighbor in a village of 600 people in the mountains of Veracruz, Mexico. We are Jim and Mindy, creators of "Solar Haven" in Arizona, but now retired for health reasons to the more temperate climate of southern Mexico. We are the only Americans living in our village. Click HERE for many photographs showing what life is like here. Diario is mildly intellectually handicapped but he spends all day helping others.  He travels far and wide soliciting donations door-to-door for various charities in towns throughout the region.  He walks countless miles every week. Rarely can he afford to take the bus to other towns and must either walk or hitchhike. He is one the poorest residents in our village. His wife has left him, and he is raising one boy by himself.Diario's shack is delightfully breezey in summer with the all the gaps between the sticks. In Winter, however, the cracks just let in the wind and cold air. His shack does not have a proper door or windows, just tarps hung over the openings. Diario has colds and/or bronchitis most of the Winter. We give him paracetamol and cough syrup, but they are hardly a subsitute for a more substantial and warm place to live. He is a simple soul with a heart of gold and a smile so big and so genuine that it warms you from head to toe. He is a very friendly guy and just loves to chat. He keeps a watchful eye on our place and alerts us immediately if anything is out of the ordinary. A dearer or more loyal friend we could not have.We are uniquly qualified to build an inexpensive, natural house.  Before coming to Mexico, we built our own staw bale house and lived off the grid with solar and wind power. 

We ran weekend workshops and had a live-in internship program for two years. Our home was featured on the the "National Solar Home Tour" for four years. Our web-site, which sees about 800 visitors a day, has a huge amount of do-it-yourself information on natural building techniques and renewable energy systems. We were surprised when we got to Mexico to find that virtually every house in towns big and small is built with concrete blocks.  Cement is not an earth-friendly building material and takes enormous amounts of energy to produce... The building budget of a family here is often used up with just the cost of the blocks and the supporting concrete posts and rebar. It makes us very sad to see so many unfinished houses, usually with just the foundation and walls standing. They are everywhere -- so much time and energy and money wasted and dreams shattered.Building a small "earthbag" house for Diario will demonstrate a much less expensive and earth friendly alternative. Earthbag building is becoming common in many countries and uses free materials from the family land itself (earth) for the walls and roof. With so little cash invested in materials and with a Mexican family doing most of the work themselves, there can be more money available to finish the house with a doors and windows, plumbing and wiring. A plastered earth-bag house, with its two-foot thick walls, will withstand hurricanes and earthquakes and is far better insulated than a concrete block house. By building a dome structure, there is no need for buying separate roofing materials like tin sheets. Many roofs here are flat poured-concete but they add a huge expense to building the house. They then sag, and eventually leak after a few years. Tin roofs don't insulate at all and are easily blown off in a strong wind. We don't know of a single tin roof in town that doesn't leak in a heavy rain. A dome house also provides room for installing a sleeping loft. This is a big plus for large Mexican families though the kids will probably squabble over who gets the groovy bedroom. Earthbag construction lends itself to both conventional houses with vertical walls and to dome houses...

A conventional house is most suited to Diario's land which is long and narrow.An earth bag home is constructed from bags filled with earth from land on or near the proposed house or in the case of our project with the local “gravel” which is a lightweight volcanic rock called “scoria”. Because of the countless air pockets in the gravel, an earthbag house built with scoria has the very high insulation value (R-45), equivalent in fact to a straw bale house! 
 With double-strands of barbed wire laid between the courses to stabilize them, each course well tamped, and a heavy finish coat of plaster to cover the walls and roof... 

  ... the resulting house is strong, energy efficient, and uses much less of the earth's resources to make.  It is much more likely to be finished given the limited financial resources of our neighbors and is the kind of construction virtually everybody in the family can lend a hand with.The main expenses for this project house are:- two large dump-truck loads of scoria gravel- 2 rolls of barbed-wire- gunny sacks from the local feed store- custom-welded heavy iron tamping tools (2)- 20 sacks of lime for plastering- dump truck load of sand, also for plastering- windows and a door- electrical supplies- plumbing supplies- wages for four locals for two months:  to build the foundation, to fill the bags, stack up courses of bags and tamp them, to lay out double strands of barbed-wire between courses, to set in the doors and windows in place, and to plaster both the inside and outside of the house.
 
While Jim is partially disabled now and can not assist with the physical labor of filling earthbags, he is an able organizer, supervisor, correspondent, writer, videographer, and web designer. Mindy, having worked for seven years building Solar Haven in the U.S. is experienced in carpentry, plumbing, electrical work, and plastering. 
Please help fund this earth-bag house for Diario. You will be giving him a house he badly needs and one he never dreamed he could have. You will be giving him a house we think he truly deserves. AND you will be helping our neighbors see for themselves that there really IS a way to build a great little house of their own and not run out of money before finishing it.  Ideas don't make much of an impression on the local folks. They must SEE it and experience it -- find out the walls really won't fall down and in fact are hell-for-stout and find out that it really is cool inside an earthbag house while all the other houses in town are not.  They will learn that we built the place for way less than any other house in town. Perhaps they may have even gotten curious and helped us fill and stack a bag or two and realized how easy it is.
We should mention that Hurricane Karl two years ago took down concrete block houses that were poorly constructed and, in fact, removed all or part of every tin roof in our village including Diario's of course.
An earthbag house is far stronger and would still be standing.
There is no reason to continue building houses with expensive concrete blocks which require so much energy to produce and are so destructive to the environment -- not when there is still earth and gravel and sand to be used instead and many hands available to do the work. An earthbag house just makes sense for the needs of the people of Mexico, for the environmental needs of our planet, and of course for our dear neighbor Diario.Here are kids at Project Somos in Guatemala where a large earthbag center has recently been completed for abandoned or orphaned children.
"THE PROJECT TEAM"

story:
The Background...

I started Butterbee Farm, the only urban flower farm in Baltimore, in January of 2013. I leased land from a wonderful urban vegetable farm (Whitelock Community Farm) while I looked for a more permanent home for Butterbee, and tested out the flower business.

The demand for flowers in Baltimore is incredibly exciting. Local flowers are an enormous hit with florists, who often have to buy flowers from South America or the West Coast. Butterbee Flowers are also at market, DIY weddings, a farm stand, restaurants, and a bouquet CSA share.

The flowers are farmed organically and sustainably, using naturally occurring soil amendments and local compost and potting soil. They are never treated with chemicals such as pesticides or herbicides, and they are never planted into plastic. Bees visit frequently, as do people-- the farm has a steady stream of visitors and volunteers.

 The Dream... 

The dream is to grow more flowers to meet the needs of sustainably-minded flower lovers in Baltimore! My urban farm is a thirteenth of an acre. The new site is seven times that amount, a half acre! It is just outside of the city, sunny, amazing drainage, ideal soil, and absolutely beautiful. In addition to selling flowers, I will hold classes on herbal remedies, bouquet making, and flower growing. I'd like to have bee hives, too.

Why Give to this Project?

Organic vegetable farming is catching on, but organic flower farms are hard to come by. Butterbee Farm is one of a small handful of organic flower farms in the mid-Atlantic. Further, many organic farms use pesticides (naturally occurring, but still toxic) that kill bees in addition to pests. Butterbee Farm will never use pesticides of any kind. 

Starting a full-fledged farm means investing in the necessities that I am currently borrowing from other farms.

Here is what I need:

-a tool shed: $1,000

-a deer fence (deer pressure in the area is pretty intense): $1000

-basic tools like hoes/a precision seeder/harvesting knives: $1,000

-soil amendments, compost, and initial tillage: $2,000

-Water meter accessibility and drip irrigation (the most sustainable kind of irrigation): $2,000.

-Potting soil and seeds: $2,000

-Labor: $1,000

-Liability insurance and LLC status: $1,000

Any amount made over $11,000 will be used towards constructing beehives and planting native trees!

the flowers! featured here: calendula, verbena, bachelor's buttons, sweet annie
The bees!
The Butterbee Farm logo

story:
Biomimicry Study in Scotland

  • Hi! I'm Brian Jayne and I am currently pursuing a Master of Science in Sustainable Practice at Lipscomb University in Nashville, TN.
  • This campaign is to help me fund a trip to Findhorn College in Scotland for a week long Biomimicry training session. This is a rare opportunity to study with Biomimicry professionals and to gain a deeper understanding of how imitating nature can help us create a better world, for ourselves and future generations.
  • Biomimicry is a fundamental element of creating a sustainable world. This course will give me a deeper and more thorough knowledge of Biomimicry and how to apply it. To not only make our world greener, but sustainable.
  • For more in depth info, follow the links below...

http://www.biomimicryinstitute.org/about-us/what-is-biomimicry.html

http://www.findhorncollege.com/programmes/biomimicry.php

The Cost

  • The cost and expense of the Biomimicry course is separate from and not related to my tuition costs at Lipscomb University.
  • I need $2500.00 USD to cover the cost of the course and transportation.
  • The course tuition is 895.00 Euro (or $1142.00 USD)
  • Air travel is approximately 1099.00 Euro (or $1400.00 USD) as of May 15, 2012

The Impact

  • The knowledge and experience gained during this course will prepare me to bring Biomimicry concepts to everyday life for everyone. While Middle Tennessee will be my focus, this knowledge and experience will be valuable to all.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • I have no perks to offer other than my eternal gratitude and appreciation but you can trust that this knowledge and experience will be used to create a better, more sustainable world. 
  • Please help me spread the word for this campaign. Promoting this campaign means as much as financial contributions!
  • Please use the IndieGoGo share tools!

story:
The Sacred Land Sanctuary is located in Crestone, Colorado in the San Luis Valley at the base of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. The Sanctuary is an exceptional model for preserving Sacred lands for the purposes of spiritual transformation and ecological preservation.

The Sacred Land Sanctuary is unquestionably beautiful. And while all land is inherently sacred, the Sanctuary's 200+ acres holds a history that goes back to the Ancients. Evidence shows that native peoples utilized this land for meditation, wilderness quests, and spiritual transformation -- exactly what the Way of Nature Fellowship programs founded by the world-renowned environmentalist and spiritual teacher John P. Milton aim to provide to modern people.

Help us pay off the loan on the land so that the Sacred Land Sanctuary can continue to be used to expand consciousness and support spiritual growth and transformation!



What We Need & What You Get

  • $80,000 is needed to prevent the loan from defaulting by December 1st, 2013!
  • Perks include fine art photography, energetic essences, energy work sessions, and a range of Way of Nature Trainings and Passages!
  • Even if we don't reach our entire goal, we plan to use the funds as a payment on the loan in good faith that our continued fundraising efforts will be enough to pay off the entire balloon payment.
  • Any funds over the loan amount will be used to purchase an adjoining parcel and to improve infrastructure on the land including repairs on the rustic care-taker cabin, a kiva for dark retreat and placing boundary flags to facilitate continuity with the community.

Sangre de Cristo Mountains by Autumn Brooke Grinath.  Signed 8x10 print with $243 donation


The Impact

The Way of Nature Fellowship, founded by John P. Milton, offers nature-based programs that deepen one's relationship with Mother Earth, and help you to realize your own inner nature through an interfaith approach from several ancient traditions. Programs include Vision Quests, Contemporary Solo Quests, Nature Quests, Sacred Passages, Meditation Retreats, Rights of Passage, Awareness Training, Dzogchen Practice, Chi Gong and T'ai Chi Training, Study of Ancient Shamanic Processes and Traditional Wilderness Quest opportunities.

The Way of Nature Fellowship is responsible for the well-being of the Sacred Land Sanctuary, and several of Milton's students serve as land stewards. We are the folks organizing this campaign to support the Sanctuary.

The Sacred Land Sanctuary serves to protect and preserve this ancient, sacred land as a temple for human spiritual transformation and liberation through Nature Quests and other programs. We truly believe that a deep connection and communion with nature is vital for the preservation of the planet as well as individual quality of life. The Sacred Land Sanctuary also serves as a successful model for preserving sacred lands worldwide.

The Sanctuary is held by the non-profit organization Threshold, Inc. Threshold was created in 1972 to support projects that protect the earth, and to demonstrate ways that members of our society to bring more balance and harmony into our relationship with nature and the Earth.

John P. Milton experiencing one of the Sacred Meditation Seats.


************************************ TESTIMONIALS ****************************************

"Within minutes of my first visit to the Sacred Land Sanctuary, I had the feeling of coming home.When I'm on the land, I feel like I'm literally inside an incredibly compassionate, playful and aware being that is always communicating with me to the extent that I am able and willing to engage. Over the years, the stone seats and the sunny spots by the creek have become my guides, teachers, and playmates. I have come with my heartbreak. I have come in times of tremendous physical distress. I have come to play. I have come to rest. Within the tremendous scope of wisdom and possibility embodied in this land I find consistently the invitation to soften and dive ever more deeply into my own heart."
~ Masha, Sacred Land Steward

•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

"The Sacred Land Sanctuary has been a refuge for me and hundreds of others to practice and grow our sacred connection to the Earth and Source.  It has graciously served as a safe container for deep transformation to occur and has helped so many wake up to their true nature, true purpose, and a heart connection to this planet.  It is one of the most sacred, special, and unique places I have ever experienced, which is a result of it's location on this planet and the unique geological features that have converged upon it.  You can feel this when you go there.  It's palpable, it's beautiful, it has a voice, and it needs our help in protecting it."
~Jennifer Menke, Sacred Land Steward


Jenny, John and Brad

••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

"This land has spoken my truth to me and mirrored my own beauty in so many ways...one cannot help but sense the presence of the ancient ones. I hold a deep gratitude for my experiences with the stone meditation seats, the nature beings, and John Milton's extraordinary teachings. This land is truly archaeologically, spiritually and ecologically unique." 
~Galaxy Dancer, Sacred Land Steward

•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

"The Sacred Land Sanctuary in Crestone is one of the very rare places on Earth where humans have consistently related to the land in a sacred way, in an intimate, heart-felt, personal relationship, for thousands of years. Other beings of Nature who live on the land recognize this way of relating and thus are comfortable meeting us in a mutual celebration of life and friendship. The land itself is mostly wild and undisturbed, and is an exceptional supportive partner for healing and for opening of one's heart and mind. The land is truly a global treasure."
~Brad Michael Kahland, Sacred Land Steward

••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

"For me, being on the Sacred Land Sanctuary is being in a place where the veil between the physical and Spiritual realms is thin...the nature spirits and ancestors are present and witnessing, ready to assist in our spiritual transformation and purification. All our relations are ready to embrace us as we walk on a path of greater illumination, and the Land offers a unique opportunity to align with a higher frequency in order to shift global consciousness. The energies of the seats, the plants, the animals and the Spirits on the land are exquisitely supportive in this process."
~Amy Myszko, Sacred Land Steward

••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

     "Ever since I was a young child, it has been Nature that has brought me the most peace.  The wind has whispered sweet songs of advice and carried my troubles away with the clouds.  The Sun has warmed my spirit in times of darkness.  The soil has renewed my sense of curiosity and playfulness, and the water has brought balance and purification into my body and soul... 
     Among the industrial growth and urban sprawl of today's society, finding a quiet place to be alone in nature is increasingly harder to find.  What was once rolling hills and forests in my childhood is now a landscape of identical homes and manicured lawns.  I've seen how quickly Nature can be transformed by man. 
     The Sacred Land Sanctuary is one of those increasingly rare places where I can escape the effects of industrial growth.  Here I can breathe air that nourishes instead of pollutes.  I can feel the sacred vibration of the Earth, and recalibrate my own.  I can merge into the stillness, and find myself there."  
~Autumn Brooke Grinath
Sacred Land Steward

••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••

"My name is Per Jorgelin and I want to preserve this land because it is sacred... Having done two sacred passages there, I know how important it is for us.  I have myself taken people for a half day walk on the land several times, and even short-time visitors feel great love to and from this protected space."
~Per Jorgelin
Sacred Passage Student
Fundraising Contributor


John P. Milton with a Group of Students on the Land


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, you can still help support the Sacred Land Trust by helping to get the word out! Indiegogo has some handy share tools...and thanks so much for taking the time to learn more about the Sanctuary and the Way of Nature Fellowship.



North Crestone Creek Running Through the Sanctuary
story_txt:
The Sacred Land Sanctuary is located in Crestone, Colorado in the San Luis Valley at the base of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. The Sanctuary is an exceptional model for preserving Sacred lands for the purposes of spiritual transformation and ecological preservation.
The Sacred Land Sanctuary is unquestionably beautiful. And while all land is inherently sacred, the Sanctuary's 200+ acres holds a history that goes back to the Ancients. Evidence shows that native peoples utilized this land for meditation, wilderness quests, and spiritual transformation -- exactly what the Way of Nature Fellowship programs founded by the world-renowned environmentalist and spiritual teacher John P. Milton aim to provide to modern people.
Help us pay off the loan on the land so that the Sacred Land Sanctuary can continue to be used to expand consciousness and support spiritual growth and transformation!

What We Need & What You Get

$80,000 is needed to prevent the loan from defaulting by December 1st, 2013!

Perks include fine art photography, energetic essences, energy work sessions, and a range of Way of Nature Trainings and Passages!

Even if we don't reach our entire goal, we plan to use the funds as a payment on the loan in good faith that our continued fundraising efforts will be enough to pay off the entire balloon payment. 

Any funds over the loan amount will be used to purchase an adjoining parcel and to improve infrastructure on the land including repairs on the rustic care-taker cabin, a kiva for dark retreat and placing boundary flags to facilitate continuity with the community.

Sangre de Cristo Mountains by Autumn Brooke Grinath.  Signed 8x10 print with $243 donationThe Impact
The Way of Nature Fellowship, founded by John P. Milton, offers nature-based programs that deepen one's relationship with Mother Earth, and help you to realize your own inner nature through an interfaith approach from several ancient traditions. Programs include Vision Quests, Contemporary Solo Quests, Nature Quests, Sacred Passages, Meditation Retreats, Rights of Passage, Awareness Training, Dzogchen Practice, Chi Gong and T'ai Chi Training, Study of Ancient Shamanic Processes and Traditional Wilderness Quest opportunities.
The Way of Nature Fellowship is responsible for the well-being of the Sacred Land Sanctuary, and several of Milton's students serve as land stewards. We are the folks organizing this campaign to support the Sanctuary.The Sacred Land Sanctuary serves to protect and preserve this ancient, sacred land as a temple for human spiritual transformation and liberation through Nature Quests and other programs. We truly believe that a deep connection and communion with nature is vital for the preservation of the planet as well as individual quality of life. The Sacred Land Sanctuary also serves as a successful model for preserving sacred lands worldwide. The Sanctuary is held by the non-profit organization Threshold, Inc. Threshold was created in 1972 to support projects that protect the earth, and to demonstrate ways that members of our society to bring more balance and harmony into our relationship with nature and the Earth. 
John P. Milton experiencing one of the Sacred Meditation Seats.

************************************ TESTIMONIALS ****************************************"Within minutes of my first visit to the Sacred Land Sanctuary, I had the feeling of coming home.When I'm on the land, I feel like I'm literally inside an incredibly compassionate, playful and aware being that is always communicating with me to the extent that I am able and willing to engage. Over the years, the stone seats and the sunny spots by the creek have become my guides, teachers, and playmates. I have come with my heartbreak. I have come in times of tremendous physical distress. I have come to play. I have come to rest. Within the tremendous scope of wisdom and possibility embodied in this land I find consistently the invitation to soften and dive ever more deeply into my own heart."~ Masha, Sacred Land Steward•••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••"The Sacred Land Sanctuary has been a refuge for me and hundreds of others to practice and grow our sacred connection to the Earth and Source.  It has graciously served as a safe container for deep transformation to occur and has helped so many wake up to their true nature, true purpose, and a heart connection to this planet.  It is one of the most sacred, special, and unique places I have ever experienced, which is a result of it's location on this planet and the unique geological features that have converged upon it.  You can feel this when you go there.  It's palpable, it's beautiful, it has a voice, and it needs our help in protecting it."~Jennifer Menke, Sacred Land StewardJenny, John and Brad••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••••"This land has spoken my truth to me and mirrored my own beauty in so many ways...one cannot help but sense the presence of the ancient ones. story:
AMARUMAYO PROJECT

ADOPT A MEDICINAL PLANT!

OFFICIAL CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN FOR THE REALIZATION OF “AMARUMAYO” ETHNOBOTANIC RESERVATION IN SOUTH EAST PERUVIAN AMAZONIA, AIMING AT PROMOTING THE SAFEGUARD OF LOCAL MEDICAL CULTURE AND LOCAL POPULATION.

Amarumayo is a project that safeguards and promotes traditional Amazonian medicine and its related human and natural environment that is nowadays considered as an extraordinary example of cultural and natural setting at the highest risk of destruction.


ITALIANO

ESPAÑOL


Who we are. Etnopharmakon is a no profit organization with legal residence in Busto Arsizio (Italia) and in Calafell (Spain), born at the beginning of 2014 with the aim to preserve and promote practices deriving from traditional and unconventional medicine and people's cultures bounded to them, through environmental conservation projects, research, education, information.

Amarumayo (literally “snakes river”) is the name given by Inca people to the river “Madre de Dios”, that gives the name also to the whole region of south east Peru, close to Brazil and Bolivia border.

Nowadays the “Madre de Dios” is one of the places in the world with the higher biodiversity level but it is also a region with the highest rate of environmental risk that turns into cultural emergency because in this place culture and nature are strongly connected. The link between nature and culture is particularly clear in traditional medical practices, based on the use of unique local plants.

In the last years, the irresponsible and indiscriminate depletion of local resources – first of all wood and gold – has been becoming a devastation that is irreparably compromising the amazing biological equilibrium and the humane culture that is manifestation and example of harmonious bond between man and nature in this place.

Our aim is to give back to this desecrated land its dignity, protecting and valuing its amazing human, cultural and environmental richness.


Adopting a plant you can help us at build the “AMARUMAYO RESERVATION”, around 5 hectares ethnobotanic protected garden located in the namesake region of Perù, near the city of Puerto Maldonado.

Amarumayo will be a safe area where grow plants to be employed in traditional medicine practices meanwhile giving to the new local generation the possibility of rediscover and strengthen their cultural identity through formative projects aiming at leading young people to the knowledge and awareness of their culture conceived not only as a richness of the past but also as a strength with a great value in modern life.

Local curanderos of verify reliability will take care of the garden and of the plants that will be used for their practices, giving to other people the possibility of knowing this way of “taking care” based on a deep knowledge of human beings in their connection with natural environment.


“Adoption of a plant” means:

•                   contribute to the safeguard of Amazon forest

•                   protect an ancient knowledge of natural therapeutic practices

•                   contribute to the fight against indiscriminate depletion of human and natural resources (in this area the traffic of human beings , particularly children, is very widespread)

•                   take a concrete action against human rights disregard

•                   create an example of “virtuous circle” promoting social economic and cultural self determination

•                   Be active part involved in the project, not only a passive viewer

 

Thanks to your contribution we will manage to:

First goal: 

55% of the funds raised

•                   buy the land (about 2,000$ for hectare, 10,000$ for 5 hectares, if we do not reach the full amount we start buying less land )

•                 create gardening spaces freely used by local approved curanderos for their practices 

•                 create the ethnobotanic garden

Second goal:

25% of the funds raised

•                   create a covered garden for storage of necessary tools and to guest the beneficiaries of projects of training, information and research that will be enhanced both al local and global level. (1,500$ for a maloca; 4,000$ for dormitories, kitchen, bathrooms, tambos, storage plants)

•                  Support a continuous campaign of information, research and rising awareness.

20% of funds raised: indiegogo and perks 

step by step:

- 10%

first hectare of land and start Amarumayo reservation

- 20%

construction of maloca

- 30%

first work for structures

- 45%

increase of land

- 55%

last work for structures

- 100%

increase of land 


To adopt a plant is very easy:

With a contribute of minimum 50 $ you will become owner of a new plant that otherwise would not grow. In return, you will get a certificate attesting the adoption and you will periodically receive information regarding the progress of the campaign and all the other initiatives carried out by the association. Moreover you will be added into the supporters’ list enjoying all the related benefits.

However, it is enough a contribute of 10 $ to actively participate to the creation of the Reservation and to be part of the group!

In any case anyone will enter with the name he/she chose to enroll the group and all the name will be listed in the thanksgiving board (published on the net and affixed on the reservation) showing that behind every achievement there is a choice of each single person who autonomously has chosen to take part of this project, and showing that if anyone does what he/she can, we can really make the change.

Adopt a plant, give it the name you like: maybe the one of a special person as amazing act of love, take care of your plant and grow the seed of difference between life and destruction and between indifference and responsible life.

We will thank any contribution, doesn’t matter if big or small, with reward and anyone will be considered as part of the project.

In case we wouldn’t reach the budget, the project will in any case start, but the portion of land involved will be smaller and the second goal will be completed later.


Example of shipibo textile


8in/20cm


12 x 16 inches / 40 x 30 cm



60 x 24 inches / 150 x 60 cm


Example of coin purse


Example of Peruvian jewelry

      


Shaman Carlo Schenone Infante, with 15 years of experience in the use of the sacred medicine of  Yagé or ayahuasca. Student of maestro Adonias Quintero and in the past collaborator of the Takiwasi center.

story:
Short Summary

Regenerative Roots is a non-profit organization that is dedicated to building thriving communities through sustainable and agricultural programs.  Our first initiative is to design a 200 sq. foot indoor garden below our office which focuses on innovative agricultural practices, including Aquaponics.  A portion of all the produce we grow there will be donated to a local food pantry.  Our ultimate mission is to establish a community center in the southern NH area within the next five to ten years.

ReGenerative Roots was formed after its Board of Directors recognized the importance of local food security in an increasingly commercialized world.  Much of our food is currently produced in distant fields controlled by huge conglomerates rather than the local farms that had done so in the past.  In just a few generations our food supply has been drastically altered, but the changes have caused a slew of negative results that are just beginning to become apparent.  ReGenerative Roots is doing what small part it can to address this vital issue.

What We Need & What You Get

The proceeds from this funding campaign shall be used to build an 8 X4 ft. two tiered Aquaponics system at our office in Nashua, NH.  Items we need for the system include two grow beds, lighting, a filtration system, clay pellets, fish barrel, tilapia fingerling, piping, along with a litany of other items that are needed to ensure the system runs efficiently.

If you donate $100 or more to this campaign we will send you a $20 gift certificate to Whole Foods along with a ReGenerative Roots T-shirt.

If you donate $250 or more to this campaign we will send you a beautiful Aquaponics fish bowl system along with a ReGenerative Roots T-shirt.

The Impact

Our lifestyles have become so hectic that it is easy to lose sight of where we are going.  Never before have we had such a bounty available, but what has been taken in the exchange?  ReGenerative Roots is doing what small part it can to solve these complex issues by focusing our efforts on promoting local food security while simultaneously raising community awareness.

become so hectic that it is easy to lose sight of where we are going.  Never before have we had such a bounty available, but what has been taken in the exchange?  ReGenerative Roots is doing what small part it can to solve these complex issues by focusing our efforts on promoting local food security while simultaneously raising community awareness.

story:
JUNE UPDATE

Hi all.  Ok, we’re now into the final campaign push to fund this project. With the money pledged up to now I started production several weeks ago .... here’s what I’ve come up with so far:


Remember that this is still a work in progress and there are still changes to be made (for example: the music is still tentative). A key concern from feedback received up to now has been “it sounds too good to be true” ... “what’s the catch?"  To address this issue I’m going to need slightly more funding to cover travel costs for going to Phoenix and videotaping the prototype METROL equipment in successful operation. 

Another concern has been that if the promise of Metrol is so great, why isn’t there already abundant seed-money investment available for it?  While I can’t go into details on this, it should be said that there are specific reasons why METROL has been ‘under the radar’ ... and that this situation is fortunately about to change.

Project Overview

We're at a turning point in history. Growing numbers of people are feeling frustrated and anxious about escalating climate change (CC), but feel powerless do anything about it.  At the same time, clean, sustainable, and now affordable 'fossil-fuel-replacement'  technologies have emerged that could make a major impact on the CC problem and are ready to go, but—for a variety of reasons—remain relatively unknown and unused. 

One particularly intriguing new development—and one that very few know about—is a hydrogen-based liquid fuel for cars and trucks called Metrol that does not require fossil fuels, but can instead be made in massive amounts from garbage, sewage, farm waste, forest waste ... as well as from solar & wind energy. Unlike other hydrogen fuels that require high pressure or extreme refrigeration, Metrol is a liquid at room temperature and can thus utilize existing gasoline and diesel-fuel infrastructure: ...i.e. tanker trucks, existing gas stations, pipelines, and standard vehicle gas tanks.

Metrol is different from other biofuels.  Instead of simply extracting methane (CH4)  from biomass and then burning it as a fuel, the making of Metrol goes one critical step further:

      — the methane is separated into solid CARBON and pure HYDROGEN— 

The carbon can then be sold to industry for large profits to make revolutionary new carbon-based manufacturing materials that are stronger than steel and lighter than aluminum. The gaseous hydrogen is combined with nitrogen and carbon dioxide from the atmosphere to make a liquid fuel that's easy to handle, transport, and store in a standard internal-combustion-engine (ICE) car.  

Once the liquid Metrol is inside a car—and after leaving the gas tank—the mixture is vaporized and pressurized utilizing waste heat from the engine. The hydrogen is then typically separated out from the carbon dioxide and the nitrogen (which return to the atmosphere from where they originated) so that the engine itself is typically burning only pure hydrogen, which is much cleaner than burning methane.  A car running on Metrol actually cleans the air that it drives through by capturing nitrous oxide (a key component of smog) from its intake air.  Fortunately, only minor changes are required to convert a standard ICE car (of which there are now over 1.2 billion in the world) so that it can burn Metrol.  Even better, that car could still run on gasoline if Metrol wasn't yet locally available.

The developer of both Metrol and the proprietary technology that allows it to work within ICE cars, trucks, boats, and airplanes—is Roy McAlister of McAlister Technologies (Phoenix, Arizona). Roy is a professional engineer with over 150 patents related to renewable energy.  He wrote a 2005 book called "Solar Hydrogen Civilization". He’s founder and president of the American Hydrogen Association, teaches at Arizona State University, and In 1995 won the top engineering award of Environmental Professional Engineer of the Year by the Association of Energy Engineers.   (References  available upon request)


I’m David Vasquez, a filmmaker, computer-graphics specialist, author, college instructor, and environmental-educator in San Francisco.  I have a doctoral degree focused on science education and I’ve been researching and keeping tabs on tech' developments related to large scale environmental problems like climate change.  In 2009 I wrote a book called “Mr. Swan’s Big Idea” (available on Amazon.com) about the promise of solar-hydrogen fuel-cell railways. I’m currently involved in a major initiative to bring environmentally-clean “Waste-To-Energy” technology to the 2nd largest city in Indonesia. To see my LinkedIn profile visit: 

https://www.linkedin.com/in/david-vasquez-ed-d-...

To see my website visit:

    www.DavidVasquezProductions.com

I’m excited about  Metrol because it can have all the sustainability advantages of hydrogen (i.e. no carbon emissions, unlimited supply) plus the convenience & low-cost advantages of gasoline. It's also very scaleable, ... it could be made in large refineries or potentially with small-scale home-production units where people essentially make their own fuel.

Metrol has the potential to make history as an energy ‘game-changer’ because, unlike any other fuel or power source for cars, it can facilitate a "grassroots", 
large-scale transition away from fossil fuels with minimum disruption to existing infrastructure.  A car owner would not need to buy a brand new car to “go green”, but could instead convert an existing car for low cost. 

By eliminating widespread amounts of both (a) naturally-occuring rotting of biomass; and (b) the burning of CO2-releasing fuels (especially fossil fuels), widespread use of Metrol could effectively “pull” large amounts of carbon out of the atmosphere and bring ‘parts-per-million’ (PPM) levels down to safe levels (i.e. below 350 PPM).

With Metrol, literally ALL the obstacles that have in the past blocked hydrogen from widespread use have been solved ... this includes safety, ease-of-use, and cost. 

The economics of Metrol are especially attractive because of potential windfall profits and rampant job creation from the carbon-capture factor.  As mentioned above, the making of Metrol captures large amounts of carbon that would otherwise be greenhouse-gas waste ... and turns it into a lucrative manufacturing resource for extremely strong and light building materials like carbon fiber, graphene, and carbon nano-tubes.


To solve Metrol’s obscurity problem, I plan to make a very short, mostly animated film that clearly illustrates how Metrol works and how readily it can transition our world from today’s quagmire to one with both clean energy use AND improved economy. 

Solving the climate-change emergency will require a worldwide  “tipping point” phenomenon (a “snowball effect”) toward clean energy that’s nothing short of a grassroots miracle. Metrol—because of its minimal need for infrastructure change—could play a big part in such an effort, ... and the short film I’m planning to produce could do much to popularize and support the commercialization of Metrol. 

Please join me in this project with a contribution of whatever you can afford.

What We Need & What You Get

The production budget of $12,000 covers mostly labor costs involved in both scriptwriting (instructional design & testing) as well as media production ( planning, 3-D modeling; 2-D & 3-D animation; live action videography, post production, and soundtrack design).

For each level of contribution, donors will receive a ‘perk’ that is proportionate in value to their donation. Such perks range from customized postcards, posters, and tee-shirts to—on the high end—opportunities to appear in the film production itself.

The Impact

The most important use of the video will be for investor presentations to raise funds for the next key step in bringing METROL to market: .... the conducting and paying for exhaustive 3rd-party field testing of the METROL system to prove its reliability.

The finished piece will also be used for internet video, science-museum exhibits, and possibly television.  It will additionally be incorporated into a feature-length documentary film now in production called  “Keys to the Cage”  by Michael Henning (director of "Hempsters; Plant the Seed”) that chronicles  the now-in-progress emergence of the hydrogen economy.

In all cases, when people see, from my short  film, the unique practical, environmental, and economic benefits of using METROL, they’ll likely do one or more of the following: 

(a) realize for the first time that phasing off of fossil fuel is not an impossible task; (b) begin talking with friends, colleagues, and public officials about developing and encouraging Metrol infrastructure; (c) invest in businesses devoted to supporting Metrol use; (d) have their own car converted to Metrol;

Ideally this all leads to a groundswell movement and  ‘tipping-point’ phenomenon suitable in scale for effectively altering the course of climate change. When we as a society genuinely believe that something like this can realistically happen, it can.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge is being clever and persuasive enough on the instructional design to motivate action that overcomes the considerable ‘inertia’ (resistance to change) that exists in our society around energy use and motor-vehicle use. The biggest risk is not collecting enough funding to do the animated film project justice.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word .... tell your friends ... please send this link to 5 people you know.
