story:
As Seen On:

The Raw Botanicals Refill System empowers YOU to create change in the world.

How? The Refill System provides you with a simple, effective and money-saving way to refill body products at home, helping reduce the number of plastic bottles that pollute oceans and rivers, fill up garbage dumps and destroy habitats.

Stop Recycling. Start Refilling.

The Raw Botanicals Refill System is more than just natural, organic bathroom amenities. It’s a system designed to empower individuals with a simple, effective and money-saving method for reducing waste from plastic bottles.

Our Story

Raw Botanicals is a 12-year-old company, born in Costa Rica. We produce high quality, organic and natural amenities and cosmetics that are used by individuals, spas and hotels around the world.

An Eye Opening Challenge…

As the company grew, we were approached by hotels interested in using Raw Botanicals organic amenities  - soap, shampoo and conditioner – for their clients. Always up for a challenge, we soon discovered, with horror, what was taking place in the hotel industry in Costa Rica – a country known for its environmental preservation and heritage. Hotels were buying tiny (2 oz) plastic bottles of bathroom amenities for their guests and then simply throwing them away.

It wasn’t hard to do the math: one 150-room hotel could expect to use 400 or more of these bottles every day. That’s over 150,000 bottles every year, in just one hotel! And, Costa Rica has almost 1000 hotels. The waste was staggering.

Acting upon the company’s commitment to the environment, we set out to change things. We created a simple, attractive and cost-saving dispenser system for bathrooms that can be refilled again and again. Now, hotels in Costa Rica use this refill method as a way to provide a high quality experience, save money, and protect the environment.

But don't take our word for it - check out this video featuring one of our luxury villa clients here in Costa Rica:


The Next Step…

With the success of the hotel refill system and its impact on the problem of waste from plastic bottles, we saw an opportunity to massively increase the breadth and depth of this impact by providing individuals with a similar system for use in their homes.

How It Works

We’ve designed Raw Botanicals Refill System with our Papaya Tangerine Body Wash to ensure it saves time and money, and reduces waste from plastic bottles.

A better use of your time and money.

Everyone uses products like body wash, shampoo and conditioner everyday. It’s not uncommon for these products to run out quickly (the average person goes through a 10 oz bottle of body wash in 30 days). And, for those of us who insist upon natural and organic products, its no secret these products can be expensive!

The Refill System saves you time by eliminating the need to go to the store to purchase more. Simply refill the bottles you use in just a few seconds at home. Also, because the Refill System provides high quality, natural and organic products in bulk quantities, there is a significant cost savings.

Reducing waste from plastic bottles.

Our true passion for the Refill System comes from its ability to empower YOU to have real, substantial impact on the waste created from plastic bottles, without leaving your home.

The bottles provided with the Refill System have a life span of more than three years. By refilling these bottles, we’re giving individuals a simple and easy way to keep 1000s of bottles out of recycle bins, landfills (or worse – oceans, rivers and habitats!). Just consider the waste created from body wash use:

We’ve designed the Refill System to tackle this problem head on and give individuals and families the ability to make a difference, without any special effort. Just use and refill!

But Wait... I Recycle?!?

Don't get us wrong - we love recycling. L.O.V.E. However, we also know that recycling has a huge carbon footprint associated with it. Refill eliminates this footprint and is just a much better option all around. Check out this quick, fun video we put together to explain:


What are we going to do with the money?

EVERY REFILL SYSTEM PURCHASED = REDUCTION OF PLASTIC WASTE

We’ve already put a ton of time, money and energy into creating the products and pieces that make up the Raw Botanicals Refill System. The money raised here will go toward building what we call the Refill Movement.  The money we’re seeking to raise will fund the first production run and distribution so you can get your kit and start enjoying natural, organic products today while making a difference. Any additional money will go toward marketing efforts to expand the Movement and expand the refill line to include our Banana Glistening Hair Balm and Ylang-Ylang Shampoo.

Manufacturing - We know you want your kit as soon as possible, so we are already working with our lab on production. We need the money to get our first batch of kits manufactured and shipped.

Distribution – The goal of the Refill System is to empower individuals to effortlessly reduce waste from plastic bottles. As such, we want to make the Refill System easily available for as many people as possible. To do this, we want to broaden our distribution channels by building a base of Representatives that will extend the impact of the Refill System to their friends, family and community.  

Marketing - YOU are the genesis of this movement.  In order to build and sustain momentum, we need you to tell your friends, family and community about this campaign. The easiest way to do that is through social media: PLEASE POST THIS ON FACEBOOK, TWITTER, G+ & INSTAGRAM A PHOTO!

The Future – The Refill Movement

We’re excited about providing individuals and families the ability to have real impact on the plastic bottle waste problem. So much so, that we are actively recruiting individuals to become Representatives in their communities. 

What Is Involved As A Rep?

Reps are empowered to spread the word about Refilling to their friends, family and communities – increasing the impact of the Refill Movement:

The video below shows how easy it for Reps to share the message of the movement and have fun while making money!


Want More Info About Being A Rep?


Perks

As a donor, you can receive any of the following perks. You can have different levels of impact based upon your level of support.

If you really want a life-changing experience, come visit us in Costa Rica to help energize the Refill Movement! (All Expenses Paid- See $3,500 perk)

story:
What this campaign and this work are about: the 'problem' and a solution

We are a diverse team of university and college faculty, students, researchers, and Yap outer island community members, working together with the people of Yap State Outer Islands, including Ulithi Atoll (Federated States of Micronesia) to help understand the challenges facing the coral reefs and the communities that rely on them. This is a positive story, making positive change in a revolutionary way -- combining tradition with science.   Learn more about us and our affiliations below, and read on to learn about and support this effort!

As many of us know, coral reefs around the world are suffering declines.  But what many of us don't often think about is that traditional cultures, which have been stewards of many of these systems for centuries, are also in peril.  And that's part of the problem. People and their environment are intimately linked, especially in places where people depend on their immediate environment everyday -- for everything from building materials to daily sustenance.  In the Micronesian outer islands, climate change, overfishing (not commercial fishing, we are really dealing with subsistence fishing), and cultural change (much of it initiated during and following World War II, are having negative effects.  Yet the reefs we have looked at in this region are relatively healthy (Yap state), which gives us all an excellent starting place.  So what's going on?  In a nutshell:

1.  Reefs are beginning to stress due to climate change as well as local impacts.

2.  People are still only subsistence fishing, and overall population has not increased much, but what used to be over 70 different kinds of fishing has been reduced to far fewer methods, including some new ones, such as night spearfishing, newer nets, motor boats etc.  This is increasing impact on fewer fish types.  Loss of diverse methods is leading to loss of diversity (and abundance) of fish.  On stressed reefs, this leads to problems.

3.  Overfishing of some fish, such as parrotfish (e.g.. from night spearfishing), is leading to negative ecological impacts -- parrotfish eat algae (a good thing for reefs), and with fewer parrotfish, algae starts to overgrow reefs, leading to larger declines.  A sort of downward spiral.

4.  Some traditional management, which has been effective for years, has either been lost, or is not being enforced, or has not been adapted to the changing times.

5. The people of the outer islands have a tremendous amount of knowledge about their reefs and how to manage them, they just need assistance with how to adapt that to these rapidly changing times.  We help provide knowledge about the reefs, and the impacts of fishing and other problems, and they can develop the management plans.  And they are.  And it is working.

We are combining science and tradition to achieve sustainable ocean management.


The key

Outer islanders have been sustainably managing their oceans for centuries, probably millennia.  Part of their success lies in the unique governance structure they still have today -- they are autonomously (self) governed.  They make their own decisions, community by community with their own councils.  They can implement management immediately if they need to, and each community can adopt a plan that is unique to their needs and environmental context.  In addition, they have a deep historical knowledge of management and traditions that have protected their ocean resources over time.  Currently, a loss of tradition combined with introduction of new and more impactful fishing methods, and the effects of climate change, are creating an imbalance leading to declines.  The key is their knowledge, which can be revived, new knowledge which we can help provide, and their governance, which allows them to implement adaptive management NOW.

Some background

 There are many ways to approach conservation and management.  Yet the vast majority of efforts focus on only a few methods.  We are doing it differently -- letting communities lead, and focusing on combining tradition with modern science. In 2010, recognizing a decline in reef health and fish populations, islanders from the remote Micronesian outer islands of Ulithi Atoll, Yap State realized that their health, their communities, and their future were being threatened by rapid environmental and cultural change.  They asked for help to learn how to manage a sustainable food supply from their oceans, a critical issue for their present and future wellbeing.  We are a team of scientists who came together to respond to the islanders' call for assistance.  This project is realizing unprecedented success.  You can learn more about us and read our reports at: onepeopleonereef.ucsc.edu

Other organizations that have been instrumental include the Oceanic Society (also organizes natural history and research expeditions to Ulithi and other places) and Bluecology (works with Pacific Islanders with a special interest in students), and CFR-West (organizes collaborative fisheries programs).  Our program follows another successful conservation effort on Ulithi, the Ulithi Marine Turtle Project (learn about this on our website).

A unique approach

We are doing things differently.  Our project has both a reef ecology as well as a social science component.  We talk extensively with people from all demographics and roles in the community to better assess the nature of fish and reef declines (including changes in fishing practices), historical context, and the role that traditions -- and the loss of them -- may play.   We also conduct extensive ecological surveys of the reefs, and share what we find with the communities.  We discuss specific findings, such as the link between parrotfish declines, night spearfishing, and algal overgrowth on reefs and how traditional management could address this.  We are encouraging both a reconnection to traditional ways, as well as an embracing of modern techniques -- such as motor boats (rather than abandoning them which is not practical) to address problems in resource abundance and reef health.  This project is achieving rapid success and support.   Our task is to listen to, learn from, and provide information to the islanders so they can make their own decisions, not to push any outside agenda or to represent external interests. We need funds to expand this project across the Caroline archipelago to additional outer islands in Yap state -- at their request.  Word of the project is spreading fast, and the people are requesting assistance.

Who we are

We are a team of dedicated scientists and community leaders, coming together with outer island people to effect positive change in how their marine systems are managed, their way.

I am Nicole Crane, one of the project leaders.  My own childhood growing up overseas in developing countries (my parents were with USAID and world hunger), and on sailboats, gave me a love of the sea, and also an appreciation of the importance of cultural diversity and traditional knowledge.  My science background has given me the tools to better understand our Planet's marine systems, and the impacts that are altering them today.  My background has also helped me understand the critical link between traditional knowledge and environmental sustainability -- a key to effective management for many communities.  

John Rulmal Jr. is also a project leader, community leader, and organizer from Ulithi Atoll (Yap outer islands).  He is helping to make this project a success in the outer islands -- uniting communities around tradition and management.  He engages Chiefs, Leaders and community members to come together around this central issue -- maintaining sustainable food supplies by ensuring healthy reefs and fish populations.  Hofag (Unity)!

Our team of scientists and organizers consists of

From right to left above:

Nicole Crane, Oceanic Society and Cabrillo College - reef ecology and community engagement

Dr. Giacomo Bernardi, University of California Santa Cruz - fish genetics and diversity

Dr. Peter Nelson, Collaborative Fisheries Research West - community-based fisheries management and fish ecology

Dr. Michelle Paddack, Oceanic Society and Santa Barbara City College - reef ecology and herbivorous fish dynamics

Dr. Avigdor Abelson, Tel Aviv University - coral reef ecology and restoration

Left above is John Rulmal, Jr., Ulithi Falalop Community Action Program, Ulithi Atoll, FSM - community liaison, local project management, community activator!

Affiliated scientists Kristin Precoda, statistician (Oceanic Society), and Sara Cannon, undergraduate student (University of California Santa Cruz), and Dr. Steve Moore (ecology robotics, and instrumentation)

Kelsey Doyle produced our video!  Kelsey Doyle (Hawks Peak Productions) is a documentary filmmaker and journalist from Santa Cruz, California whose passionate work focuses on significant environmental and political topics.

Renee Buchanan who worked on our website and social media

Local science teams - critical in collecting data for us to help analyze

Chiefs and Leaders of the Yap Outer Islands - key to developing and carrying out the plans!

Here are some of the 'local scientists'! (below from left to right, Basco-Asor Island, Alex-Falalop Island and Mario-Mog Mog Island)

What your support will help achieve

We have successfully worked with communities on Ulithi Atoll (the 4th largest atoll in the world).  Your support will help move this project out across the other outer islands.  It will help us conduct a workshop this summer where we will bring together representatives from across the outer islands to help develop management plans and share knowledge about reef ecology and fish life histories.  They are asking for this.

Your funds will contribute to an effort that will enhance conservation, sustainability, and livelihoods across a vast area of the Western Pacific ocean -- these islands autonomously govern over 100,000 square miles of ocean in one of the most biodiverse regions on Earth.  This is an unprecedented ocean sustainability opportunity: working together to protect oceans, people, and culture.  You can help make a difference.

Specifically

We need funds to be able to move this project forward quickly. We want to take advantage of the momentum in the region.  Grant funds (see our supporters below) have enabled us to work on Ulithi for the past 3 years, and to establish the method and get the word out.  Now we are ready to move forward at the request of outer islanders. We plan to hold a sustainable ocean management workshop for outer islanders in the summer 2014 on Ulithi Atoll. Examples of what your donation would cover:

$30 will pay for informational materials for 2 people, or will buy one ship passage for one person to the summer 2014 workshop on Ulithi Atoll.

$50 will pay for food for one week for one person during the 2014 workshop.

$200 will buy a digital camera for one island community so they can photograph their fish catch and send it us as data so we can inform them of fishing pressures and management success.

$500 will fund one local science team from an island community to participate in training to learn how to collect data to inform themselves of management success.

$1,000 will support four local high school and college students to join the project and help develop the plans, encouraging youth participation.

$2,000 will send one science team member to Ulithi to meet with communities, participate in the workshop, and conduct surveys.

$25,000 will fund a summer field expedition for both local and US/Israel based science teams to conduct surveys, and work with specific communities (up to 3 islands) to develop management plans.

**Funds will be used where they are most needed. The more funds we raise, the more we can do and the more islands we can include.

See the perks for contributing!!

The Impact

This project has already achieved unprecedented success in the region.  These outer island communities have not been involved directly in a program like this -- designed to assist them to better understand and manage their reefs.  We have been able to involve more communities, more quickly, and with concrete plans, than any other program in the region -- and it will serve as a model beyond the region.

Some quotes:

"We need to sacrifice and plan today to ensure a healthy food source and healthy reefs for the future. " Juan Uwel, Falalop reef owner and manager, Chief, Falalop Island, Ulithi Atoll.

"We started setting aside temporary protected areas and limiting night spearfishing, and we saw changes in 3 months--more fish!"  - Ignathio Waithog, reef owner and manager, Mog Mog Island, Ulithi Atoll

“We need to have a common understanding around management, so that everyone agrees and supports it. Understanding the old ways, and the impacts of the new ways, can help us protect the ocean for our children, and their children.  We need to do this, its making a difference.” - Isaac Langal, Chief on Asor Island, Ulithi Atoll

"I am really supporting this project because it addresses health of the reefs but also health of the people and it means food security for our people.  I am happy we are doing this as a community " Dr. Arthur Yolwa - Mog Mog Island, Ulithi

"Our Island of Satawal is very much in need of information to help us adapt our management, we need this! " Sabino Sauchomal, Yap State Legislature Floor Leader, citizen of Satawal Island.

 By funding this project, you will help us advance this program throughout the region -- something the people want, and are ready for.  We don't need to 'sell it', we just need funds to do it!

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help in other ways too!  We need help with report preparation, website development, and even people who want to support themselves to come to the islands with us to help collect data (see the website for Oceanic Society and go to their volunteer vacation link to see research expeditions that support this work).

We also need the word spread!  Share this campaign with as many people as you can, and let them know about this work and the unique way we are achieving results with sustainable ocean management.  You can use the Indiegogo share tools to help!



Supporters to date -- thank you!!


And Kelsey Doyle, who produced our video!  Hawks Peak Productions

story:
About Us

The Ghana Youth Environmental Movement (GYEM) and the Ghana Youth Climate Coalition (GYCC) are together the largest youth led climate and environmental group in Ghana. We are made up of thousands of young people from diverse backgrounds with the deepest passion for environmental sustainability and climate justice.

Our Founders who are young people are also Climate Reality Leaders personally trained by former US Vice President Al Gore to educate and empower the public about the causes and dangers of climate change and possible solutions.


We are raising money for Power Shift in Ghana! This event is slated for July 25-28 in the University of Ghana campus.

What is Power Shift?
Power Shift is the largest youth-led and first ever environmental/climate summit in Ghana to train and empower more than 500 young people with the tools, techniques and technology to solve the environmental crisis in Ghana.

Power Shift is a 3 days summit- a single mammoth gathering of young people in our generation to learn, device and discuss strategies to fight for environmental justice in Ghana. It is time to set and shift priorities from the bottom to the top, at all levels of society, from policies to implementation. 

We believe we are the most strategic generation that has a better chance of saving our environment and the planet for our children and future generations. 

Why Power Shift?

Our generation is faced with unprecedented environmental crisis and challenges:

-The Government of Ghana has signed an agreement with a Chinese Energy Group to construct a 700MW coal fired power plant in Ghana;

-Agbogboshie, a community in Ghana has been named among The World's 10 Most Polluted Places;

-Water pollution through illegal mining ('Galamsey') is destroying rivers and water bodies and threatening access to good drinking water;

-More than 20 whales have been seen washed ashore dead in areas of oil exploration in Ghana since 2009;

- Ghana loses GHS750m (more than $1.875m) annually due to poor sanitation delivery. 

What We Need 

We are hoping to raise $10,000 for Power Shift.

The funds will be used to pay for accommodation, transportation and subsistence (meals and refreshment) of the hundreds of young people traveling from all length and breadth of the country - from all the 10 regions of Ghana for the 3 days mammoth gathering.

We will also pay for the summit venue and space, summit materials/stationery and honorarium for some selected resource persons, experts and trainers who will be training participants.

If we are not able to raise our target funding, we will have to cut down on the number of participants for Power Shift who are very qualified and equally passionate about taking action for the earth. We want to prevent doing this and that is why your support means everything to us.

Why Does Your Contribution Matter?

The youth are the future of Ghana. They are the stewards of the environment and future policy makers and leaders. Ghana needs the youth to protect the environment. The conference has to happen to ensure that Ghana will be protected from the ravages of climate change. If the young people of today are not equipped and empowered to protect the environment, we have little or no chance of dealing with the impacts in future. Donations of any size are greatly appreciated.

The Impact

Your contribution will make Power Shift possible no matter how small it is. "Little drops of water make a mighty ocean" so no donation is too small. The more people we can have donate, the  more we will reach our goal soon.

Issues of environmental injustice and climate change affect all of us no matter where we live, so supporting Power Shift in Ghana means protecting the planet no matter where you live. As Archbishop Desmond Tutu puts it, "we are in this together". We believe supporting Power Shift is supporting humanity and global conservation and sustainability.

We have successfully run campaigns on coal and promoted renewable energy as the way forward for a clean future. That is the future we want and with your support, Power Shift can bring that future even steps closer.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are so many ways you can help us aside donating. Please get the word out there for us. Tell people about Power Shift in Ghana. Share this page to your social media networks, someone might see it and donate. You can also share the youtube video you just watched. The more views we get, the more likely we will get someone donating or supporting our cause. Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

The Moratorium on offshore oil drilling along the east coast ends in 2 short years, and the Obama administration approved seismic testing off the east coast last year allowing the oil industry to move forward with their plans to test and drill for oil. The fight is now!

The NC state congress and Governor McCrory are open arms to the oil industry, buying into large oil's claim of increased revenue and job opportunities for the state, but we know better!

Coastal tourism's proven yearly contributions to North Carolina include 30,000 jobs (twice as many as would be generated by offshore drilling), 2.75 billion dollars (50% more than would be generated by offshore drilling), and 260 million dollars generated for state and local taxes (more than twice what would be generated by offshore oil drilling), according to a 2013 study by North Carolina State University, and the 2013 numbers from the Commerce Department.

These numbers only speak directly to the tourism industry and make no reference to the jobs and revenues generated from secondary tourism for example construction jobs, commercial fishing, teacher salaries, government services, law offices, medical facilities and professionals, auto mechanics and so on. All of which are in danger due to the negative impacts of offshore oil drilling.

We like our booming tourism industry and see no reason to risk thousands of jobs and billions of revenue for a dirty industry that promises less jobs, less revenue and a catastrophic down side.

What We Need

BOEM, Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, has been conducting public hearings in coastal towns gearing residents for big oil's intentions of testing and drilling for oil off the east coast. We have been doing our best to educate people about the issue and to encourage them to go to these meetings, speak out against offshore oil, and reach out to their representatives and state governors to express their opinion.

We have also been launching a marketing campaign in order to have a wider reach and hopefully influence more people to get involved, and to let the decision makers know how we feel.

We are specifically seeking funding for two billboards currently in the works that will be located on the two major highways leading to and from the Outer Banks, NC, I-64 going west to Raleigh and US 158 going north to Virginia.

We have enough to cover about 2 - 3 months, but this fight could last a year or two, or longer! We need your help to keep these billboards up so that the millions of people that visit the Outer Banks every week from spring to fall understand what's at stake and can help us influence the decision makers.

Any contribution is greatly appreciated!

    How Else Can You Help

    Visit http://www.NotTheAnswerNC.org

    Click here to file an official federal statement.


    Make your comments:

    1. Information-rich, specific, and geographically-focused.
    2. Clearly communicated, concise and supported by scientific evidence or sound reasoning.
    3. Descriptive of how you or the environment will be affected.

    Call Governor McCrory's office at 919-814-2000 and tell him not to risk our proven, more profitable coastal tourism industry in a risky chase for offshore petroleum.

    Then call your state senator & representative and do the same

    Then call the White House at 202-456-1111 and ask President Obama to rescind all lease sales for offshore drilling off the east coast.

story:
Please help Pierre AJ and Ben rebuild by contributing anything. We will use the money to repair the damages, pay for a security system, fix our stolen identity and get us back on our feet.

We will prove that these guys did not ruin our lives and we want to turn our house back into the fun welcoming place that it used to be.

If our goal is reached we will be able to have parties like we used to.

story:
Hello there friends, family & supporters!

My name is Ellen Enquist and I am a student at Boise State University in Boise, Idaho where I am majoring in Environmental Studies. I am fundraising for the Young Women's Environmental Leadership Retreat for which I have been accepted. 

The retreat is a 4-day (March 21-24) experiential workshop to give me the tools to engage my community around gender justice as it relates to environmental sustainability, and empower the women and females in my life to be fearless leaders. Which really isn’t something I can pass up considering women, environment, and leadership are 3 words that perfectly explain my future career. So I am asking you to help fund my way to California to help me become the next environmental leader in our society.

I am fresh off my 3 month internship with Greenpeace USA in Washington, D.C. where I learned all about grassroots campaigning, community organizing, and many other important aspects of the environmental movement. I am in the beginnings of a 100% renewable energy campaign on Boise State's campus and will be community organizing in Alaska this summer against that dirty old fossil fuel, coal. As you can see environmental leadership is something I can use greatly to my benefit for my future career. And anything you can give is greatly appreciated.

My cost breakdown is this:

-$450 for retreat tuition

-$250 for my plane ticket from Boise, ID to Oakland, CA

If you look to the right side of this page you can see some of the perks I am willing to give in return for you generous contributions!

story:
Recently our Australian Government has approved by the Environment Minister Greg Hunt late on Tuesday include the dredging of 3 million cubic metres of spoil – which will be dumped in the reef's waters – for the development of three coal export terminals at Abbot Point.

Read more: http://www.smh.com.au/environment/conservation/government-approves-massive-resource-projects-on-great-barrier-reef-coast-20131210-2z3z2.html#ixzz2n4gHaEPP

This will destroy our already fragile Great Barrier Reef and eventually lead to the destruction of the Reef and in turn the extinction of millions of endangered marine creatures.

My father was a great campaigner of the environment and particularly the coastal environment and I would like to follow in his footsteps and "make a difference" you can read about my father John Amor here:

http://www.standard.net.au/story/742733/south-west-loses-its-coast-care-champion/

I am sure if he was still alive he would be knocking on the ministers door right now!

The money from the campaign will go towards mounting an aggressive push to stop this from happening. Our current Prime Minister since been in power has not acted in Australian's interest and almost all his decisions have been based on supporting large companies to benefit the rich and not the majority of Australian's. To read more of what our Prime Minister has done read here:

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-09-07/road-ahead-for-abbott-government/4942822

If you cannot donate money I am in need of any legal advice and any lawyers or solicitors that can offer their services free of charge would be appreciated. Please help me and other Australian's to stop this environmentally genocide of our marine environment.


Yours Sincerely

Jeremiah Amor

story:
Tony Nocito Biography: 

I have spent my adult career working in the construction industry in the Greater New York area. For 25 years I operated my own contracting enterprises. My companies performed demolition and asbestos abatement on major projects in the New York/New Jersey area.

Development of the ABCOV® Method of Asbestos Destruction:

While in the asbestos abatement industry I realized the magnitude of worldwide asbestos contamination and of the horrific, devastating terminal health consequences borne by individuals exposed to asbestos and asbestos-containing materials. Billions of tons of asbestos-containing materials have been installed throughout the 20th century in factories, power industries, homes, refineries, automobiles, airplanes, railroad cars, military ships, private ships, military bases, government buildings, commercial buildings, office buildings, and schools, making everyone susceptible to lung cancer and Mesothelioma. Fact: There is no safe level of asbestos exposure, causing the permeation of asbestos contamination to become the largest environmental and health debacle facing our world today and many years in the future. Landfill space is quickly diminishing and there are more asbestos, asbestos-containing materials and asbestos-contaminated materials in the world than landfill space to store these asbestos materials. I knew something had to be done about the deadly hazards of asbestos. This motivated me to search out new methods and technologies for removing and permanently disposing of asbestos, asbestos-containing materials, and asbestos-contaminated materials. I initiated and underwrote research and development of the project known as the ABCOV Method of Asbestos Destruction at Battelle Memorial Laboratories in Columbus, Ohio, and Materials Science Laboratories of the Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, Georgia. During the 30 years developing the non-thermal; Federal Environmental Protection Agency approved ABCOV Method of Asbestos Destruction I encountered and treated a myriad amount of asbestos, asbestos-containing materials, and asbestos-contaminated materials. I discovered that no two asbestos-containing materials are alike, i.e. the percentage and type or types of asbestos, Serpentine or Amphibole or a combination of both, embedded in the matrix/ binder, the inconsistency of the matrix/binder and the contamination of the asbestos-containing materials by external hazards, such as, but not limited to, heavy metals, radionuclides, and volatile organics. Gaining this knowledge fostered the creation of various chemical formulas and the development of the most robust equipment needed to efficiently and completely destroy all forms of asbestos. 

IMPORTANCE of DESTROYING ASBESTOS AND YOUR CONTRIBUTION:

As of January 2014, 55 nations have banned asbestos, with an additional 16 nations placing restrictions on its use. Although all 28 countries of the European Union have banned the use of asbestos, the toxic mineral remains legal in the U.S. and Canada

Even though asbestos has been restricted and banned, there are billions of tons of asbestos remaining in our built environment, including landfills built to store asbestos. (EPA: "All Landfills Will Fail"). The asbestos in our built environment is a ticking time bomb that is ominous to our health and will remain so until it is permanently taken out of our environment.   

I have dedicated the past 30 years filing original patents, acquiring Federal Environmental Protection Agency and State approvals and refining the ABCOV® Method of Asbestos Destruction to full commercial availability. It's very important to those who suffer from lung cancer and Mesothelioma, their friends and loved ones to accomplish full implementation of the ABCOV Method of Asbestos Destruction to permanently remove asbestos from our environment to protect and prevent future generations from contracting and suffering from the fatal diseases lung cancer and Mesothelioma. 

    What Is Mesothelioma and What Are The Symptoms?

    Mesothelioma: A rare cancer of the membrane that covers the lungs and chest cavity (pleura), the membrane lining the abdominal cavity (peritoneum), or membranes surrounding other internal organs.  Signs of mesothelioma may not appear until 30 to 40 years after exposure to asbestos.

    Symptoms: 

    • Shortness of Breath;

    • Tightness in the Chest;

    • Constant Dry Cough;

    • Chest Pain;

    • Appetite Loss;

    • Enlarged Fingertips;

    • Nail Deformities.

     ASBESTOS STATISTICS:

    Your Contribution to The ABCOV® Method of Asbestos Destruction Will Help to Prevent Asbestos Exposure:

    • More than 3,000 people in the United States are diagnosed with Mesothelioma each year.
    • More than 125 million people worldwide encounter asbestos in the workplace.
    • Every five minutes someone in the world dies from asbestos-related illnesses, 100,000 people a year and 5 to 10 million people by 2030.
    • Every year there are more people killed by asbestos than in road accidents.
    • For the past 34 years, asbestos has been removed, although not eliminated, but simply bagged, tagged and stored in landfills.
    • What happens when asbestos is landfilled: bags break allowing asbestos to become airborne and migrate into the water table.  
    • EPA: “All Environmental Liabilities Involve Future Costs"
     
     

     

    1. Provide an Environmentally Safe way to Destroy Asbestos with a Non-Thermal, EPA Approved, Chemical-Physical Process that:

    • Eradicates Asbestos from the Environment;
    • Protects and Prevents the Public from the Devastating Effects of Asbestos Illnesses;
    • Provides the Most Cost Effective and Efficient Asbestos Destruction Process 

    2. Eliminate Landfill “Cradle-to-Grave” Liability:

    • By Terminating Asbestos Landfill Storage 

    • By Minimizing Waste

    • By End Product Recycling ​​

    3. Adds Value to our Environment by:

    • Ensuring Good Sustainable Environmental-Health Risk Management

    ABCOV PROCESS:

    • Destroys all 6 Forms of Asbestos and Asbestos Containing Materials
    • Addresses all Hazardous and Mixed Waste Asbestos Inventories
    • Non-Thermal
    • Federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Approved
    • Technically Proven
    • ABCOV Plant Equipment can be Built: Fixed-Base or Mobile, Modular System and Scalable to Meet Customer's Needs.

    ABCOV TEAM:

    Plant System Design:

    Five Chemical Process Engineers with Field Experience and More Than 15 Years ABCOV Experience and Patent Attorney with 20 Years Experience with ABCOV.

    Plant Operators:

    •  ABCOV Plant Operators: Must be Accredited Asbestos Abatement Supervisors and Handlers Who are Trained to Operate the ABCOV Process
    • Laboratory Technician to Verify Asbestos Destruction by Polarized Light Microscopy (PLM)
    • Independent Laboratory for Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM)

    TECHNICAL BASE:

    1. Strong Development Base through Battelle, Georgia Tech, Westinghouse Electric, Consolidated Edison, Catholic University, U.S. Navy, U.S. Air Force and U.S. Army; Awarded a U.S. Government $4.8M Research and Development Cooperative Agreement; 18 Years Pilot Plant Operations Testing and Destroying a Great Many Different Types of Asbestos-Containing Materials and Asbestos-Contaminated Materials.
    2. 30 years asbestos destruction experience 

    ONSITE ASBESTOS DESTRUCTION STOPS TRUCKING of ASBESTOS THROUGH YOUR NEIGHBORHOOD:

    NO ASBESTOS LEAVES THE ABCOV PROCESS UNTIL COMPLETELY DESTROYED:

    August 6, 2010 (E. Bishop, U.S. EPA to H. Ahmet)

    March 15, 2006 (M.S. Alushin, U.S. EPA to T.Nocito)

    June 25, 2004 (M.S. Alushin, U.S. EPA to T.Nocito)

    March 29, 2003 (M.S. Alushin, U.S. EPA to T.Nocito)

    March 30, 1999 (J.B. Rasnic, U.S. EPA to T.Nocito)

    February 14, 1997 (J.B. Rasnic, U.S. EPA to T.Nocito)

    May 31, 1996 (J.B. Rasnic, U.S. EPA to T.Nocito)

    March 28, 1995 (C.Simon, U.S. EPA to J.D. Craten, APG)

    March 15, 1994 (C.Simon, U.S. EPA to L.Paretsky, Con Edison)

    National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants for Asbestos – 40 CFR Part 61.155 Environmental Standard for Operations that convert the asbestos-containing waste material into non-asbestos (asbestos-free) material

    New York State Approvals

    Kentucky State Approvals

    Maryland State Approvals

    Connecticut State Approvals

    Oklahoma State Approvals

    Delaware State Approvals

    Illinois State Approvals

    Pennsylvania: Governed by EPA Region 3

    California: Governed by EPA Region 9 

    Minnesota State Approval follows NESHAP CFR 61.155.

    Wisconsin follows NESHAP CFR 61.155 but requires an Air Permit.

     Waste Advantage Magazine May 2014 Issue

    Clean Energy Technologies Will Create Waste by Tony Nocito

    The Asbestos Scene – Knowing the Hazards

    The Asbestos Debacle

    ABCOV® Treats Natural Occurring Asbestos In Silt, Dirt, and Rock

    EnergyPulse: Solve Cercla and SEC Asbestos Liability

    Construction & Demolition Recycling: On-Site Abatement

    ABCOV Method Overview – A Great Proactive Asbestos Solution

    Senate Designates the 1st Week of April “National Asbestos Awareness Week”

    ABCOV Process Cleanly Destroys Asbestos by Tony Nocito

    Congress Makes Progress Removing Asbestos from the Environment by Tony Nocito

    FY07 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) Language – “Non-Thermal Treatment of Asbestos and Asbestos Containing Material”

    Defense Department Awards Unique Asbestos Destruction Project to A-Conversion, LLC.

    Environmental Assessment

    New York Post : Transforming Asbestos Into Cash

    Characterization of Treated and Untreated Asbestos Containing Material – ConEdison of New York

    Capsule Report: West Valley Nuclear Services – Destruction & Decontamination of Radioactive Asbestos-Containing Material by the ABCOV® Process

    West Valley Nuclear Services Confirmation Letter by Vice President James Little

    Griffiss Air Force Base: Turning Asbestos Into Non-Toxic Material

    EPRI Report: Asbestos Disposal and Treatment Options November 1993

    To View ABCOV's Articles and Blogs, Please go to www.abcov.com

     

    Please give what you can afford to help the ABCOV Method accomplish its goals to prevent Mesothelioma from spreading by destroying asbestos in our built environment. Feel free to contact me with questions: email: tony@abcov.com  Phone; 212-571-9125

    Total Amount of Contributions Needed: 

    • $100,000.00

    Use of Contributions:

    • Perk $5,000.00 (5% of Funds Contributed)

    • Extend Patent Applications: $60,000.00

    • Social Media Marketing: $20,000.00

    • Sales Presentations, Trade Shows, and Travel: $15,000.00

    If ABCOV's contribution goals are not fully met, contributions will be put towards patents and social media marketing.

    Please share this campaign on your social media platforms. Your time and help will be much appreciated.

    Other Ways To Help:

    Mesothelioma is a horrific-devastating disease. People who contract Mesothelioma suffer greatly. Therefore, taking asbestos out of our environment is a must. If you are unable to contribute to the ABCOV Method campaign, anything you can do to help and support as a volunteer to a  person you may know who has contracted Mesothelioma or volunteer your time to a hospital or a hospice that treats Mesothelioma patience or any organization that is an advocate for Mesothelioma or Mesothelioma research hospitals around the world (see list on ABCOV website: www.abcov.com).

Please give what you can afford to help the ABCOV Method accomplish its goals to prevent Mesothelioma from spreading by destroying asbestos in our built environment. Feel free to contact me with questions: email: tony@abcov.com  Phone; 212-571-9125
Total Amount of Contributions Needed: $100,000.00Use of Contributions:
Perk $5,000.00 (5% of Funds Contributed)
Extend Patent Applications: $60,000.00
Social Media Marketing: $20,000.00
Sales Presentations, Trade Shows, and Travel: $15,000.00
If ABCOV's contribution goals are not fully met, contributions will be put towards patents and social media marketing.
Please share this campaign on your social media platforms. Your time and help will be much appreciated.
Other Ways To Help:
Mesothelioma is a horrific-devastating disease. People who contract Mesothelioma suffer greatly. Therefore, taking asbestos out of our environment is a must. If you are unable to contribute to the ABCOV Method campaign, anything you can do to help and support as a volunteer to a  person you may know who has contracted Mesothelioma or volunteer your time to a hospital or a hospice that treats Mesothelioma patience or any organization that is an advocate for Mesothelioma or Mesothelioma research hospitals around the world (see list on ABCOV website: www.abcov.com).

story:
A generous donor has offered to match dollar for dollar your donation, up to $2,500.  Donate today to double your impact! 

Summary

This campaign is raising funds on behalf of California Trout, a verified non-profit organization. 

What do the iconic trout waters of the Mount Shasta area and the meadows of the High Sierra have in common?

They are vital to California's water supply.

The spring-fed rivers of the Mt. Shasta area - the McCloud, Upper Sacramento, Pit, Fall and Hat Creek - provide a consistent source of cold water not just for fish but also serve as an important and steady source of water for millions of Californians. And, when healthy, Sierra meadows store water as the snow melts, releasing it over the summer and fall months when fish and people need it most. 

Yet many in urban areas don't realize their water has traveled hundreds of miles from these source areas to reach their tap. SOURCE, a short film by California Trout and Keith Brauneis Productions, will educate urban dwellers about where their water comes from and the need to protect it.  Despite the vastness and variable nature of our state, we are more connected than it seems -- by water. The film will also serve as a call to action for legislators to lead on policy that protects and invests in these important areas, to ensure our water security.

In the face of extreme drought and climate change, California experienced a crisis that threatened water availability and security for millions of people.  The volatile and variable climate trends are likely to become the norm in the state. Using science, policy, and ecological restoration, California Trout is committed to protecting the source waters that are vital to millions of Californians and, of course, the fish that inhabit those waters. 

We will be submitting SOURCE to many film festivals such as Wild & Scenic Films, the Environmental  Film Festival, among others.  We'll also use the film to engage communities, agencies, partners and the public in a discussion about restoring and protecting our source waters to secure our water future. 

How You Can Help

We are in need of funding to complete production and launch the film.  This is an important message that is long overdue.  The future of California depends on water, the liquid gold that powers our state. Help us raise awareness of our highly important source waters and support our work to pass legislation that will protect them. 

CalTrout and Keith Brauneis Productions have created successful campaigns in the past with films like Eternally Wild and Enough is Enough.  Eternally Wild helped raise awareness about the fate of the Smith River and inspired fans to advocate for its protection.  That effort assisted in the designation of the Smith as Outstanding Resource Waters, which provides protection from future mining threats. The film has aired in 165 cities worldwide. Enough is Enough told the story of the blue ribbon waters of the McCloud River, highlighting its important history and the impact it has had on California's native trout and fly fishing. Each film was nationally-aired, was in 2 film tours, and currently reside on more than 10 major websites. Visit Keith Brauneis Productions  for more related films and CalTrout to learn more about our conservation efforts.

Your Support

Your tax-deductible donation is the key to this project's launch and it's inevitable success. The dollars raised in this campaign will all go toward the many aspects required for filming, post-production, and launch of the film. By donating to the film you will receive communications about CalTrout projects and related topics including a monthly e-newsletter, The Streamkeeper's Blog, and quarterly digital magazine, The Current. 

Risks and Challenges 

Every production has inherent risks and challenges, thankfully we have done this many times before and understand the risks involved and how to avoid them, and how to use challenges to our advantage when we can't bypass them. We gathered a small team of seasoned adventurers, ready to face any road blocks.

With our combined years of experience and expertise in all aspects of this production, we feel confident that we will deliver an outstanding film that will help shape water policy and management in California. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in the position to donate to the campaign, please share this with your friends.  You can also learn more about the work CalTrout is doing on behalf of California's fish, water and people by subscribing to our monthly newsletter at caltrout.org.

story:
Overlook Mountain, in Woodstock New York, may well be one of the most important and sacred mountains in the Catskill region, if not arguably all the northeast United States. The mountain acts as a major gateway to Catskill Forest Preserve, half a million acres and is also the closest Catskill Mountain trailhead to the New York City metropolitan area. Overlook Mountain is also the center of Tibetan Buddhism in North America and was recognized as a sacred site by the Iroquois Confederacy at the Council at Onondaga in 1979. It is also a breeding ground for the endangered Eastern Timber Rattler.

Recently, some amazing archaeological and historical discoveries have been made in the Lewis Hollow section of Overlook Mountain. Giant stone cairns there may be ancient and of native origin. A leading SUNY archaeologist examined the cairns and great cairns present on the property and exclaimed “they are some of the best preserved and well constructed examples I have seen”. Deep mysteries exist on Overlook Mountain; Mysteries that the Buddhists and Native Americans recognize. Mysteries connected to the stars and the cycle of nature and humankind. You can learn more about these discoveries here or learn more about the history of Overlook Mountain Click here

Forty years ago the land that is home to these impressive stone cairns was threatened by real estate development. To protect this land and prevent the development of a 20 home subdivision, three families joined together and purchased two large lots of land on Overlook Mountain. From then till now they kept the land wild and undeveloped, allowing people to wander freely. Unfortunately the owners, who were once so interested in conserving the land, are no longer interested in doing so. They have put this land on the market ad it is now for sale.

Right now a non-profit is trying to buy the property and establish the Overlook Mountain Interpretive Center and Preserve. The 82 areas of land are listed as two lots for $630,000. Without asking anyone, this new non-profit has already received voluntary commitments from local neighbors and other interested parties for nearly $50,000 towards the purchase and conservation of the land. The current owners would probably accept an offer considerably lower than the $630,000 asking price, if it were from a conservation-minded group.

The property is listed at $630,000 and this non-profit can apply for a matching grant from New York State of up to $315k. This means that if we can raise $315k, New York State could match us for that same amount -- putting the total raised at $630,000. However, the state grant is no sure thing, so we must try to raise as much as possible with any excess going toward creating a small interpretive center.

The proposal for this non-profit to purchase the land for conservation and establish an interpretive center has been presented to the Woodstock Town Supervisor and Town Board, who feel it is a worthwhile effort and would also qualify for financial support from the town’s open spaces and recreation fund. And, the town Code enforcement Officer has found the proposal is an approved use under current local zoning laws, as a cultural center, museum or library.

So, now is the time and the need is URGENT because at any time, a developer with deep pockets could purchase the property and plan to build a subdivision, forever scarring the land and disturbing the archeological, historical, cultural and nature features found there.

If this non profit can raise the funds to buy the land it will BE permanently protected as a historic site eligible for listing in the National Register, enabling the public to enjoy and learn from it, RATHER than it becoming a private paradise for a wealthy landowner. In addition to preserving the land, the non-profit plans to build the Overlook Mountain Interpretive Center, a small building where people can learn about the history, culture and wisdom Overlook Mountain has to offer. Nothing like this exists now on Overlook or in Woodstock.

The dedicated folks behind this project are a 501(c)3 non-profit organization incorporated in the state of New York They have spent the past year trying to find a way to save this property. Pro bono legal representation has been provided through the New York Lawyers for Public Interest www.nylpi.org, for the filing of the 501(c)3 certificate of incorporation. This IndieGoGo account is linked directly to the 501(c)3 bank escrow account and all the funds will go directly toward purchase of the property.

Even if IT RAISES the full amount and ends up with over $700,000, this isn't enough to build the interpretive center with exhibits and programming. But it will effectively put the property into the right hands so it can eventually be protected in a way that honors and reflects all that Overlook Mountain has given to people through time, and ensures that while Overlook Mountain will continue to serve the public good in the future, the good public will also serve The Mountain,

Internet, this is where you come in: Help Save Overlook Mountain and build the Overlook Mountain Interpretive Center to protect the mountain.

The Indiegogo campaign is linked directly to the bank account of Overlook Mountain Center, Inc. It is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization registered with the State of New York. More details about the campaign can be found over here.
