story:
What We Do and Why

"There is something elementally satisfying about the challenge of this work, both personally and as a group."                                                                  -Bob Chapel - Jolly Rover Volunteer - Warwick, NY                                          

The Jolly Rovers are an independent organization of volunteer trail builders, from all walks of life, specializing in traditional stonework. Without the use of mortar, heavy machinery or imported materials, our volunteers transform highly damaged paths in public parklands into aesthetic works of art, using nothing but native materials found onsite and construction techniques that date back to antiquity.  



Our growing family of 30 volunteers contributes over 5,000 hours of skilled service  every year through building and teaching workshops in public parks and forests, with each individual volunteering an average of 150 hours annually. These volunteers employ their craft at the request of state, federal and nonprofit land managers on some of the most heavily trafficked and ecologically damaged paths in the northeastern United States.  



Many paths and trails that receive heavy visitation are in need of repair work due to erosion from heavy use. The resulting erosion creates unsightly scars, negative impacts on the ecosystem and sometimes worsens to the point where safety itself becomes an issue. 

The work we leave behind aims to inspire those that use it long after we are gone, proving that sustainability and beauty can be crafted into something of practical use for the public benefit. What we create proves that the spirit of volunteerism can still build beautiful things that will last for generations, allowing for increased access to both the experienced hiker and the novice individual, family or school group interested in enjoying a regions natural treasures.


Like similar stone structures from the ancient world that survive to this day, our work strives to continue the legacy of aesthetic and sustainable principles achieved by these early builders. Stone survives the test of time, and when constructed with care, structures built with it can be inviting and inspiring, welcoming people that might not otherwise venture into the woods. We believe this increase in accessibility directly affects the well being of a community as well as the preservation of such open space for future generations; after all, the more people that are able to identify with open space, the more they will fight to keep it.

"It’s my way of giving back to the community by improving our parks with structures that will outlive me, and doing that work with the greatest bunch of people I know."                                                                             -Bob Ricci - Jolly Rover Volunteer - Easton, PA


What We Need & Why

To this end we seek to grow so we can expand our volunteer efforts. We've been successful in testing out this growth over the past 4 years, with volunteer service hours growing by 25% annually and membership increasing at roughly the same rate. In order to sustain this growth and expand our reach to more regions we'll need to take the next step in officially forming as a tax exempt non-profit organization. 

There will be legal and accounting fees associated with the process of getting us through the strict state and federal requirements for tax exemption.  We will also need to insure the Jolly Rover organization and its members with a general liability policy for this upcoming growth year. Finally, we'll need to create outreach and promotional materials along with making numerous upgrades to our website. These website upgrades and outreach materials will allow us to describe our accomplishments of the past and detail our vision for the future.

- Insurance - $750 - General liability policy for all members. 

- Legal Services  - $7,500 - Incorporation and tax exemption.

- Web and Outreach Development - $6,375 - Upgrades to our existing website and the creation of outreach materials.

- Accounting - $625 - General accounting fees for the upcoming year. 

- Indiegogo - $765 - Indiegogo charges a 9% fee on all funds raised if we don't reach our goal, but only 4% if we do. Please help us reach our goal. 

We are humbly asking the public to help support these start up expenses in this campaign, the results of which will set us up as a fully independent organization capable of sustaining itself for the long term. The total estimate of $16,015 has been reached by obtaining quotes from professionals in each field. Unfortunately, since we are not yet a tax exempt organization, taxes will have to be paid on all donations received, so a percentage has been added on to each item listed above to help cover this requirement.

Should we be fortunate enough to raise more funds than the costs outlined above, they will be put into the organization's bank account and used to help support the Rover's next goal after achieving its tax exempt status, the hiring of a full-time Executive Director. With this Director we will be able to sustain the administration and logistics of our current scope of activity while also setting us up strategically to execute our Board of Directors desire to grow in the future.


Sustaining Ourselves Into the Future

As a tax exempt non-profit organization several opportunities will open up to us that will allow us to sustain our activities well into the future. All proceeds from these sources will be used to sustain and further the mission of the Jolly Rovers into the future.

Tax Deductible Donations - Through our growing network of friends and supporters, we will finally be able to accept gifts from donors in all the states we work in. 

Contracts - Through our years of work in the parks and forest system, we have made a name for ourselves as one of the most capable and technically advanced volunteer trail crews in the country. As a result, contracts with the United States Forest Service have been offered to us but we have been unable to pursue them due to us lacking tax exempt status with the IRS. Once obtained, we will be able to take advantage of these long term agreements which will help fund portions of our work for years to come. 

Workshop Fees - One of the ways we will be able to support our volunteers need for tools, equipment and gear maintenance will be to accept fees for the workshops we teach throughout the eastern United States. As our reputation increases so does the amount of workshop offers we get.

Grant Eligibility -  There are several annual funding opportunities through both the state and federal government which finance trail and park rehabilitation projects. With our tax exempt status, we would be eligible to apply for these.

History of the Jolly Rovers


The Jolly Rovers began with a small group of ten volunteers who met on the Appalachian Trail; these ten were veterans of a unique multi-year educational program with New York-New Jersey Trail Conference and the Appalachian Trail Conservancy at Bear Mountain State Park, NY, where professional trail builders from all over the country trained volunteers in the craft of traditional stonework for the benefit of the legendary Appalachian Trail.  

In 2011, three of these ten got together over dinner to develop an idea; to take the traditional stone working skills learned in one park and spread them to all parks in need, not just in New York, but all over the country.  When the three approached the ten with the idea, all were in. This jolly group of friends who committed themselves to rove became the Jolly Rovers. 

"Building with stone, building friendships, both to last a lifetime and longer; building them in tough conditions only makes them stronger."    -Alicia Mandelkow - Jolly Rover Volunteer, New York, NY        


                                                          

Now, in our fourth year of operation, we have begun to take the steps necessary to form as a fully operational nonprofit organization. A board of directors has been elected, bylaws have been written and the Rovers numbers have expanded to 30 full time crew members. Each of these members is trained over a four day period, free of charge, and apprenticed over ten additional days before gaining full membership. Collectively, these volunteers contribute a total of 5,000 hours of skilled service annually. With our recruitment interest remaining strong for next year, we fully expect these numbers to increase. 


Apart from our efforts to directly improve parklands in the northeast directly through our construction projects, another key part to our mission is to spread the knowledge to other volunteer groups across the country. We seek out organizations and government agencies in need of affordable training opportunities to enhance the skill sets of their own local volunteer communities. Our volunteer instructors currently travel from North Carolina to New Hampshire at the invitation of these host organizations and agencies, some of which include the United States Forest Service, the Appalachian Trail Conservancy, the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, the Wilderness Society, the Monadnock Conservancy and the Vermont Youth Conservation Corp.   

"The Jolly Rovers team provided not only one of the most sought out courses during the Wilderness Skills Institute, they provided one of the most highly rated segments of training. Their energy and enthusiasm for the craft was infectious and noted by just about everyone who took the course."                                                                                                                   -Bill Hodge - Director - Southern Appalachian Wilderness Stewards, The Wilderness Society                                                                                    
Through these workshops we aim to build a lot more than just works in stone, in every community we visit we strive to build the culture of camaraderie and volunteerism that has brought us together and keeps us coming back for more. 

     The Jolly Rovers will always be a small organization close to its roots, but through education initiatives our small organization can enhance the way volunteers do work in our public parks and forests across the country. Through our volunteer instructor program we can bring top quality instruction and inspiration to organizations and park agencies whose budgets are becoming increasingly tight every year.


What You Get!

NOTE: Indiegogo does not allow you to put a size or color down for certain perks below. If you choose a perk that does require a size or color you can email us that information at jollyrovertrailcrew@gmail.com or we will get in touch with you via email after the campaign is over.

Jolly Rover gear is fun to wear. It never ceases to amaze us just how many people look twice anytime they see the skull and crossed hammers, it's a definite conversation starter. The Jolly Rover emblem is a play off of the legendary "Jolly Roger" flag of pirate lore. We promise all donors that the Rovers do not employ the traditional practices of piracy associated with its original symbolism. Rather, its adaptation refers to the fact that the Rovers, by nature of our specialized work, are different, tackling every project with an independent spirit and sense of adventure. 


Stickers and Patches ($10-$25) - Both sport our emblem of the skull and crossed hammers. Stickers and patches are 3" X 3" circles with our white emblem on a black background. (Sticker is not pictured above, but is the same layout as the patch.) Donors that give $10 will get a sticker and $25 will get both a sticker and a patch.

Bandanna ($50) - Made in the USA from 100% American cotton, these have become very popular with our crew to wear or keep handy in ones pack; it's comfortable and keeps the sweat out of your eyes on active days of labor or recreation. Donors that give $50 will also get one of each item listed above.



Hat ($100) - The Jolly Rover baseball cap is made from 100% cotton and sports the embroidered skull and crossed hammers on the front with the "Jolly Rovers Trail Crew" lettering on the back. Donors that give $100 will also get one of each item listed above.



Organic T-Shirt ($200) - "Adventurous. Rigorous. Creative. Constructive." These words symbolize the Jolly Rovers volunteer effort and what you're supporting. A slight variation of the shirt our crew members wear in the field, these shirts are made from 100% organic cotton and carry the skull and crossed hammer emblem on the front and our Rover seal on the back. It's hard to find a more  comfortable shirt! Sizes run from small - 2X large. Donors that give $200 will also get one of each item listed above. 



Aurorae Yoga Mat Combo ($300) - Yoga is a great way to keep everything in line after a day of work or pleasure on the trail. This Aurorae Classic Yoga Mat is ultra-thick, extra-long with a focal point icon. Biodegradable and free from Phthalates, Latex & Silicone. It's one of the top selling yoga mats on Amazon.com. Thank you Aurorae Yoga for your support in this campaign! Donors that give $300 will also get one of each item listed above, that includes the Jolly Rover shirt, hat, bandanna, patch and sticker, a $100 value! Donors, please state which of the above colors you want when you place your order. (Left to right) Infinite Black, Solar Yellow, Seamist Green, Ocean Blue, Midnight Blue, Violet, Crown Purple, Hope Pink, Ruby Red, Royal Plum, Camarone Green, Earth Brown. 

Aurorae Multi Purpose Back Pack Combo ($300) - This Aurorae sport bag/multi purpose cross body sling backpack is great for yoga, hiking, biking, travel, gym, school and  the office. Donors that give $300 will also get one of each item listed above, that includes the Jolly Rover shirt, hat, bandanna, patch and sticker, a $100 value! Special thanks to our supporters at Aurorae Yoga for their support in this campaign. Donors, please state which of the above colors you want when you place your order. (Left to right) Taupe, Yellow, Green, Blue, Purple, Red, Ebony, Grey.

"Behind the Steps" Tour - ($1,000) The Jolly Rovers will organize and lead a day hike tour for you or a group to a Jolly Rover project of your choosing.  From the volunteers that swing the hammers and set the stones, you'll hear what goes into shaping a stone from a boulder to how it travels hundreds of feet to its final and precise destination using techniques that date back to antiquity. Donors will also receive the Jolly Rover shirt, hat, bandanna, patch and sticker along with the yoga mat and bag of their choosing!

Workshop ($3,000) - The Jolly Rovers will organize and execute a 2 day training workshop for 12 people with an organization of your choosing. The workshop course will be tailored to the needs of that organization and will teach volunteers and/or staff how to split, shape and build with stone in their given location. Courses will be organized for the 2015 calendar year. We ask that the organization chosen be one that the donor has an affiliation with so that proper introductions can be made. Additionally, we would be amiss to not bring a little Jolly Rover gear to all the workshop participants as well. To view the workshops we teach to our own crew members click here. Donors that give $3000 will also get one of each item listed above including either the yoga mat or bag of their choosing!

DELIVERY - Please allow up to 8 weeks from end of campaign for delivery.


In Closing

Considering what’s involved in this type of volunteer work, people ask us: “Why do you do this!?” The answer is simple, it’s not really “work,” at least not in the sense that most people tend to mean it. The draw comes from various desires in all of us; to create in ways that many jobs out there no longer allow us to, to leave something behind that benefits others long after we are gone, to challenge ourselves physically and mentally, to share a sense of camaraderie with a community, to build true friendships; in the end, we hope to continue creating a legacy where we build much more than steps and walls. Your support would be greatly appreciated.

We accomplish through hard work and cooperation with those we care about, the creation of lasting things of beauty.                                                                  -Karen Nelson - Jolly Rover Volunteer - Highland Lake, NJ


      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you feel like helping in another way, any support in promoting this campaign via social media, email, and of course word of mouth would be greatly appreciated. Indiegogo has several share options embedded at the top of this campaign page to speed the process along.

      You can also follow us on Facebook or Twitter; just search for Jolly Rovers Trail Crew. 

      Finally, if you know someone (perhaps yourself) that would be interested in joining the Jolly Rovers, please feel free to contact us at jollyrovertrailcrew@gmail.com.  We can fill you in on what it takes!

      And if nothing else remember...

      "Building with stone is cool, especially when there’s beer afterwards."        -Willy Diaz - Jolly Rover Volunteer - West Caldwell, NJ
story_txt:
What We Do and Why






"There is something elementally satisfying about the challenge of this work, both personally and as a group."                                                                  -Bob Chapel - Jolly Rover Volunteer - Warwick, NY                                          


The Jolly Rovers are an independent organization of volunteer trail builders, from all walks of life, specializing in traditional stonework. Without the use of mortar, heavy machinery or imported materials, our volunteers transform highly damaged paths in public parklands into aesthetic works of art, using nothing but native materials found onsite and construction techniques that date back to antiquity.  









Our growing family of 30 volunteers contributes over 5,000 hours of skilled service  every year through building and teaching workshops in public parks and forests, with each individual volunteering an average of 150 hours annually. These volunteers employ their craft at the request of state, federal and nonprofit land managers on some of the most heavily trafficked and ecologically damaged paths in the northeastern United States.  





Many paths and trails that receive heavy visitation are in need of repair work due to erosion from heavy use. The resulting erosion creates unsightly scars, negative impacts on the ecosystem and sometimes worsens to the point where safety itself becomes an issue. 
The work we leave behind aims to inspire those that use it long after we are gone, proving that sustainability and beauty can be crafted into something of practical use for the public benefit. What we create proves that the spirit of volunteerism can still build beautiful things that will last for generations, allowing for increased access to both the experienced hiker and the novice individual, family or school group interested in enjoying a regions natural treasures.








Like similar stone structures from the ancient world that survive to this day, our work strives to continue the legacy of aesthetic and sustainable principles achieved by these early builders. Stone survives the test of time, and when constructed with care, structures built with it can be inviting and inspiring, welcoming people that might not otherwise venture into the woods. We believe this increase in accessibility directly affects the well being of a community as well as the preservation of such open space for future generations; after all, the more people that are able to identify with open space, the more they will fight to keep it.
"It’s my way of giving back to the community by improving our parks with structures that will outlive me, and doing that work with the greatest bunch of people I know."                                                                             -Bob Ricci - Jolly Rover Volunteer - Easton, PA




What We Need & Why
To this end we seek to grow so we can expand our volunteer efforts. We've been successful in testing out this growth over the past 4 years, with volunteer service hours growing by 25% annually and membership increasing at roughly the same rate. In order to sustain this growth and expand our reach to more regions we'll need to take the next step in officially forming as a tax exempt non-profit organization. 


There will be legal and accounting fees associated with the process of getting us through the strict state and federal requirements for tax exemption.  We will also need to insure the Jolly Rover organization and its members with a general liability policy for this upcoming growth year. Finally, we'll need to create outreach and promotional materials along with making numerous upgrades to our website. These website upgrades and outreach materials will allow us to describe our accomplishments of the past and detail our vision for the future.


- Insurance - $750 - General liability policy for all members. 
- Legal Services  - $7,500 - Incorporation and tax exemption.
- Web and Outreach Development - $6,375 - Upgrades to our existing website and the creation of outreach materials.
- Accounting - $625 - General accounting fees for the upcoming year. 
- Indiegogo - $765 - Indiegogo charges a 9% fee on all funds raised if we don't reach our goal, but only 4% if we do. Please help us reach our goal. 
We are humbly asking the public to help support these start up expenses in this campaign, the results of which will set us up as a fully independent organization capable of sustaining itself for the long term. The total estimate of $16,015 has been reached by obtaining quotes from professionals in each field. Unfortunately, since we are not yet a tax exempt organization, taxes will have to be paid on all donations received, so a percentage has been added on to each item listed above to help cover this requirement.
Should we be fortunate enough to raise more funds than the costs outlined above, they will be put into the organization's bank account and used to help support the Rover's next goal after achieving its tax exempt status, the hiring of a full-time Executive Director. With this Director we will be able to sustain the administration and logistics of our current scope of activity while also setting us up strategically to execute our Board of Directors desire to grow in the future.




Sustaining Ourselves Into the Future
As a tax exempt non-profit organization several opportunities will open up to us that will allow us to sustain our activities well into the future. All proceeds from these sources will be used to sustain and further the mission of the Jolly Rovers into the future.
Tax Deductible Donations - Through our growing network of friends and supporters, we will finally be able to accept gifts from donors in all the states we work in. 
Contracts - Through our years of work in the parks and forest system, we have made a name for ourselves as one of the most capable and technically advanced volunteer trail crews in the country. As a result, contracts with the United States Forest Service have been offered to us but we have been unable to pursue them due to us lacking tax exempt status with the IRS. Once obtained, we will be able to take advantage of these long term agreements which will help fund portions of our work for years to come. 
Workshop Fees - One of the ways we will be able to support our volunteers need for tools, equipment and gear maintenance will be to accept fees for the workshops we teach throughout the eastern United States. As our reputation increases so does the amount of workshop offers we get.
Grant Eligibility -  There are several annual funding opportunities through both the state and federal government which finance trail and park rehabilitation projects. With our tax exempt status, we would be eligible to apply for these.


History of the Jolly Rovers



The Jolly Rovers began with a small group of ten volunteers who met on the Appalachian Trail; these ten were veterans of a unique multi-year educational program with New York-New Jersey Trail Conference and the Appalachian Trail Conservancy at Bear Mountain State Park, NY, where professional trail builders from all over the country trained volunteers in the craft of traditional stonework for the benefit of the legendary Appalachian Trail.  
In 2011, three of these ten got together over dinner to develop an idea; to take the traditional stone working skills learned in one park and spread them to all parks in need, not just in New York, but all over the country.  When the three approached the ten with the idea, all were in. This jolly group of friends who committed themselves to rove became the Jolly Rovers. 


"Building with stone, building friendships, both to last a lifetime and longer; building them in tough conditions only makes them stronger."    -Alicia Mandelkow - Jolly Rover Volunteer, New York, NY        




                                                          

Now, in our fourth year of operation, we have begun to take the steps necessary to form as a fully operational nonprofit organization. A board of directors has been elected, bylaws have been written and the Rovers numbers have expanded to 30 full time crew members. Each of these members is trained over a four day period, free of charge, and apprenticed over ten additional days before gaining full membership. Collectively, these volunteers contribute a total of 5,000 hours of skilled service annually. With our recruitment interest remaining strong for next year, we fully expect these numbers to increase. 







Apart from our efforts to directly improve parklands in the northeast directly through our construction projects, another key part to our mission is to spread the knowledge to other volunteer groups across the country. We seek out organizations and government agencies in need of affordable training opportunities to enhance the skill sets of their own local volunteer communities. Our volunteer instructors currently travel from North Carolina to New Hampshire at the invitation of these host organizations and agencies, some of which include the United States Forest Service, the Appalachian Trail Conservancy, the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference, the Wilderness Society, the Monadnock Conservancy and the Vermont Youth Conservation Corp.   


"The Jolly Rovers team provided not only one of the most sought out courses during the Wilderness Skills Institute, they provided one of the most highly rated segments of training. Their energy and enthusiasm for the craft was infectious and noted by just about everyone who took the course."                                                                                                                   -Bill Hodge - Director - Southern Appalachian Wilderness Stewards, The Wilderness Society                                                                                    

Through these workshops we aim to build a lot more than just works in stone, in every community we visit we strive to build the culture of camaraderie and volunteerism that has brought us together and keeps us coming back for more. 



     The Jolly Rovers will always be a small organization close to its roots, but through education initiatives our small organization can enhance the way volunteers do work in our public parks and forests across the country. Through our volunteer instructor program we can bring top quality instruction and inspiration to organizations and park agencies whose budgets are becoming increasingly tight every year.




What You Get!
NOTE: Indiegogo does not allow you to put a size or color down for certain perks below. If you choose a perk that does require a size or color you can email us that information at jollyrovertrailcrew@gmail.com or we will get in touch with you via email after the campaign is over.

Jolly Rover gear is fun to wear. It never ceases to amaze us just how many people look twice anytime they see the skull and crossed hammers, it's a definite conversation starter. The Jolly Rover emblem is a play off of the legendary "Jolly Roger" flag of pirate lore. We promise all donors that the Rovers do not employ the traditional practices of piracy associated with its original symbolism. Rather, its adaptation refers to the fact that the Rovers, by nature of our specialized work, are different, tackling every project with an independent spirit and sense of adventure. 

Stickers and Patches ($10-$25) - Both sport our emblem of the skull and crossed hammers. Stickers and patches are 3" X 3" circles with our white emblem on a black background. (Sticker is not pictured above, but is the same layout as the patch.) Donors that give $10 will get a sticker and $25 will get both a sticker and a patch.
Bandanna ($50) - Made in the USA from 100% American cotton, these have become very popular with our crew to wear or keep handy in ones pack; it's comfortable and keeps the sweat out of your eyes on active days of labor or recreation. Donors that give $50 will also get one of each item listed above.





Hat ($100) - The Jolly Rover baseball cap is made from 100% cotton and sports the embroidered skull and crossed hammers on the front with the "Jolly Rovers Trail Crew" lettering on the back. Donors that give $100 will also get one of each item listed above.



Organic T-Shirt ($200) - "Adventurous. Rigorous. Creative. Constructive." These words symbolize the Jolly Rovers volunteer effort and what you're supporting. A slight variation of the shirt our crew members wear in the field, these shirts are made from 100% organic cotton and carry the skull and crossed hammer emblem on the front and our Rover seal on the back. It's hard to find a more  comfortable shirt! Sizes run from small - 2X large. Donors that give $200 will also get one of each item listed above. 









Aurorae Yoga Mat Combo ($300) - Yoga is a great way to keep everything in line after a day of work or pleasure on the trail. This Aurorae Classic Yoga Mat is ultra-thick, extra-long with a focal point icon. Biodegradable and free from Phthalates, Latex & Silicone. It's one of the top selling yoga mats on Amazon.com. Thank you Aurorae Yoga for your support in this campaign! Donors that give $300 will also get one of each item listed above, that includes the Jolly Rover shirt, hat, bandanna, patch and sticker, a $100 value! Donors, please state which of the above colors you want when you place your order. (Left to right) Infinite Black, Solar Yellow, Seamist Green, Ocean Blue, Midnight Blue, Violet, Crown Purple, Hope Pink, Ruby Red, Royal Plum, Camarone Green, Earth Brown. 

Aurorae Multi Purpose Back Pack Combo ($300) - This Aurorae sport bag/multi purpose cross body sling backpack is great for yoga, hiking, biking, travel, gym, school and  the office. Donors that give $300 will also get one of each item listed above, that includes the Jolly Rover shirt, hat, bandanna, patch and sticker, a $100 value! Special thanks to our supporters at Aurorae Yoga for their support in this campaign. Donors, please state which of the above colors you want when you place your order. (Left to right) Taupe, Yellow, Green, Blue, Purple, Red, Ebony, Grey.
"Behind the Steps" Tour - ($1,000) The Jolly Rovers will organize and lead a day hike tour for you or a group to a Jolly Rover project of your choosing.  From the volunteers that swing the hammers and set the stones, you'll hear what goes into shaping a stone from a boulder to how it travels hundreds of feet to its final and precise destination using techniques that date back to antiquity. Donors will also receive the Jolly Rover shirt, hat, bandanna, patch and sticker along with the yoga mat and bag of their choosing!

Workshop ($3,000) - The Jolly Rovers will organize and execute a 2 day training workshop for 12 people with an organization of your choosing. The workshop course will be tailored to the needs of that organization and will teach volunteers and/or staff how to split, shape and build with stone in their given location. Courses will be organized for the 2015 calendar year. We ask that the organization chosen be one that the donor has an affiliation with so that proper introductions can be made. Additionally, we would be amiss to not bring a little Jolly Rover gear to all the workshop participants as well. To view the workshops we teach to our own crew members click here. Donors that give $3000 will also get one of each item listed above including either the yoga mat or bag of their choosing!



DELIVERY - Please allow up to 8 weeks from end of campaign for delivery.

In Closing
Considering what’s involved in this type of volunteer work, people ask us: “Why do you do this!?” The answer is simple, it’s not really “work,” at least not in the sense that most people tend to mean it. The draw comes from various desires in all of us; to create in ways that many jobs out there no longer allow us to, to leave something behind that benefits others long after we are gone, to challenge ourselves physically and mentally, to share a sense of camaraderie with a community, to build true friendships; in the end, we hope to continue creating a legacy where we build much more than steps and walls. Your support would be greatly appreciated.
We accomplish through hard work and cooperation with those we care about, the creation of lasting things of beauty.                                                                  -Karen Nelson - Jolly Rover Volunteer - Highland Lake, NJ




  Other Ways You Can Help If you feel like helping in another way, any support in promoting this campaign via social media, email, and of course word of mouth would be greatly appreciated. Indiegogo has several share options embedded at the top of this campaign page to speed the process along.

story:
I'm Andreas Neunert and welcome to my campaign. With your support we can truly Save the Virachey National Park in Cambodia.

Für Deutsch bitte nach unten scrollen !

The Plan

... to place at least 10 motion-triggered cameras deep inside Virachey National Park, Cambodia in January 2014 to proof existence of endangered species and justify limiting concessions to land already granted. A team of local rangers picks them up 2 months later, before the onset of the rainy season. The expedition will take around 2-3 weeks.

Have a closer look at this previous GPS recorded trek to Veal Thom grassland inside the park. We will go another 10-20 km north than what you can see on the map close the Lao border and place the cameras on the holy Haling Halang mountain.

 Small gifts for small donations ;). Look to the right    -->

 Twitter: 

 

The Dilemma

Virachey National Park is located in the extreme Northeast of Cambodia in an area also known as "The Dragon's Tail" of the Kingdom. At 3,325 sq. km is Cambodia's largest national park and it is bordered by protected areas in Laos to the north and Vietnam to the east -Nam Kong PPA and Chu Mom Ray, respectively. According to the highlander people who live in the park's buffer zone along at the Sesan River, tigers, elephants and possibly even rhinoceros make their homes in Virachey, however their existence is not verified and no conservation group or NGO is currently protecting them.

In 2008, the World Bank abandoned their conservation and ecotourism programs at Virachey. read more Sections along the Vietnamese border have been sold off to rubber developers, and illegal loggers and poachers penetrate the park with exemption from punishment. Upwards of 90% of Virachey has been made available for mining exploration, however according to unofficial reports, there are simply not enough valuable mineral deposits to justify extraction by the company that holds the exploration license.

 

The Opportunity

An ineffective moratorium on logging is currently in place in Virachey and elsewhere in the region, yet illegal logging and land sales continue unabated. Nevertheless it offers a last hope for discovery and conservation in a place where scientific work has never been done. There are 140 mammal species likely to live in the park, at least 15 among them are rated endangered, critically endangered or probably exstinct according to the IUCN Red List. If we can capture images of this wildlife, it will provide positive proof that the park retains biodiversity that should be preserved, and justify limiting concessions to land already granted. If the cameras can capture the image of tiger, or snap a photo of a rhino, we can change the destiny of the endangered species that may still call Virachey home.

Small proof excists that the biodiversity of the park is extraordinary. But this is by far not enough.

                           

Cat Footprints

                                                 

Clouded Leopard dung

                                                         

Elephant dung

 

Siamese Crocodile "critically endangered"                      

This Siamese crocodile captured near Jark Village on the O Lai Lai River in the park's buffer zone. The Siamese croc has been written off by NGOs as extinct in Virachey. This picture proves the opposite.

 

They know the way so my mom doesn't get scared ;) 

 

The Park

Virachey National Park is one of the largest protected areas in Cambodia, covering 3,325 square kilometers of tropical forests and grasslands streching east to Vietnam, north to Laos and west to Stung Treng Province. It is bordered by an equally-large wilderness to the north on the Laos side called Nam Kohng Provincial Protected Area (NKPPA), a 55,000 hectare jungle in Ratanakiri called the Vuen Sai-Siem Pang Protected Forest. To the east, it connects to Chu Mom Ray National Park in Vietnam. And Virachey is the vital link wedged in between.

 See map. 

 

The Reason for Motion Triggered Cameras 

Studies showed that this is the most effective method.

  • ..." smaller population numbers "... " while this could be due to higher hunting of jaguars and their prey species, it could also be due to more rigorous research methods, including more camera traps used in the current study. "
  • " While the cameras captured 57 big cats in the Sunderbans Tiger Reserve (STR) region, a similar study in areas outside the tiger reserve last year had spotted 20 animals. "

Attending a training in Thailand at the end of this year with a conservation NGO on "How to put up motion triggered cameras" will increase the chance of getting valuable photoshots.

 

The Park in the News

  • Mongabay.com - " Exploring Asia's lost world " 
  • Mongabay.com - " Into the unknown mountains of Cambodia: rare birds, rice wine, and talk of tigers " 

 

The Initiator

My name is Andreas Neunert. At the moment I work with "Doctors Without Borders" in Kampong Cham, Cambodia in a Tuberculosis project. I went trekking to the Veal Thom Grassland in Virachey in April '13 and I was so fascinated that I decided to take action for this highly under pressure beautiful wilderness. Find me on Facebook and drop me a line.

 

The Finances

One highend camera + safetybox costs $549,-

... and I dont walk 2 weeks with a machete north carrying a crappy camera that does not work at the end ;) 

  • " The market leading trail camera has a remarkably fast shutter speed of just 0.2 seconds so that you will not miss fast moving animals."
  • " Want the best trail camera ever made?  Look no further. " 
    • " No glow infrared "                ...so we don't scare something
    • " Near-instant recovery time "  ...so we don't miss something
    • " 20-30k pics per battery set " ...so something can play with it for more than 2 month
    • " Durability is best in class "     ...so something does't scare the camera

 

plus an additional lock each around $15

plus a memory card each around $15

= $579 for each Camera Set

The more cameras the better but we are aiming to put up at least 10

10 x $579 = $5.790

Food and porters appr. $400,- per week = $800

$5.790 + $800 = $6590

     

    Remember ...

    • You can contribute more than the value of a specific Award... you still get the one chosen.

     

     

     

    "Awkun Charraan" - "Thank you very much" to our supporters.


    !!!   Bonus Goals   !!!

    1. $9,485: 15 Camera Sets
    2. $12,380:  20 Camera Sets
    3. $15,000: Hire a FFI Croc Expert Team to do a survey in the park on the  Siamese crocodile population.
    4. $20.000: Reuse all cameras on a bonus expedition into WWF's - "HeartOfBorneo" at Kayan Mentarang National Park, Indonesia.

     -----------------------------------------------------------------------


    German / Deutsch

     

    Wie einige von euch vielleicht wissen, bin ich ja nun schon eine Weile hier in Kambodscha mit "Ärzte ohne Grenzen" tätig und es gefällt mir wirklich sehr gut. Ein Highlight der letzten 6 Monate, natürlich neben meiner täglichen Arbeit ;), hat mich jedoch bislang nicht wieder losgelassen. Im April, in meiner ersten Urlaubswoche, habe ich mit meinen Kollegen eine 6 Tages Wanderung durch den Virachey Nationalpark gemacht. Es war einmalig.

    Ich habe mich nun entschlossen für den Park einzutreten und aktiv zu werden, denn bislang weckt die Region nur Interesse bei vietnamesischen Kautschukfirmen, die ohne zu fragen alles platt machen, um Plantagen anzulegen. Im Januar 2014 startet eine Expedition (2-3 Wochen) in die Kernzone des Virachey Nationalparks dicht an der laotischen Grenze, um min. 10 Wildkameras zu platzieren. Dies zusammen mit erfahrenen lokalen Rangern, einem Vogelexperten und trainierten Leuten, die wissen wie man mit einer Wildkamera richtig umgeht. Ziel der Aktion ist es, zu beweisen, dass der Park vom Aussterben bedrohte Tierarten beheimatet und somit einen deutlich strengeren Schutzstatus verdient.

    Momentan gibt es seitens der kambodschanischen Regierung ein etwas erfolgloses Stillhalteabkommen bezgl. aller vergebenen Landkonzessionen. Zudem gibt es leider keine einzige Naturschutzorganisation die sich um den Park kümmert. Auch die Weltbank hat im Jahr 2008 ihr Engagement beendet. Mittlerweile wurden bereits große Abschnitte entlang der vietnamesischen Grenze in Kautschukplantagen umgewandelt, riesige Waldflächen gerodet und Wilderer dringen immer weiter in den Park vor ohne jegliche Strafverfolgung und das trotz vorhandener Gesetzgebung. 90% des Parkes wurden zudem für den Bergbau freigegeben. Zum Glück konnten bislang keine lukrativen Vorkommen gefunden werden.

    Das in der Randzone des Parkes lebende Naturvolk berichtet der Park beheimatet weiterhin Populationen von seltenen Arten wie Tiger, asiatischem Elefant und evtl. sogar letzte Exemplare des asiatischen Nashorns. Mindestens 15 vom Aussterben bedrohte Säugetier-Arten, neben weiteren 125 Säugetieren, nennen den Park ihr zu Hause.

    Das Moratorium der Regierung ist jedoch die letzte Chance den Park in seiner Ursprünglichkeit zu erhalten, einer Region in der bislang nicht einmal Wissenschaftler vorgedrungen sind. Wenn es uns gelingt Schnappschüsse von stark gefährdeten oder vom Aussterben bedrohten Tierarten zu machen, beweist dies eine außergewöhnliche Biodiversität, die es lohnt zu bewahren. Naturschutzorganisationen und Regierung werden darauf aufmerksam und werden sich gezwungen sehen, erneut für den Park einzutreten.

    Bislang hindert uns nur die Finanzierung an diesem so sinnvollen Vorhaben. Zu diesem Zwecke habe ich nun diesen Spendenaufruf hier erstellt. Ich hoffe ein paar unter euch folgen ihm.

    Wer eine Internettransaktion scheut, dem biete ich auch die Möglichkeit der Überweisung an. Der Betrag wird nach ein paar Tagen hier auf der Seite, wenn erwünscht anonym, sichtbar. 

    Es gibt auch kleine Gegenleistungen. Siehe oben rechts auf dieser Seite. Updates und news der Aktion bei Twitter.

    Youtube mit ein paar zusätzlichen Videos.

     

     

                  "Awkun Charraan" - "Vielen Dank" an alle Unterstützer.
story_txt:
I'm Andreas Neunert and welcome to my campaign. With your support we can truly Save the Virachey National Park in Cambodia.
Für Deutsch bitte nach unten scrollen !
The Plan
... to place at least 10 motion-triggered cameras deep inside Virachey National Park, Cambodia in January 2014 to proof existence of endangered species and justify limiting concessions to land already granted. A team of local rangers picks them up 2 months later, before the onset of the rainy season. The expedition will take around 2-3 weeks.
Have a closer look at this previous GPS recorded trek to Veal Thom grassland inside the park. We will go another 10-20 km north than what you can see on the map close the Lao border and place the cameras on the holy Haling Halang mountain.
 Small gifts for small donations ;). Look to the right    -->
 Twitter: 


 
The Dilemma
Virachey National Park is located in the extreme Northeast of Cambodia in an area also known as "The Dragon's Tail" of the Kingdom. At 3,325 sq. km is Cambodia's largest national park and it is bordered by protected areas in Laos to the north and Vietnam to the east -Nam Kong PPA and Chu Mom Ray, respectively. According to the highlander people who live in the park's buffer zone along at the Sesan River, tigers, elephants and possibly even rhinoceros make their homes in Virachey, however their existence is not verified and no conservation group or NGO is currently protecting them.
In 2008, the World Bank abandoned their conservation and ecotourism programs at Virachey. read more Sections along the Vietnamese border have been sold off to rubber developers, and illegal loggers and poachers penetrate the park with exemption from punishment. Upwards of 90% of Virachey has been made available for mining exploration, however according to unofficial reports, there are simply not enough valuable mineral deposits to justify extraction by the company that holds the exploration license.

 
The Opportunity
An ineffective moratorium on logging is currently in place in Virachey and elsewhere in the region, yet illegal logging and land sales continue unabated. Nevertheless it offers a last hope for discovery and conservation in a place where scientific work has never been done. There are 140 mammal species likely to live in the park, at least 15 among them are rated endangered, critically endangered or probably exstinct according to the IUCN Red List. If we can capture images of this wildlife, it will provide positive proof that the park retains biodiversity that should be preserved, and justify limiting concessions to land already granted. If the cameras can capture the image of tiger, or snap a photo of a rhino, we can change the destiny of the endangered species that may still call Virachey home.
Small proof excists that the biodiversity of the park is extraordinary. But this is by far not enough.
                           
Cat Footprints
                                                 
Clouded Leopard dung
                                                         
Elephant dung
 
Siamese Crocodile "critically endangered"                      
This Siamese crocodile captured near Jark Village on the O Lai Lai River in the park's buffer zone. The Siamese croc has been written off by NGOs as extinct in Virachey. This picture proves the opposite.
 

They know the way so my mom doesn't get scared ;) 
 
The Park
Virachey National Park is one of the largest protected areas in Cambodia, covering 3,325 square kilometers of tropical forests and grasslands streching east to Vietnam, north to Laos and west to Stung Treng Province. It is bordered by an equally-large wilderness to the north on the Laos side called Nam Kohng Provincial Protected Area (NKPPA), a 55,000 hectare jungle in Ratanakiri called the Vuen Sai-Siem Pang Protected Forest. To the east, it connects to Chu Mom Ray National Park in Vietnam. And Virachey is the vital link wedged in between.
 See map. 
 
The Reason for Motion Triggered Cameras 
Studies showed that this is the most effective method.

..." smaller population numbers "... " while this could be due to higher hunting of jaguars and their prey species, it could also be due to more rigorous research methods, including more camera traps used in the current study. "



" While the cameras captured 57 big cats in the Sunderbans Tiger Reserve (STR) region, a similar study in areas outside the tiger reserve last year had spotted 20 animals. "


Attending a training in Thailand at the end of this year with a conservation NGO on "How to put up motion triggered cameras" will increase the chance of getting valuable photoshots.
 
The Park in the News

Mongabay.com - " Exploring Asia's lost world " 

Mongabay.com - " Into the unknown mountains of Cambodia: rare birds, rice wine, and talk of tigers " 

 
The Initiator
My name is Andreas Neunert. At the moment I work with "Doctors Without Borders" in Kampong Cham, Cambodia in a Tuberculosis project. I went trekking to the Veal Thom Grassland in Virachey in April '13 and I was so fascinated that I decided to take action for this highly under pressure beautiful wilderness. Find me on Facebook and drop me a line.
 
The Finances
One highend camera + safetybox costs $549,-
... and I dont walk 2 weeks with a machete north carrying a crappy camera that does not work at the end ;) 

" The market leading trail camera has a remarkably fast shutter speed of just 0.2 seconds so that you will not miss fast moving animals."

" Want the best trail camera ever made?  Look no further. " 



" No glow infrared "                ...so we don't scare something
" Near-instant recovery time "  ...so we don't miss something
" 20-30k pics per battery set " ...so something can play with it for more than 2 month
" Durability is best in class "     ...so something does't scare the camera



 
plus an additional lock each around $15
plus a memory card each around $15
= $579 for each Camera Set
The more cameras the better but we are aiming to put up at least 10
10 x $579 = $5.790
Food and porters appr. $400,- per week = $800
$5.790 + $800 = $6590

 
Remember ...

You can contribute more than the value of a specific Award... you still get the one chosen.

 
 
 
"Awkun Charraan" - "Thank you very much" to our supporters.


!!!   Bonus Goals   !!!

$9,485: 15 Camera Sets
$12,380:  20 Camera
     Sets
$15,000: Hire a FFI Croc Expert Team to do a
     survey in the park on the  Siamese crocodile population.
$20.000: Reuse all cameras on a bonus expedition
     into WWF's - "HeartOfBorneo"
     at Kayan Mentarang National Park,
     Indonesia.



 -----------------------------------------------------------------------

German / Deutsch
 
Wie einige von euch vielleicht wissen, bin ich ja nun schon eine Weile hier in Kambodscha mit "Ärzte ohne Grenzen" tätig und es gefällt mir wirklich sehr gut. Ein Highlight der letzten 6 Monate, natürlich neben meiner täglichen Arbeit ;), hat mich jedoch bislang nicht wieder losgelassen. Im April, in meiner ersten Urlaubswoche, habe ich mit meinen Kollegen eine 6 Tages Wanderung durch den Virachey Nationalpark gemacht. Es war einmalig.
Ich habe mich nun entschlossen für den Park einzutreten und aktiv zu werden, denn bislang weckt die Region nur Interesse bei vietnamesischen Kautschukfirmen, die ohne zu fragen alles platt machen, um Plantagen anzulegen. Im Januar 2014 startet eine Expedition (2-3 Wochen) in die Kernzone des Virachey Nationalparks dicht an der laotischen Grenze, um min. 10 Wildkameras zu platzieren. Dies zusammen mit erfahrenen lokalen Rangern, einem Vogelexperten und trainierten Leuten, die wissen wie man mit einer Wildkamera richtig umgeht. Ziel der Aktion ist es, zu beweisen, dass der Park vom Aussterben bedrohte Tierarten beheimatet und somit einen deutlich strengeren Schutzstatus verdient.
Momentan gibt es seitens der kambodschanischen Regierung ein etwas erfolgloses Stillhalteabkommen bezgl. aller vergebenen Landkonzessionen. Zudem gibt es leider keine einzige Naturschutzorganisation die sich um den Park kümmert. Auch die Weltbank hat im Jahr 2008 ihr Engagement beendet. Mittlerweile wurden bereits große Abschnitte entlang der vietnamesischen Grenze in Kautschukplantagen umgewandelt, riesige Waldflächen gerodet und Wilderer dringen immer weiter in den Park vor ohne jegliche Strafverfolgung und das trotz vorhandener Gesetzgebung. 90% des Parkes wurden zudem für den Bergbau freigegeben. Zum Glück konnten bislang keine lukrativen Vorkommen gefunden werden.
Das in der Randzone des Parkes lebende Naturvolk berichtet der Park beheimatet weiterhin Populationen von seltenen Arten wie Tiger, asiatischem Elefant und evtl. sogar letzte Exemplare des asiatischen Nashorns. Mindestens 15 vom Aussterben bedrohte Säugetier-Arten, neben weiteren 125 Säugetieren, nennen den Park ihr zu Hause.
Das Moratorium der Regierung ist jedoch die letzte Chance den Park in seiner Ursprünglichkeit zu erhalten, einer Region in der bislang nicht einmal Wissenschaftler vorgedrungen sind. Wenn es uns gelingt Schnappschüsse von stark gefährdeten oder vom Aussterben bedrohten Tierarten zu machen, beweist dies eine außergewöhnliche Biodiversität, die es lohnt zu bewahren. Naturschutzorganisationen und Regierung werden darauf aufmerksam und werden sich gezwungen sehen, erneut für den Park einzutreten.
Bislang hindert uns nur die Finanzierung an diesem so sinnvollen Vorhaben. Zu diesem Zwecke habe ich nun diesen Spendenaufruf hier erstellt. Ich hoffe ein paar unter euch folgen ihm.
Wer eine Internettransaktion scheut, dem biete ich auch die Möglichkeit der Überweisung an. Der Betrag wird nach ein paar Tagen hier auf der Seite, wenn erwünscht anonym, sichtbar. 
Es gibt auch kleine Gegenleistungen. Siehe oben rechts auf dieser Seite. Updates und news der Aktion bei Twitter.
Youtube mit ein paar zusätzlichen Videos.
 
 
              "Awkun Charraan" - "Vielen Dank" an alle Unterstützer.

story:
Summary

Help save sea turtles and contribute to the conservation of marine biodiversity

 

Problem

Sea turtles have been around for over 150 million years. Despite their terrestrial origin they evolved and became adapted to the ocean, unlike other reptiles. There are 5 species of sea turtles occurring in Portuguese waters, all listed on the IUCN Red List of Endangered Species as “endangered” or “critically endangered”. The survival rate of sea turtles is decreasing, largely due to anthropogenic actions that destroy their nesting habitats, and also due to poor coastal management plans, pollution, and accidental capture by fisheries.

In order to avoid the extinction of these species, more research on their behavior and habitats is needed, so that we can promote their survival. Some sea turtles travel 10 thousand miles each year crossing the territorial waters of different countries. Therefore, considering these wide ranging species, biodiversity conservation must be seen as a priority that concerns us all, not just one country or region.

 

Who are we?

CRAM-Q (Rehabilitation Center of Marine Animals of Quiaios),  is managed by SPVS (Portuguese Wildlife Society), a nonprofit Non-Governmental Organization which main objective is to boost and encourage research on Wildlife. Our mission at CRAM-Q focuses on the rescue, rehabilitation and return of marine animals back to nature (birds, mammals and reptiles) while increasing the scientific knowledge about these animals and their habitats. We are a team of technicians and researchers, rescuing animals from more than 500 km of the Portuguese coast with an average of five hundred interventions each year. Although cetaceans and seabirds are also admitted to CRAM-Q, with respect to turtles we have already rehabilitated common-turtles (Caretta caretta), green turtles (Chelonia mydas) and leatherback turtles (Dermochelys coriacea).

 

Our objective

Presently our main objective is to acquire the necessary transmitters to monitor sea turtles after their release back to the ocean. Tracking rehabilitated turtles is very important. Monitoring turtles after their release is the best way to ultimately evaluate the success of the rehabilitation process. By using post-release monitoring we are able to know where the turtle is travelling to, what type of dives are made, etc. Most importantly, it is the only way to find out what regions of the ocean (migration corridors, feeding areas, etc.) are actually important for their overall conservation. Until 2009 marine turtles were thought to have a “marginal occurrence” in Portuguese waters. Since then our research team was already able to demonstrate that sea turtles are much more frequent in our waters. In fact, in 2011 alone we collected 150 stranded turtles and 60 turtles were observed during a 4-day aerial census.At this point and because we have been struggling financially, we cannot meet the budget needed to purchase the necessary sea turtle transmitters. Presently, all available funding supports operational costs only, such as medication and food, specific analysis and veterinary care, staff salaries, maintenance of facilities (water, electricity, repairs), fuel for animal rescuing and releases.
The rehabilitation process of each sea turtle is often very long, expensive, involving many people. Without transmitters, not only do we lose the real outcome of the turtle rehabilitation process (did the turtle survive or not after release?), we also lose extremely valuable information on their needs and threats across the ocean. These devices are vital to the continued study of these animals, largely contributing to the conservation of sea turtle species.
 
 

Placing transmitters

The attachment process is also harmless to the sea turtle.
 
 
 

Monitoring of 4 turtles (Caretta caretta)

 
 
 
 

Therefore, by assisting in the purchase of these transmitters you are contributing to the conservation of sea turtles and to the promotion of the conservation of biodiversity.

 

Budget 

 

Be a Rehabilitator for 3 days or 10 week (Perks)

Attend and participate in activities such as: preparing food for various animals existing in the center; observation of eating behaviors; assist technicians in the whole process of animal treatment, measurement of physical parameters of the various aquatic systems & chemical analyses of water quality.

  • Check in at 8:00 A.M.
  • Presentation of the CramQ's team 
  • Brief explanation of the service provided by Cram-Q
  • Guided tour of the center (the facilities and means available)
  • Presentation of all animals recovering in the Center
  • Preparing food for various animals existing in the center
  • Lunch Break 
  • Talk about the organization (structure, resources, funding, results, animals returned to nature, and more complicated cases to rehabilitate
  • Assist Technicians in the process of treatment of animals
  • Participation in the release of any animal, if days match 
  • Snack 

Gifts: Certificate, Photography with Cram-Q team and an animal, T Shirt

 

Perks

At the end of the campaign, we will send all the perks to donors.

 

Links:

http://socpvs.org/cramq.php

http://www.facebook.com/CramQ

 

        

 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you can´t help with a donation, please share this campaign via facebook or mail.

 

We, and especially the animals, will be eternally grateful for your contribution. These are contributions that make the difference and allow us to continue and improve our work.

 

Thanks to Walt Disney Music Company & Walt Disney Records for allowing the use of music during the period of the campaign

 

[UPDATE]

Watch the report made by the Portuguese news agency Lusa about Julieta and our IndieGoGo Campaign.

http://rd3.videos.sapo.pt/M0olVW6KHCt5JeZaInlj/mov/1
 

[UPDATE]

On the 8th of April, this little 2,65Kg loggerhead turtle was accidentally captured in trammel nets, 3 nautical miles off Nazaré (center of Portugal). Mr. Henrique Maranhão, the captain of the fishing boat “Marco Aurélio” and his crew, promptly rescued this little guy from the nets and phoned the Maritime Authorities of Nazaré. CramQ was contacted and went to the fishing harbour to collect and assist the seaturtle. X-rays detected some water in the lungs and at the moment, the turtle is in rehab at CramQ, being preventively treated for pneumonia. The CramQ staff would like to thank the “Marco Aurélio” crew and the Polícia Marítima of Nazaré for their very important contribution to the conservation of marine turtles.

At the Maritime Authorities facilities in the Nazaré fishing harbour.

Already in the box ready to travel to CramQ

Mr Henrique Maranhão, the captain of the“Marco Aurélio” fishing boat that rescued the turtle from the trammel nets and called the maritime authorities to rescue the animal.

The seaturtle having an X-ray performed by Dr. Sara Dias at FozCanis (Veterinary Hospital)

story:
The main goal of the campaign “A documentary for Mayflower” is to create a documentary film about the Mayflower Bocawina National Park in Belize.

    My name is Duarte Dellarole and I’m currently taking a degree in Ecotourism (BSc.) at Escola Superior Agrária de Coimbra (Coimbra, Portugal). As part of my curricular Internship I’ve proposed to make a documentary film about the Mayflower Bocawina National Park in Belize, where I will be staying for 3 months.

This Internship will be made with the support of both the Mama Noots Eco Resort (located inside the Park) and the Friends of Mayflower Bocawina NGO and community based organization that co-manages the Park.

    Filming nature has always been one of my passions and this will be a great opportunity to dedicate this passion to a more serious project.    

    In addition to the documentary I’ve also proposed to make a free website for the Park since they are a low-budget organization.

    To see the aspects that will be featured on the documentary please download the Documentary plan: http://sdrv.ms/TViUY3

   The filming will occur from May to July 2013 in Belize.

 

 

 

   The Mayflower Bocawina National Park is located in the Stann Creek District at the base of the Maya Mountains, with over 7000 acres of pristine lowland broadleaf forest, waterfalls and evidence of an ancient Mayan City.

While its original attraction was the Mayflower Archaeological Site, it was established as a national park in 2001, which emphasizes community co-management and environmental protection.

Archaeologists predict once the excavation is complete the Mayflower site
will rank as one of the largest in Belize. The trail system offers excellent
hiking and it’s an adventurous climb to Antelope Falls.  

    The National Park designation supports the protection of the watersheds, and allows for low-impact non-extractive
activities such as education, tourism and research activities.

    Mayfolwer Bocawina is co-managed by the Friends of Mayflower Bocawina with the Forest Department and the Institute of Archaeology. Mayflower has a membership of 128 members from stakeholders communities. There are two wardens who work at the park on a daily basis to maintain the trails and immediate surroundings. All other work done at the park is voluntary. Their umbrella organization is the Association of Protected Areas Management Organization (APAMO) and The Protected Area Conservation Trust (PACT) who assist the park in small, medium and large grants. Funding for the park comes only from the parks entrance fees and grant proposal.

Some of the most charismatic and endangered wildlife of Belize can be found on the Park, such as:

    Friends of Mayflower Bocawina is a community based organization (CBO/NGO) established in 2001 that manages the Mayflower Bocawina National Park. The NGO is managed by local stakeholders from the community of Silk Grass, Hopkins Sittee, Dangriga and Valley Communities all located in the Stann creek District. The day to day management is done by a seven member executive from the community of Silk Grass.

    Mama Noots Eco Resort is a beautiful paradise of 48 acres nestled within the Mayflower Bocawina National Park. The property boasts beautiful flora and fauna to attract its visitors, and once deep into hiking its many trails, it reveals to you all of the wonders of nature, including its inhabitants of howler monkeys, more than 200 species of birds, and if you're lucky, an occasional sighting of a Jaguar lazing in a tree. 

    The idea is to have a place where people from every walk of life can come and commune with nature, where couples and families can find that quality time together while learning how to preserve our Mother Earth. 

    The philosophy is to keep this tropical paradise as pure and untouched as possible while providing the guests with comfort and service, not to be surpassed by larger and more established resorts. The energy is generated from a small hydro-electric generation scheme and a solar and wind generation plant.

 

   To make these ideas possible I will have some expenses and that’s why I need your help.

   This will include the flight to Belize; extension fee to be able to stay 3 months in Belize; filming equipment; taxes for bringing filming equipment.

    I will also need someone to narrate the documentary in English which may require some payment unless I find someone who’s willing to do it for free.

    If there's any extra money raised during the campaign it will go directly to the Friends of Mayflower Bocawina (CBO/NGO) to be applied in the management of the Park.

   Our givebacks:

- Night-stays at the Mama Noots Eco-Resort

- Free entrance at Mayflower Bocawina National Park

- Special crowdfunders version of the documentary

- Joshua Berman's "Belize" Handbook

- Internship report (digital)

- Photo print

 

Learn how you can make a contribution through Indiegogo

 

   With this campaign and with the documentary I hope to catch the attention of ecotourists, students and scientists to the importance of this natural jewel.

    I hope to be able to promote the work of these local communities who have decided to protect their land against the massive tourism industry, deforestation and hunting of endangered wildlife, who have also made a promise to protect their cultural heritage.  

    There will also be an instant impact on my joy for being able to fulfill this dream which I would like to thank in advance to all the funders. I’ll be giving a part of my knowledge to this project but I’m sure I will learn a lot more while working with the local communities. 

 

    If you cannot donate to this cause you can always share it with your friends and family and hopefully someone will be interested and donate to this cause or even visit this protected area in Belize.

    I will also be accepting equipment and sponsors, for example filming equipment, camouflage tents and trail cameras.

    If you know someone with good narration skills in please feel free to contact me (duartedellarole@hotmail.com).

Mayflower Bocawina National Park: www.mayflowerbocawina.tk
Mama Noots Eco Resort: www.mamanootsbelize.com
Forest Department: www.forestdepartment.gov.bz
Association of Protected Areas Management Organization: www.apamo.net
The Protected Area Conservation Trust: www.pactbelize.org
Institute of Archaeology: www.nichbelize.org

Escola Superior Agrária de Coimbra: www.esac.pt
BSc. in Ecotourism: http://webmanager.esac.pt/mgallery/default.asp?obj=1597

While its original attraction was the Mayflower Archaeological Site, it was established as a national park in 2001, which emphasizes community co-management and environmental protection.
Archaeologists predict once the excavation is complete the Mayflower sitewill rank as one of the largest in Belize. The trail system offers excellenthiking and it’s an adventurous climb to Antelope Falls.  
    The National Park designation supports the protection of the watersheds, and allows for low-impact non-extractiveactivities such as education, tourism and research activities.
    Mayfolwer Bocawina is co-managed by the Friends of Mayflower Bocawina with the Forest Department and the Institute of Archaeology. Mayflower has a membership of 128 members from stakeholders communities. There are two wardens who work at the park on a daily basis to maintain the trails and immediate surroundings. All other work done at the park is voluntary. Their umbrella organization is the Association of Protected Areas Management Organization (APAMO) and The Protected Area Conservation Trust (PACT) who assist the park in small, medium and large grants. Funding for the park comes only from the parks entrance fees and grant proposal.

Some of the most charismatic and endangered wildlife of Belize can be found on the Park, such as:


    Friends of Mayflower Bocawina is a community based organization (CBO/NGO) established in 2001 that manages the Mayflower Bocawina National Park. The NGO is managed by local stakeholders from the community of Silk Grass, Hopkins Sittee, Dangriga and Valley Communities all located in the Stann creek District. The day to day management is done by a seven member executive from the community of Silk Grass.

    Mama Noots Eco Resort is a beautiful paradise of 48 acres nestled within the Mayflower Bocawina National Park. The property boasts beautiful flora and fauna to attract its visitors, and once deep into hiking its many trails, it reveals to you all of the wonders of nature, including its inhabitants of howler monkeys, more than 200 species of birds, and if you're lucky, an occasional sighting of a Jaguar lazing in a tree. 

    The idea is to have a place where people from every walk of life can come and commune with nature, where couples and families can find that quality time together while learning how to preserve our Mother Earth. 
    The philosophy is to keep this tropical paradise as pure and untouched as possible while providing the guests with comfort and service, not to be surpassed by larger and more established resorts. The energy is generated from a small hydro-electric generation scheme and a solar and wind generation plant.
 

   To make these ideas possible I will have some expenses and that’s why I need your help.
   This will include the flight to Belize; extension fee to be able to stay 3 months in Belize; filming equipment; taxes for bringing filming equipment.
    I will also need someone to narrate the documentary in English which may require some payment unless I find someone who’s willing to do it for free.
    If there's any extra money raised during the campaign it will go directly to the Friends of Mayflower Bocawina (CBO/NGO) to be applied in the management of the Park.
   Our givebacks:

- Night-stays at the Mama Noots Eco-Resort
- Free entrance at Mayflower Bocawina National Park
- Special crowdfunders version of the documentary
- Joshua Berman's "Belize" Handbook
- Internship report (digital)
- Photo print
 
Learn how you can make a contribution through Indiegogo

 

   With this campaign and with the documentary I hope to catch the attention of ecotourists, students and scientists to the importance of this natural jewel.
    I hope to be able to promote the work of these local communities who have decided to protect their land against the massive tourism industry, deforestation and hunting of endangered wildlife, who have also made a promise to protect their cultural heritage.  
    There will also be an instant impact on my joy for being able to fulfill this dream which I would like to thank in advance to all the funders. I’ll be giving a part of my knowledge to this project but I’m sure I will learn a lot more while working with the local communities. 
 
    If you cannot donate to this cause you can always share it with your friends and family and hopefully someone will be interested and donate to this cause or even visit this protected area in Belize.
    I will also be accepting equipment and sponsors, for example filming equipment, camouflage tents and trail cameras.
    If you know someone with good narration skills in please feel free to contact me (duartedellarole@hotmail.com).

Mayflower Bocawina National Park: www.mayflowerbocawina.tkMama Noots Eco Resort: www.mamanootsbelize.com Forest Department: www.forestdepartment.gov.bz Association of Protected Areas Management Organization: www.apamo.net The Protected Area Conservation Trust: www.pactbelize.org Institute of Archaeology: www.nichbelize.orgEscola Superior Agrária de Coimbra: www.esac.pt BSc. in Ecotourism: http://webmanager.esac.pt/mgallery/default.asp?obj=1597

story:
My name is Elizabeth Wiley and I am a College of Charleston Marine Biology student
currently interning for Wounded Nature-Working Veterans www.woundednature.org.
Our relatively new non-profit organization could really use your support as we work
to convalesce the East Coast marine environment, which acts, undoubtedly, as a great
resource in many of our daily lives.

Here is the short story of Wounded Nature’s organization and its purpose:
As a result of 5 years of economic depression, funding for waterway and beach clean-
ups has been either drastically cut or totally eliminated in the federal, state, and local
budgets. As a result, the only beaches being cleaned are the main public areas where
voters have easy access. These beaches happen to be areas that wildlife avoids because
of the number of humans occupying this area. The areas that wildlife has migrated to,
used for breeding and raising their young, failed to be acknowledged by the government.
This results in an accumulation of trash that wildlife eats, becomes entangled in, and is an aesthetic eyesore to what should be a pristine and natural area.

The campaign is very important to me, because I grew up with the simple, yet
unfortunately common mentality that we can always be dependent upon our oceans for
water and food supply. However, as I continue to learn more about our marine life,
I have quickly learned how easily we could lose those seemingly endless resources.
If we can find the right ways in which to preserve the environment through simple
recycling methods and alert others of their environmental impact, we could really make a difference.

With the help of contributions, our organization will form a photographic journal
of litter and trash wash-up on beaches in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, and North
Carolina. This type of journal would enable others to see what is affecting our marinelife and would inspire many to change their routines to lend a hand in the restoration process, instead of continuing to pollute it.  This grant will be used to scout beaches prior to beaches being scheduled for clean up.  The money will be used to cover equipment, travel, survey, and marketing costs.

In order to produce such a journal, we will
need $15,000. To get people excited and motivated to help our environment,
items like this journal need to be constructed or people will always lack understanding
of the harm they impose on our marine life. If we do not reach this goal, we will use our funds to cover as much of this area as the raised funding will allow.

We will be launching five 50-55ft Victory Vessels each with a primary sponsor.
Currently we have a sponsor for one of the boats and are seeking other sponsors for the
remaining four. Annual sponsorship costs is 1.4 million. Promotion of our organization
and its goals is vital. As our name and purpose becomes more well-known, we will
obtain more donors and sponsors allowing us to increase our positive environmental
impact.

Any donations and assistance you can give by either spreading the word about Wounded
Nature-Working Veterans or just simply visiting our website www.woundednature.org
would be greatly appreciated.

story:
Short Summary

We are Solarize Carrboro, a local initiative whose mission is to bring affordable solar power to the people of North Carolina. We believe this is the best way to bring lower energy costs, self-reliance, and energy independence in a way that protects our environment and lifestyle for future generations.

UNC Chapel Hill student interns Drew Chandler and Michael Balot joined the Solarize Carrboro initiative in the spring of 2014 and have worked closely with McDougle Middle School students and teachers to get this project off the ground.

This project will only make a small dent in the total energy footprint of McDougle Middle School and the Carrboro Public Library, but it will do immeasurable good in educating our youth about renewable energy and community activism.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $8,000 to build this array and install the web-based solar monitoring software that will really transform the project into an educational tool. Check out our unique perks on the right, and please donate what you can!

The Impact

By contributing to this project, you will be supporting McDougle students and Carrboro residents who want to learn more about how solar photovoltaic power works.

  • The solar array will have real-time web-monitoring software so anyone can see how much energy the panels are producing at any given time from any location with an internet connection!
  • We have already had over 200 people sign up for the free home solar assessment in Carrboro, so we know that people are interested in going solar!
  • Teaching this generation about how solar energy works will foster future leaders who care about the country's energy policy

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily, we would still love to have your help! If you live in Carrboro, sign up for a free solar assesment or simply join our mailing list at: http://www.solarizenc.org/

  • You can also share our campaign via social media or by word of mouth!
  • Feel free to contact us if you have any questions or concerns or if you want to volunteer with Solarize Carrboro
