story:
About the cookbook

The Disco Soup cookbook is an activist tool dedicated to global eaters who want to be actively part of the fight against climate change and food waste.  

Through insights on the worldwide food waste situation, about 100 recipes by activists of World Disco Soup Day and inspiring stories of special products, farmers and fishermen, the reader is invited to rediscover the value of food, its cultural heritage. Food is not a commodity and it cannot be wasted.

What is World Disco Soup Day? 

On World Disco Soup Day, organizers, attendees, and chefs will collect, chop, and cook leftover food or any food that would otherwise go to waste, such as ‘ugly’ fruits and vegetables (the products which do not conform to commercial aesthetic standards). During the preparations, and for a long while after, music will be pumping and everyone will be dancing! It is a fun, gastronomic and musical event that brings together young people, students, children, seniors, cooks, and all the supporters of this battle against food waste. It is also a transformation tool that brings together diverse knowledge for education and awareness.

Why this book?

This book is an ode to the worldwide gastronomic heritage, in particular to those traditional recipes which use the leftovers of the previous meal and transform it into something delicious. To be able to gather these recipes, most of the volunteers reached out to their grandparents and to elderly people in their communities, whose generation didn’t conceive waste and in particular food waste. 

We have thought of this book as an inspirational tool to reduce food waste and fight climate change in a simple and fun way, while gathering the inputs of a global community of change makers. 

Your contribution

With your help, we will bundle the amazing recipes we have received from our network into a book, supplemented with illustrations, interviews and essays. You will be able to pre-order your Disco Soup cookbook copy. Straight after World Disco Soup Day 2021, we will send you your hard copy of the book. 

Who made the book?

This book is made in cooperation with the Slow Food Youth Network, the World Disco Soup Day Task Force and a great number of volunteers from the past editions of World Disco Soup Day. After last year's World Disco Soup Day, we gathered food rescuing recipes from all over the world, which we now brought together in this book!

Text and editing: David McKenzie
Supported by: Patricia Christie Djojo & Gabriela Bonilha
Design: Pop-eye Studio 
Project coordination: Slow Food Youth Network

story:
My Story
Hello, my name is Ronny Steen, and I am an animal behaviorist conducting environmental research at a Norwegian University. I specialize in video monitoring to study animal behavior, meaning I use digital cameras to remotely monitor wildlife. I am currently working with a Greek marine research institute called Archipelagos to observe the Eleonora’s falcons (Falco eleonorae), a beautiful falcon whose nesting habitat is in danger. 

Outside the breeding season, they live in Madagascar, although in the summer they travel to breed in the Mediterranean. About 80% of the world’s population of Eleonora’s falcons are located in Greece, they breed in colonies in Islets and coastal cliffs. 

My research team and I travel to these cliffs to place special motion-activated cameras at their nests. Our job is to record the daily activity of the Eleonora’s falcons to determine their parenting habits and diet, which in turn can help us predict the migratory patterns of other birds, and even charter environmental climate changes. 

One of the biggest treats is invasive rats staying at the Islets, they aggressively devour the falcon eggs before they could hatch. Further, their breeding grounds being threatened by modern expansion. I hope that my video research will convince wildlife authorities to impose new regulations to protect the falcons. 

What I Need 
I am requesting $2500 to continue my research. This money will be used for traveling expenses, camera equipment, and to further raise awareness. With your help, I will be able to travel to an uninhabited islet situated in the eastern part of the Aegean Sea in Greece to continue my filming of the falcons. The method is non-invasive and requires no handling of the birds. 

The Impact
The Eleonora’s falcon is on the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s “Red List”. With over 80% of their population converging in the Mediterranean. The world population of Eleonora’s falcon is located on a small number of colonies, making each colony important for the global population. 

Other Ways to Help
It's great when people can help donate. But if you can't donate at this time, it doesn't mean that you can't help. Please share my story via social media, email and word of mouth to tell your friends about my campaign. Thank you in advance!

story:
The Nature Connection Pyramid is all about a new approach to nature and the environment. It demonstrates that by making some very small adjustments to the way we do things on a daily, weekly, monthly and annual basis you can transform your screen time into "green time" and experience improved mental and physical health, fun, and of course a brighter future for our entire planet. This campaign is your opportunity to pre-order a copy of The Nature Connection Pyramid.

Download the Nature Connection Pyramid Iconographic for FREE

New Stretch Goals!

$5,000- C&NN 10% Donation

$5,000 - Once we have hit and passed our goal of $5,000, NKI will make a donation of 10% of our total campaign earnings to the Children and Nature Network! We want to share our success and give back to the children and nature movement. What better way than to support our favorite non-profit, The Children and Nature Network? We look forward to supporting C&NN's international mission to reconnect children with nature! 

$10,000 - "Estamos Aqui" Sneak Peek

$10,000 - Unlocks the first sneak preview of “Estamos Aqui”. Last year NKI partnered with Latino Outdoors to create a new feature length film that told the story of the Latino heritage of conservation and nature connection. This film will premiere in the Spring. Help us hit our $10,000 stretch goal and we will release the first sneak peek at our exciting new film! 

$15,000 - FREE Estamos Aqui DVD's for ALL!

$15,000 - The moment we hit $15,000 every backer of this campaign, regardless of contribution size will be given a free copy of Estamos Aqui on DVD! As soon as the final cut is ready, we will send a copy to everyone who donated to this campaign! Please help us hit this important milestone. Thank you!

The Australian Challenge -

Throughout our collaboration Tania has often insisted that Australia has important stories to tell when it comes to connecting children with nature. We have agreed on many occasions that someday we would get together and make an Australian film… well, “someday” has come! We have made a stretch goal to test the waters and to see how badly the people of Australia want to see this happen. There are 4 special perks with the title “Australian Challenge”. If we sell out of all 4 perks, we will officially start production on the new film when I visit Melbourne in October! If you want to see an Australian film made, help us sell out the Australian Challenge perks!

$19 - Australian Challenge Perk # 1 (20 Available)

Pre-Order "The Nature Connection Pyramid" by Kenny Ballentine and Tania Moloney!


$39 - Australian Challenge Perk #2 (10 Available)

Pre-Order "The Nature Connection Pyramid" by Kenny Ballentine and Tania Moloney AND get the documentary film "Nature Kids" on DVD!


$50 - Australian Challenge Perk #3 (5 Available)

Pre-Order "The Nature Connection Pyramid" by Kenny Ballentine and Tania Moloney, AND get the 11 x 17 Nature Connection Pyramid Poster, AND "Nature Kids" on DVD!


$1500 - Australian Challenge Perk #4 (1 Available)

Kenny Ballentine will be touring Australia this October or in 2016. Claim this perk and he will present a film screening, keynote speech, or workshop for your group or organization!  This opportunity typically costs $3900 plus travel fees. Get a LIVE NKI event at 50% off and without any travel fees! Help us fulfill The Australian Challenge!


Meet The Authors

Kenny Ballentine

Kenny Ballentine is a family-man, award winning filmmaker, author, public speaker and nature guide. He is the creator of the feature-length documentary film "Nature Kids", the author of "The Nature Connection Pyramid" and the founder of The Nature Kids Institute.  Kenny’s mission in life is to bring the wonders of the natural world into the lives of children everywhere.  He envisions a future where our everyday lives will be as immersed in nature as they are in technology and where children are outside, healthy, and deeply connected to the planet they will inherit.  The primary focus of Kenny’s films, workshops, speeches and outings is to turn that vision into a reality. Kenny currently lives in beautiful Northern California with his wife and three children.

Tania Moloney

Tania is passionate about helping families connect with nature and with each other. Her childhood was filled with opportunities for outdoor adventures and she made (and ate) LOTS of mud pies. She has a head and heart full of cherished childhood memories of family camping trips, building "cubbies", sleeping under the stars and playing with sticks. Now with her own young family, Tania desperately wants those memories and experiences for her children too. As a result she has happily embraced that her kids will have perpetually dirty feet and her pockets/car/washing machine/handbag will be permanently filled with nature’s treasures. Tania will share with you how she and her family make the choice for nature (more often than not anyway) despite their busy life, and you’ll take away lots of ideas, practical tools and resources to help you and the families you support choose nature more often too.

Lear More About "Estamos Aqui"

Estamos Aqui! We are here! The Latino population is the fastest growing American demographic. They are also among the most under-represented groups in conservation, outdoor recreation, and environmental education organizations. What are the causes and consequences of this divide? What are the challenges and opportunities? In this feature-length documentary film we will uncover and celebrate the little-known but beautiful and vibrant Latino heritage for conservation and outdoor recreation. Latino families and individuals from all over the United States are already connecting with their history, their culture, their communities and the planet through powerful, meaningful and culturally relevant interactions with nature. In Estamos Aqui we will meet these inspiring people, hear their stories and discover how our connection to nature simultaneously makes us unique and brings us together.

Estamos Aqui is co-directed and co-produced by Kenny Ballentine and Jose Gonzalez. Ballentine is the director of the award-winning documentary film, “Nature Kids” and is the founder of The Nature Kids Institute. Gonzalez is the founder of Latino Outdoors and is a member of the Latino Conservation Alliance.

Filming has taken place all over America, including a kayak trip down the LA River, a family hike in Central Park in New York City, lobbying Congress in Washington DC, and a rare “”day at the park” for families from California's’ agricultural Central Valley. In September 2015 the film will have wrapped production and will be moving into post production.  The first screening of the work in progress will be shown at the Americas Latino Eco Festival in Denver Colorado this October. It is anticipated that Estamos Aqui will begin public exhibitions in the Spring of 2016.


The Purpose of This Campaign

We plan to use the funds we raise through this campaign to pay for our first printing of "The Nature Connection Pyramid" to help us finish "Estamos Aqui" and to further expand the work of The Nature Kids Institute across the globe!

Our Awesome Perks

We have packed as much value into our perks as possible. From our new book to Live NKI events, you will find that every item has been dramatically discounted for this campaign. These are the lowest prices you will ever see for these items... period!
  • Books and Posters will ship in November
  • DVD's will ship immediately
  • The NKI Membership Program launches in November
  • Live events can be scheduled via direct contact with Kenny Ballentine

More Cool Stuff From The Nature Kids Institute

Pre-Order "The Nature Connection Pyramid" by Kenny Ballentine and Tania Moloney AND get the documentary film "Nature Kids" on DVD!
$50 - Australian Challenge Perk #3 (5 Available)
Pre-Order "The Nature Connection Pyramid" by Kenny Ballentine and Tania Moloney, AND get the 11 x 17 Nature Connection Pyramid Poster, AND "Nature Kids" on DVD!
$1500 - Australian Challenge Perk #4 (1 Available)Kenny Ballentine will be touring Australia this October or in 2016. Claim this perk and he will present a film screening, keynote speech, or workshop for your group or organization!  This opportunity typically costs $3900 plus travel fees. Get a LIVE NKI event at 50% off and without any travel fees! Help us fulfill The Australian Challenge!

Meet The Authors
 Kenny Ballentine


Kenny
  Ballentine is a family-man, award winning filmmaker, author, public  
speaker and nature guide. He is the creator of the feature-length 
documentary film "Nature Kids", the author of "The Nature Connection 
Pyramid" and the founder of The  Nature Kids Institute.  Kenny’s mission
 in life is to bring the wonders  of the natural world into the lives of
 children everywhere.  He  envisions a future where our everyday lives 
will be as immersed in  nature as they are in technology and where 
children are outside,  healthy, and deeply connected to the planet they 
will inherit.  The  primary focus of Kenny’s films, workshops, speeches 
and outings is to  turn that vision into a reality. Kenny currently 
lives in beautiful  Northern California with his wife and three 
children.

Tania Moloney

Tania is passionate  about helping families connect with nature and with each other. Her
  childhood was filled with opportunities for outdoor adventures and she
  made (and ate) LOTS of mud pies. She has a head and heart full of  
cherished childhood memories of family camping trips, building 
"cubbies",  sleeping under the stars and playing with sticks.
 Now  with her own young family, Tania desperately wants those memories 
and  experiences for her children too. As a result she has happily 
embraced  that her kids will have perpetually dirty feet and her  
pockets/car/washing machine/handbag will be permanently filled with  
nature’s treasures. Tania  
will share with you how she and her family make the choice for nature  
(more often than not anyway) despite their busy life, and you’ll take  
away lots of ideas, practical tools and resources to help you and the  
families you support choose nature more often too.

Lear More About "Estamos Aqui"


Estamos Aqui! We are here! The Latino population is the fastest growing American demographic. They are also among the most under-represented groups in conservation, outdoor recreation, and environmental education organizations. What are the causes and consequences of this divide? What are the challenges and opportunities? In this feature-length documentary film we will uncover and celebrate the little-known but beautiful and vibrant Latino heritage for conservation and outdoor recreation. Latino families and individuals from all over the United States are already connecting with their history, their culture, their communities and the planet through powerful, meaningful and culturally relevant interactions with nature. In Estamos Aqui we will meet these inspiring people, hear their stories and discover how our connection to nature simultaneously makes us unique and brings us together.
Estamos Aqui is co-directed and co-produced by Kenny Ballentine and Jose Gonzalez. Ballentine is the director of the award-winning documentary film, “Nature Kids” and is the founder of The Nature Kids Institute. Gonzalez is the founder of Latino Outdoors and is a member of the Latino Conservation Alliance. 
Filming has taken place all over America, including a kayak trip down the LA River, a family hike in Central Park in New York City, lobbying Congress in Washington DC, and a rare “”day at the park” for families from California's’ agricultural Central Valley. In September 2015 the film will have wrapped production and will be moving into post production.  The first screening of the work in progress will be shown at the Americas Latino Eco Festival in Denver Colorado this October. It is anticipated that Estamos Aqui will begin public exhibitions in the Spring of 2016.

The Purpose of This Campaign
We plan to use the funds we raise through this campaign to pay for our first printing of "The Nature Connection Pyramid" to help us finish "Estamos Aqui" and to further expand the work of The Nature Kids Institute across the globe!
  Our Awesome PerksWe have packed as much value into our perks as possible. From our new book to Live NKI events, you will find that every item has been dramatically discounted for this campaign. These are the lowest prices you will ever see for these items... period! 
Books and Posters will ship in November
DVD's will ship immediately
The NKI Membership Program launches in November
Live events can be scheduled via direct contact with Kenny Ballentine

More Cool Stuff From The Nature Kids Institute

story:
A lot can happen in 5 years
Or nothing much at all.
Sometimes in 50 years not much happens
If a crowd doesn’t make something happen.


Your voices will speak to the crowd on 2015 Earth Day
and the crowd will all make it happen by 2020 Earth Day.


EdayX –
the 1st crowd election day

EdayX is an online “election day” every Earth Day:

  • Vote on the top environmental solutions;
  • Choose your favorite celebrity environmentalists;
  • Select the coolest and smartest eco-friendly products;
  • Decide on the world’s greenest cities; and
  • “Elect” the most planet-friendly politicians.


EdayX Mission

If you put it on the front page, people pay attention. If you keep it there, progress happens.

EdayX will showcase the smartest “green” solutions, pushing the environment to the front page. By highlighting innovative ideas, EdayX will inspire donors and consumers to support some of the most cutting-edge projects, products, and leaders. EdayX will be orchestrated annually, building up to a global event on the 50th anniversary of Earth Day on April 22, 2020.


The Inspiration

It woke us up, that silent spring, that first Earth Day, when the green awakening began.

The first Earth Day in 1970 brought attention to the environmental challenges this planet faces. Twenty years later, on Earth Day 1990, environmental groups and progressive companies launched initiatives to support the “green economy.” But since then, environmental causes have moved to the inside pages.

Now, as we approach Earth Day 2020, we have the opportunity and the momentum to put the planet back on the front page. To do that, we need to start using Earth Day, a woefully underused marketing tool, to push environmental progress to the front page for the first time in decades.


How EdayX Works in Connection with the 2020 Earth Day Global Event

The 2020 Earth Day Global Event is a huge opportunity for the world’s cities and towns to capture and drive public participation in “green” solutions. This 50th anniversary of Earth Day will be a watershed event, the Super Bowl of events for 2020, and will put a spotlight on the green economy and recent environmental innovations.

EdayX will help maximize public participation in the green movement, leading up to 2020 Earth Day. Each year, EdayX will exponentially build momentum and interest up to the worldwide event, and then beyond.


The Value of EdayX to…

Green commerce companies and organizations:

  • Awareness and dramatic increase in sales of their green products, services, and memberships;
  • A higher profile; and
  • An opportunity to be a vanguard in a visible and growing national internet campaign.

Sponsors:

  • Added traffic to their products and websites; and
  • Increased sales of their products and services.
  • Environmental movement and progressive leaders:
  • A source of solutions to environmental issues; and
  • A way to turn out more environmental voters during the 2016 presidential elections.

Donors:

  • An opportunity to make a difference that has global value;
  • An opportunity to connect people nationally and globally in an environmental endeavor; and
  • An opportunity to help build the green economy and create jobs.

Media partners:

  • Added traffic to their outlets and websites; and
  • Enhanced goodwill.

The public:

  • A chance to contribute solutions to environmental issues; and
  • A chance to vote on solutions to environmental issues, and not just on candidates.

Giving good companies maximum profile allows them to prosper and grow. It is also a powerful way we can help the environment.

Projected Budget through EdayX 2015

(We will be seeking additional partners and sponsors to add to this budget and impact of the EdayX launch.)

  • Upgrade website, develop voting software: $10,000 
  • Design, print, and mail marketing materials: $7,500
  • Project management (300 hours @ $25/hour): $7,500
  • Social media/organizational outreach (300 hours @ $18/hour): $5,500
  • Partnership/sponsors outreach/development (300 hours @ $18/hour): $5,500
  • Cooperative Ads Network/Outreach (300 hours @ $18/hour): $5,500
  • Hire public relations firm: $7,500
  • Internet advertising & cooperative ad network placements: $15,000

Total: $64,000


About EdayX and BluCentral

EdayX and Earth Day 2020 are part of BluCentral, an “ecopreneurial” organization dedicated to developing and promoting the “green” economy and environmental solutions that work in the real world.

Thomas Harens, founder and director of BluCentral, has long been a champion of the green movement. As Special Events Director for Earth Day 1990 in Los Angeles, Harens created the 450,000-person event concept “Walk to the Water.” He then served as Events Director for Earth Day International 1991, where he worked on the first-ever Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. He served in the Minnesota House of Representatives and is a former electric vehicle propulsion technology developer.


Important Dates

Now-July 2014: Raise money, begin project development

July-December 2014: Begin outreach, update website

January 15, 2015: EdayX official launch – nominations begin!

March 15, 2015: Voting begins

April 22, 2015: Earth Day – last day of voting

story:
Our Story

IWP started as a twinkle in Kelly and Ricardo's eyes. During our Environmental Planning graduate program we focused on developing holistic water management strategies that balance human and ecological need and support thriving communities. Around the world, rapid urbanization, industrialization, and the development of environmentally sensitive areas like floodplains and stream and river corridors, are damaging the worlds watersheds. Traditional water management strategies are costly to maintain and destroy numerous ecosystem services provided by a naturally functioning watershed. These strategies often disproportionately  impact disadvantaged communities, particularly in the developing world, whose needs for safe drinking water, adequate sanitation, protection from natural disasters, and access to quality open space are not being met. However, new holistic approaches, things like rain gardens, floodplain parks, and wetland water treatment facilities,that are often simple and comparatively inexpensive to implement and maintain, are being utilized more and more, mostly in North America and Europe. 

We wanted to champion these types of low impact, affordable solutions in disadvantaged communities in other parts of the world. We saw an opportunity to use our time in school to look for ways local communities in Latin America could utilize them and tailor them to address the environmental problems they face.

It wasn't as easy as we thought. We found it difficult to make connections with local groups that could champion our ideas and the bureaucratic and logistical roadblocks seemed insurmountable. Fortunately, our fearless leader, Ricardo da Cruz e Sousa, persevered. He connected with a water district managing a creek in a poor neighborhood on the edge of the city of Quito who liked his ideas and offered to work with him on a demonstration project. The success of the project gained media attention from the local news, triggering a city ordinance to protect and restore all the creeks in the metropolitan area. 

Excited with this result, we founded International Watershed Partners (or IWP) to work to pave the way for other young professionals to utilize their burgeoning expertise on real world projects. We saw the opportunity for other students to have a similar impact while gaining experiences that will help them be better, more compassionate environmental planners and designers.

  

Since the success of Ricardo's work in Quito, IWP has helped four more environmental professionals, called IWP Fellows, to work on watershed plans and designs in three different communities in Ecuador and Cuba. In addition to providing our our Fellowswith small stipends for travel to their project sites, IWP helps them to navigate the often confusing and intimidating process of working in another country. We also build relationships with local organizations working on watershed issues who are open to these new technologies but who may not have the resources or expertise to pursue them on their own. We then connect them  with interested Fellows and leverage our experiences  to help the Fellow successfully work with communities to find solutions tailored to their needs. IWP has helped to facilitate the following projects:

  • A watershed assessment to identify  impacts on water quality and provide recommendations on landuse practices around a new airport for protecting and restoring the local streams in a poor community on the outskirts of Quito, Ecuador.
  • A wetland water treatment facility design for treating sewage in a impoverished community in Cuba.
  • Training city workers in holistic management of the urban forest in Cuenca, Ecuador.

We've recently been invited to collaborate on two more projects in Ecuador, and so we're now looking to OUR community for support in sending two more IWP Fellows to work.

What We Need 

The funding you will help us raise for this campaign will allow us to accomplish three major goals:

  1. Send 2 new IWP Fellows to work on important projects in Ecuador ($2500).
  2. Hire a web designer to revamp our website so we can reach more young professionals looking for real world experience and reach more disadvantaged communities looking for environmental planning expertise ($1650).
  3. Pay our 501(c)3 Tax Exemption application fee ($850).

All funding raised from this campaign will be paid to our Chief Financial Officer, Scott Walls.  Once we have received Tax exempt status IWP will be able to open a bank account of our very own and all donations will from then on will be tax exempt. We appreciate your support through this transition.

Your Impact

By donating to our campaign you will help fund students to travel to remote places and gain experience working with real people. From personal experience, we know what kind of impact this can have in making one a better, more compassionate environmental professional. You will also be helping disadvantaged communities find affordable solutions to complex water related problems such as floods and landslides, lack of potable water, poor sanitation, pollution, lack of habitat for culturally important species, and lack of open space.

Concretely, in the short term, your help will send 2 IWP Fellows down to Ecuador to work with our partner, Dr. Blanca Ríos Touma of the Center for Biodiversity and Climate Change Research of Universidad Tecnológica Indoamérica, on the following exciting projects:

1) An analysis of land use impacts on Andean tropical stream ecology and biodiversity

&

2) An analysis of how bioaccumulation of petroleum pollutants in fish pose a risk to the local Amazon communities who depend on these freshwater resources for food.

$2500 of our target will be spent on flights, lodging and any equipment the Fellows will need to assist Dr. Touma in her research.

In the long term, we'd like to grow our capacity to find new projects and continue building our relationship with the communities we've already helped. To help us do this, we'd like to develop a more robust and eye-catching IWP website that will enable us to:

  • better connect with communities and young professionals looking for the kinds of opportunities we're offering,
  • better communicate our Fellows' successes,
  • provide a place for others to learn from our projects and experiences implementing and developing holistic watershed technologies in new and diverse places, and
  • create a space for a community of compassionate and experienced professionals just starting out in their careers.

$1650 of our target will go to hiring a web designer to help us develop our webpage to meet our vision.

So far, with the support of local organizations on the ground at our project sites in Ecuador and Cuba, we've been able to accomplish so much solely on grit, "off the grid" (without tax exempt non-profit status).  We've learned a ton and have been proud of our accomplishments, but we'd like to be able to do more! We have a long term plan to fund our work which includes donations as well as taking advantage of the numerous grants offered by philanthropic organizations that support missions like ours. To do accomplish this we need to get legit with Uncle Sam, so in 2015 we will finally be filing for 501(c)3 Tax Exempt Status for Public Non-Profit Organizations. This status will provide us with the following benefits:

  • Income we earn is exempt from federal income tax
  • Donations are tax deductible for donors
  • Qualification to receive private and public grants
  • Lower postage rates on corporate mailings
  • Reduced rates for radio and public service announcements in the local media
  • Credibility in the nonprofit community

The fee to apply for 501(c)3 Tax Exempt Status is $850.

Risks & Challenges

Our experiences have given us unique insights into the challenges and obstacles we face. For instance, it will be important to find and enlist Fellows who have the language skills in addition to the appropriate technical skills to  effectively help the communities they will be working for and to communicate their findings. Additionally, in order to meet the needs of the communities we work in, we will need to build trust within these communities. To be persuasive in advocating for our Fellows recommendations, we also need to be able to navigate their local bureaucracies.  To meet these challenges we have brought together a world class Advisory Board and have sought out organizations and professionals based in the communities where we work. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. Spread the word! Ask folks to make some noise about our campaign and the great work we're doing. And don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

That's all there is to it. 

Oh, and thanks for your support!

Ricardo, Kelly, and Scott

story:
Stand up for Victims of Frac Sand Pseudo Science

How would you feel if an advocacy group from outside your community told you the life you worked hard to create would be put at risk by industrial development nearby? Would you take the warning seriously? Would you worry about the safety of your family or the value of your home?

Now imagine learning this supposedly credible advocacy group was composed of lawyers, not scientists, and it was deliberately withholding information and exaggerating the risks of a common activity, mining for sand, that has occurred safely near communities like yours for more than a century,

Would you be angry? Well, you should be!

This is exactly what is happening in communities in Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, and Wisconsin. Midwest Environmental Advocates (MEA) – a group of lawyers, not scientists, funded by George Soros and other anti-technology left-wing individuals and foundations – has misled people about the potential risk of mining for the sand used in hydraulic fracturing, commonly referred to as “frac sand” mining,

Why is this your problem?

First, MEA’s irresponsible advocacy has served to increase stress and anxiety among people living near sand minds or the sites of proposed new mines.

MEA's scaremongering has a larger negative impact on the health of people living near industrial sand facilities than the industrial sand operations themselves because they cause unnecessary fear and even panic. MEA is obscuring the truth: Industrial sand mining, when properly regulated, is safe.

Second, MEA contaminates and pollutes public debates over public safety by promoting flawed and unscientific research and dismissing the best-available science. The only study cited by MEA measuring levels of air particulates near industrial sand facilities is a highly controversial study that has been rejected by the scientific community. The Heartland Institute has published a critique of this study, noting the researchers did not use equipment or sampling methods approved by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

A far better study conducted by Institute for Wisconsin’s Health Inc. found industrial sand mining poses little risk to air or water quality. The report concluded the biggest health risk associated with industrial sand mining was stress and anxiety due to people worrying unnecessarily for their health, feeling as if they have lost their “sense of place,” and potential loss of property values.

Third,  unlike sand mining itself, scaremongering actually can lower property values for homes and businesses near existing or proposed sand mines. It can be used to frighten local officials into banning or erecting obstacles to an important and safe economic activity. And it can destroy jobs in rural communities where jobs are hard to come by.

MEA doesn't care if its inaccurate rhetoric hurts people, but you should. We all should. We could care about the victims of frac sand pseudo-science.


How The Heartland Institute is helping

The Heartland Institute is a 32-year-old national nonprofit organization that produces high-quality research on a wide range of public policy issues. We have 250 policy advisors -- academics and policy experts who produce original research and participate in peer-review -- and have published some 33 books and 140 policy studies.

Heartland has published five Policy Studies on hydraulic fracturing and frac sand mining coauthored by geologist Mark Krumenacher and Heartland Research Fellow Isaac Orr. In “Environmental Impacts of Industrial Silica Sand (Frac Sand) Mining,” Krumenacher and Orr conclude silica sand mining has minimal environmental impact, poses virtually no public health risk, and is an important part of domestic energy production that has substantial economic benefits.

Krumenacher and Orr's latest report, "Social Impacts of Industrial Silica Sand (Frac Sand) Mining: Land Use and Value," explains how "mining is not a threat to tourism, scnenic beauty, or property values."

Heartland has generated press coverage by writing and submitting news releases, op-eds, and letters to the editor. Heartland spokespersons have met with state legislators and community leaders to discuss the issue. We are about to release a series of videos to educate the public about all aspects of fracking and frac sand mining.

 

You can help the victims of frac-sand pseudo-science

Please help us fight for the victims of MEA’s irresponsible reporting! With your help, we can...

* distribute the best-available science to people living near industrial sand facilities and their elected representatives,

* travel to these communities to meet with civic and business leaders and testify before civic groups and city councils,

* educate millions of people with our webpage and posting videos to our YouTube channel.

With your help, the families who live near industrial sand facilities will sleep easier knowing the best-available scientific evidence says their families and communities are safe.

A generous contribution now to The Heartland Institute would be a timely investment in freedom. Gifts of any size will be greatly appreciated. I hope you’ll give today! If you have any questions, please call me at 312/377-4000 or send me an email at rknox@heartland.org.

For additional information on this topic and others, please visit www.heartland.org.

Keep In Touch!

Thanks for supporting The Heartland Institute!

Sign up for email updates about our progress here www.heartland.org
And share our project with friends, colleagues, and relatives via Facebook, Twitter, or by email

Invest in Freedom, Invest in The Heartland Institute!

story:
There are harmful things in life that legislation can't fix or ban. It falls upon people like you and us to figure out a better way. Our mission is to address a business practice that must be changed: Direct Mail.

Do you know the effects of Direct Mail on the environment? Do you know how much Direct Mail you receive? What it costs your community? If you don't, then please check our video. The answers will very likely shock you. 

Who Likes Direct Mail?!

Direct Mail = Paper (a lot of paper) that gets in your way. Paper that's pushed on you every day. 

Four common complaints about Direct Mail: 1. Irritation, 2. Waste, 3. Fraud, 4. Invasion of Privacy.

This Seinfeld episode pretty much sums the frustration caused by Direct Mail:




BusySt = Technology that makes your life easier, whenever you need it. 

(BusySt is pronounced as Busy Street)

During our feasibility study, we figured that the only way we could convince businesses to cut down or eliminate their use of Direct Mail is to actually offer them a much better alternative. But it also became clear to us that any solution we came up with had to be very appealing to consumers as well. 

So let's look at the main attributes of BusySt: 

1- BusySt will help any business or organization reach its community in a way that is:

  • Cost effective
  • Sustainable
  • Valuable to consumers 

2- BusySt will make it easier for consumers to:    

  • Find out what's happening around them.
  • Sort through the new options - that otherwise they wouldn't have known. 
  • Follow the businesses or organisations they're interested in. 
  • Share their discoveries with their friends and family. 

3- BusySt will be a comprehensive platform that encompasses components such as:

  • Real-time Search
  • Local Networking
  • Real-time Advertising
  • Analytics

BusySt will be a NEW and BETTER way for businesses to run their advertising campaigns at the local and national level. 

BusySt will be a NEW and BETTER way for consumers to build and maintain their Local Network. 

BusySt will be available as a website (on Mac and PC), and also as a FREE app for your iPhone or your Android phone. We intend to expand our app to the iPad and Android tablets in the future. 


  1. Support our project financially (with as little as $27)
  2. Support our project intellectually (with your ideas and expertise)
  3. Support our project socially (by telling your friends and family). 
  4. In the future, you can also ask your favorite business(es) to use our platform for their advertising. 

These 4 options are not mutually exclusive. We want this project to be open to all types of contributions. With your help we can:

  1. Bring the product to market rather sooner than later.
  2. Create more features in order to attract more businesses.

The answer is simple: programmers are expensive. Good programmers are even more expensive. 

The average salary of a mobile programmer in the US is around $100K/year. And that's for a full-time person. If we hire freelancers, they'd cost even more. And programmers who are experts in the iPhone environment aren't necessarily experts in the Android environment and vice versa. 

Needless to say that there are other expenses besides mobile programmers. 


If the environment is something you care about, if wasteful practices actually bother you, then this project is up your alley. So, please, get involved! 

Our goal is to convince businesses to use our platform while cutting down on their use of Direct Mail. We hope to bring down the use of Direct Mail by 30% in the next 5 years. That will save communities millions of dollars and save the world millions of trees. 

THE STAKES ARE SIGNIFICANT. 

As we mentioned, we welcome your ideas and expertise. Please feel free to write us at contribute@busy.st with details about how you can help intellectually. Include your contact information and, if possible, your resume. We will get back to you as quickly as possible. 

:-)

Cheers, 

Special message from Moncef (Founder at BusySt and Project Lead): 

Hello there - 
As the lead person on this project, I will do my best to address any question, suggestion, or concern you may have. Please send me the same to this email address: moncef@busy.st  
Thank you. 
Moncef



(color: dusk blue)

Cheers,

story:
Heal the Earth

Microbes are the key

Naturally occuring microbes in soil produce organic acids including humic and fulvic acid. Fulvic acid cleans chemicals from the soil and makes nutrients water soluable so plants can absorb them. Fulvic acid is nature's clean up and plant feeding mechanism. It increases natural sugar levels in plants which feed microbes at the root level. Those microbes in turn increase root mass, break down nutrients in the soil and feed nutrients back to the plant. That synergistic process worked well until we overwhelmed our soil with chemicals, including synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, herbicides and fungicides. Now the health of our soil has become critical.

Nature has the answer

Four years ago, while testing different sources of compost for a municipal landfill mitigation project, we discovered a specific compost which tested very high in organic acids. A small group of trusted friends collaberated on finding an extraction method. We discovered a process to extract fulvic acid and over 70 micro nutrients in a liquid without using any chemicals. The patent on this method is pending.

Does it really work?

We have tested the liquid, Fulvic Buffet and Fulvic Bloom, for three years and have proven that it does in fact improve the environment for microbes, and it helps feed plants nutrients critical to good plant health. When applied to plants our product can increase sugars in as little as thirty minutes, measured by refractometer.

We won third place in the Invented in Utah competition in 2010 for the extraction method we developed. We also won the 2012 Best of State for Business Innovation in Utah award.

Why is it important?

Healthy soil supports high levels of microbes so it cleans itself and grows healthy plants which produce fruits and vegetables that taste better and have a much longer shelf life. Sixty years ago it was common for people to store garden produce in a root celler all winter and into the next summer. Now if produce is not sold in a couple of weeks from the time it is removed from cold storage it is "outdated" and must be put in a landfill. The short shelf life of fruits and vegetables is a symptom of low nutrient value.

Reduces need for synthetic fertilizers

Microbes break down mineral nutrients, and fulvic acid feeds those nutrients into the roots of plants. High levels of microbes and fulvic acid allow plants to more easily uptake all nutrients, even synthetic fertilizers, so less fertilizer needs to be applied. Applying less fertilizer saves the environment by reducing nitrate and phosphate leaching into our water and air.

Reduces need for pesticides and fungicides

Healthy plants and soil tend to repel insects and disease so fewer pesticides and fungicides are needed to maintain yields. Abundant beneficial microbes also crowd out pests and fungi so they can't access roots.

 

Saves water

Adding Fulvic Bloom to plants results in greater root mass and higher microbe counts in the soil. This means plants utilize water better, and the soil retains water longer, which reduces drought stress on plants.

Higher yields

Healthy soils and healthy plants lead to higher yields. Farmers from Georgia to Wisconsin who have added our product to their fertilizer programs have achieved five new state records for corn production in just the past  two years. Fulvic Bloom improves germination and gives young tender plants a jumpstart.

Help us heal the earth

We have proven the product and now we need capital to expand to give more people access to our product. Market testing our liquid fulvic in Home and Garden Shows indicates consumers are looking for a natural product which will reduce or eliminate the need for chemicals which may harm animals and children. When compared to the most popular chemical based liquid fertilizer on the market, our product worked better at lower cost and without chemicals.

We know we can restore health to soil, plants, animals and people by using natural organics, it's just nature concentrated. But we need to expand our production so more people can join the movement to heal the earth.

How the funds will be used

Increased storage

Continuous extractor

Mixing tanks

Loadout facility

Building for winter extraction and equipment storage

You can join the movement to heal the earth by contributing to our campaign, or by helping to spread the word to friends and acquaintances. We are passionate about the good we can accomplish with your help. When you donate to our campaign we will send you product to use so you can do your part in Healing the Earth.

story:
Design students from the Maryland Institute College of Art want to turn an old box truck in to a mobile water filtration system and education center about the impending water shortage crisis.

Water scarcity is one of the biggest issues facing our society today - did you know that 1 in 8 people in the world don't have access to safe drinking water? This number will only increase over time. Despite this and other shocking statistics, most people remain woefully uneducated about the impending global water crisis - our goal is to change that.

 

We want to create a mobilized water filtration system that serves as a functioning laboratory and educational outreach center. We're teaming up with University of Florida at Gainesville students who are currently in the process of designing an innovative and sustainable water filtration system. We design the mobile platform - they engineer the scientific components. Our plan is to raise enough money to purchase a box truck that we can then renovate and turn in to a mobile, interactive education center about water scarcity, water security and water conservation. 

What We Need

To do this we need your help - we need about $11,500.

  • $4,500 for the purchase of a used, but adequate box truck with a little over 100,000 miles
  • $3,000 for parts and materials to retrofit the truck
  • $2,500 for the vehicle wrap and decal to brand the truck
  • $1,500 for printing costs to develop our first print run of handouts and fliers

By contributing you're not only helping a group of young students develop their skills and talents as designers - you're also helping to spread awareness about water scarcity, water security, and water conservation - something we should all be devoting more time and attention to. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Like our project but can't donate? No problem! You can still help us by spreading the word - be sure to like us on facebook and follow us on twitter, or just simply tell your friends about us. Anything helps!

story:
PROTECTING OUR ENVIRONMENT TAKES EVERYBODY

When Jeff Wallin, founder of The Biochar Company, became a father, his perspective entirely shifted. He found himself wondering what life would look like for his children after a few decades of the climate crisis.

As any good entrepreneur would do, Jeff found a solution he believed could help shape a better future: biochar—a tool that simultaneously helps heal the soil and atmosphere, while growing better plants.

Today, Jeff’s company--The Biochar Company-- is one of 11 finalists in Sir Richard Branson’s $25 million Virgin Earth Challenge and is launching a new soil-building system that unlocks the power of biochar to help gardeners create soil rich in carbon-based organic matter that can capture and contain vital nutrients, bacteria, and other microorganisms critical to plant life, and our own! 

Why biochar?

Biochar was first used by Amazon natives to transform thin, low-nutrient soil, into productive fields for crops and grazing. Over eons, these people perfected an ecologically sound system for converting organic material, such as wood and plant waste, into a carbon-rich, powerful soil amendment that captures carbon in the soil and puts it to work growing plants instead of releasing it into the atmosphere. 

The reason the people behind The Biochar Companyget up in the morning is to create products that enable you to grow life from soil better than ever before, while at the same time, being part of the solution for a better future. Each time someone buys one cubic yard of biochar, they are eliminating the same amount of carbon emissions from 3.4 cars on the road. The Biochar Company believes that a connection with the soil is important—without it, life does not exist. Biochar helps protect our soil, food, and atmosphere – critical elements of environmental awareness  and our existence!

Soil Reef and the Virgin Earth Challenge

Biochar’s ability to sequester carbon is why The Biochar Company was named a finalist in the Virgin Earth Challenge, established by Virgin Chairman Sir Richard Branson to incent and reward sustainable and scale-able solutions to remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.

The contest is ongoing with only 11 companies still in the running. This campaign is one more step in proving the commercial viability of biochar as a carbon sequestration technology that benefits the consumer and the planet, while hopefully moving Soil Reef closer to winning the $25 million prize. 

How you can help

The thought of combating climate change can be overwhelming. It’s easy to feel like there isn’t much we can do on an individual level. But, using biochar is something you can do to make a long-term difference by removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.

This campaign aims to raise a minimum of $30,000 dollars to develop and market the Soil Reef Biochar System, an all-natural, organic biochar soil-building system that creates dark and rich productive soil for the backyard gardener. Anyone who contributes $100 will receive the three-part Soil Reef Biochar System conveniently delivered to their doorstep. Those supporters who contribute $150 will also buy an Estufa Finca stove for a less-fortunate family in the Dominican Republic. The stove, created by local craftspeople, prepares food, discharging substantially less carbon and particulates into the air compared to an open fire, using less wood, while creating biochar as an end product. 

Join us as we take the next step in the organic gardening movement, and improve our fruits, vegetables, and flowers, help farmers in developing nations, and our planet as a whole!

Today, Jeff’s
company--The Biochar Company-- is one of 11 finalists in Sir Richard Branson’s
$25 million Virgin Earth Challenge and is launching a new soil-building
system that unlocks the power of biochar to help gardeners create soil rich in
carbon-based organic matter that can capture and contain vital nutrients,
bacteria, and other microorganisms critical to plant life, and our own! 
Why biochar?
Biochar was first
used by Amazon natives to transform thin, low-nutrient soil, into productive
fields for crops and grazing. Over eons, these people perfected an ecologically
sound system for converting organic material, such as wood and plant waste,
into a carbon-rich, powerful soil amendment that captures carbon in the soil
and puts it to work growing plants instead of releasing it into the
atmosphere. 
The
reason the people behind The Biochar Companyget up in the morning is to
create products that enable you to grow life from soil better than ever before,
while at the same time, being part of the solution for a better future. Each
time someone buys one cubic yard of biochar, they are eliminating the same
amount of carbon emissions from 3.4 cars on the road. The Biochar Company
believes that a connection with the soil is important—without it, life does not
exist. Biochar helps protect our soil, food, and atmosphere – critical elements
of environmental awareness  and our existence! 
Soil Reef and the
Virgin Earth Challenge
Biochar’s ability
to sequester carbon is why The Biochar Company was named a finalist in the
Virgin Earth Challenge, established by Virgin Chairman Sir Richard Branson to
incent and reward sustainable and scale-able solutions to remove greenhouse
gases from the atmosphere.
The contest is
ongoing with only 11 companies still in the running. This campaign is one more
step in proving the commercial viability of biochar as a carbon sequestration
technology that benefits the consumer and the planet, while hopefully moving
Soil Reef closer to winning the $25 million prize. 
How you can help
The thought of
combating climate change can be overwhelming. It’s easy to feel like there
isn’t much we can do on an individual level. But, using biochar is something you can do to make a long-term difference by
removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
This
campaign aims to raise a minimum of $30,000 dollars to develop and market the Soil Reef
Biochar System, an all-natural, organic biochar soil-building system that
creates dark and rich productive soil for the backyard gardener. Anyone who
contributes $100 will receive the three-part Soil Reef Biochar System
conveniently delivered to their doorstep. Those supporters who contribute $150
will also buy an Estufa Finca stove for a less-fortunate family in the
Dominican Republic. The stove, created by local craftspeople, prepares food,
discharging substantially less carbon and particulates into the air compared to
an open fire, using less wood, while creating biochar as an end product. 
Join us as we take
the next step in the organic gardening movement, and improve our fruits, vegetables,
and flowers, help farmers in developing nations, and our planet as a whole!

story:
Eco-Charcoal poduces Zambia's first and only sustainable, high-quality charcoal. We exist to confront unsustainable charcoal production, which is a major driver of deforestation in Zambia. About 85% of urban Zambians rely on charcoal, especially with the ongoing power deficit. Charcoal, however, can be produced in a sustainable and environmentally-friendly way. We use sustainable harvesting practices, to reduce deforestation and local poverty, through job creation and improved income to rural producers. Please check out our Eco-Charcoal brochure and flyer to learn more.

Tree cover accounts for about 83% of Zambia's landmass, covering about 61 million hectares. In 2014, the Central Province of Zambia experienced over 40,000 hectares of forest loss, while Zambia as a whole loses around 300,000 hectares annually.

How you can help:

Please help us to continue this vital work, by supporting us with the purchase of an essential transport vehicle. This second-hand vehicle will be used to visit rural producers and customers, and enable us spread the word about our charcoal alternative and ultimately protect more forests across Zambia.

More about how we work:

  • Our project is currently implemented on approximately 430 hectares of community forest land in Ndubulula, Namanongo, and Mwe'shangombe communities, with expansion to other areas soon. 
  • We use a sustainable harvesting system, allowing for full regrowth and regeneration of forests, enabling charcoal to be produced as a renewable resource. We do this by using the Coupe and Shelterbelt system of sustainable harvesting, never fully cutting down trees and allowing for optiumum forest regeneration over an 18 year rotation cycle. 
  • We only use higher-efficiency kilns that make use of entire trees and produce more charcoal, reducing the number of trees that are cut.
  • We work with independent local producers (called Charpreneurs), who are often former traditional charcoal makers. We train them in sustainable, environmentally-friendly charcoal harvesting and production methods, and pay 20% above market price.
  • We sell this sustainable charcoal to restaurants, lodges and individuals in Lusaka, Zambia. You can read more about us on our website, or get in touch with our team at sales@eco-charcoal.com or on +260 974 904 155 or +260 211 290 051.

story:
Have you ever thought about all the money we can waste on silly souvenirs and gifts, every year? Instead of purchasing yet again another oversized teddy bear covered in hearts we thought we’d find a better use for some of that money, but we can't do it alone!

There are so many reasons why, backing up the life of a Llama or an Alpaca, is cooler than giving away a cuddly Valentine's or Eastern toy:

1. You will get an awesome update of your beneficiary pet, in the Andes Mountains!

2. Plus receiving monthly surprises from your adopted Llama (valid for the months you decide to adopt it). Because, who doesn’t love surprises?!

3. Get an Adoption Certificate to make your relationship official!

4. A community based touristic experience! (Depending on which perk you choose).

5. Most importantly, you can move your relationship with the planet to the next level, by adopting... a Llama... in Ecuador!

So why should we adopt a Llama or an Alpaca in Ecuador???

Adopting Andean Camelids like Llamas or Alpacas, creates a symbiotic relationship with the environment, plus you will help to empower a community in the Andes Mountains, by helping them to break their economic dependence on traditional cattle. Cows are one of the biggest polluters and deforesters of the Planet. Don’t get us wrong! We love our cow friends, we just know more benefits can come from camelids. Save a cow and adopt a Llama!

In conclusion, by remotely supporting the life of a Llama or Alpaca each and everyone of us has the opportunity to directly contribute to environmental and economic sustainability. The benefits of the adoption can be surprisingly positive. The Andes Mountains and especially its high-moors hold around 10% of the Planet's fresh-water, but the people's economic dependence on cows, has taken that livestock frontier, to gain more terrain, imagine the risk for those water reserves. This vicious circle can be turned around with a little bit of our support.

We work closely with people from the Ecuadorean high-moors, and together we believe on the importance of CBT (Communitarian Based Tourism) helping the whole region and beyond, to break poverty cycles and finally eliminating their economic dependence on cows. Furthermore, we bring ecological minded people to the region that will help us to stabilize and preserve this important ecosystem (for the whole world), while offering you a cultural experience!

So, who are “we”:

We are a small but international group of like-minded people. Based in San Francisco, California, IncitU Empowerment pilots its first initiatives in Ecuador. IncitU creates ideas to empower people, from the bottom of the pyramid in the most developing parts of the world. At the end of the day, we all life on the same beautiful planet all together. http://incituempowerment.com

story:
What is our story?

  • We are concerned neighbors, living in The Kawartha’s and there is a huge limestone development proposed in our area.
  • The Proposed 400 acre quarry is a class A, Category 4, crushed stone and Dimensional stone
  • Our Township has approved this application.....9 of us are officially opposing it at the level of the Ontario Municipal Board on May 20, 2014
  • We want to ensure that our environment including water, land and sound are being protected against Limestone Industrial development  & ancillary operations including
  • Our area is big, but our population is small as many of our residents are seasonal, so trying to bring awareness to this plight has been difficult.


Where exactly do we live?

  • We live northeast of Bobcaygeon in an area called Nogies Creek a major tourist destination in Ontario.
  • Maybe you have fished; water skied or snowmobiled in our area.
  • Nogies creek empties into Pigeon Lake, which is one of the Kawartha Lakes and part of the Trent System
  • Maybe you have boated through the Trent System or entered a Walleye tournament on Pigeon Lake
  • We live in a limestone rich county and the proposed development is only a short distance from Nogies Creek
  • We live about a 2 hour drive South of Algonquin Park and about 2 hours north of Toronto


Legal Issues

  • Proposed development is near our Provincial Fish Sanctuary where Muskies still spawn and Bald Eagles can be seen flying over
  • Possible Loss of property value
  • Possible increased taxes to maintain roads
  • Disappearing wildlife from noise & dust including deer that cross our front lawns daily 
  • Increased truck traffic


What are we asking you do?

We have opposed this issue ourselves for 2 years but now can’t do it alone.....it is just too expensive......we need funding help........

  • Funds for legal counsel to attempt to stop this development and put regulations in place for environmental protection from Limestone Development
  • Funds for experts in the field of environmental protection, to present evidence that our land, water and air are in danger
  • This evidence will be presented  by the experts to the Ontario Municipal Board (OMB)
  • All funds will go directly to these needs.

What have we done so far?

  • Hired an Environmental Lawyer
  • Hired a Land Planner
  • Formed a quarry committee under NPLRA (North Pigeon Lake Ratepayers Ass)
  • Public meetings x 3 of which highest attendance was 500 local residents. (many were turned away due to building capacity restrictions)
  • Delegations sent at Municipal and County level to show our opposition
  • Collaboration with First Nations at Curve Lake as the proposed area is scared hunting ground
  • Collected $4000.00 in bank currently from anonymous/personal funding
  • Written numerous editorials in local newspapers
  • Spent personal money to start acquiring expert’s reports
  • Concert for Fund Raising has been organized for April 19/14 during Earth Week at the Lakeview Arts Barn featuring the Eclectic G-Strings
  • Special guest speaker Maude Barlow (National Chairperson of the Council of Canadians) on April 19th/14 at the Lakeview Arts Barn

http://www.cfrad.com

http://www.stopthisquarry.com

story:
Tourism Beyond Sustainability

The PermaculTourism Initiative is a regenerative model for global-tourism, going beyond the "leave no trace" goal of eco-tourism, to leave a beautiful trace by utilizing Permaculture Design within our educational travel programs. 


This 16-day PermaculTourism Adventure in Nepal will be documented through videography, photography, audio-recording, and written story to set an example of the impact that can emerge when earth-conscious, willing, global community comes together. Our curriculum will engage international participants and local villagers alike to generate the maximum regenerative impact on the Earth.

What We Need

Your donations will go towards building Permaculture systems and infrastructure at four main focus sites along our way: 

  • Shree Jana Adarsh Secondary School in Kobang
  • A small family-owned Organic Farm near the Hot Springs of Tatopani
  • Tibetan Refugee Settlement in Marpha
  • Rainbow Children's Home in Pokhara

Your Donations will also support... 

  • Permaculture infrastructure including: Food Forrest, Earth-Works, Greenhouse, Compost Facilities, Polyculture-Gardens, Natural-Building structures, and More! Includes the cost of tools and materials required for establishing a model Permaculture system at the Shree Jana Adarsh School.
  • Education: Providing free education to any interested Nepali people including course materials and services
  • Media: Documenting the experience to share with the World. This includes videography, photograpy, audio-recording, some equipment and costs of production and replication.
  • Organization Costs: Including transportation, food, and lodging of our team of facilitators.
  • Stipends for the Nepali people who contribute their services as teachers and guides.


What You Get

  • By donating a little to this campaign you can personally engage from afar with Nepali students and will be able to witness the benefit your kindness has imparted.
  • By donating a little more you can support local Nepali craftspeople, receive a beautiful hand-made item from Nepal, choose your favorite photos to cherish for years to come, and even become a sponsor of the project.
  • By donating a lot, you can come be part of the team (limited space available).  You will learn Permaculture techniques and then get a chance to implement them. You will have the opportunity to be inspired by the hearts of the Nepali people you will be collaborating with and help to leave a beautiful trace in your wake.

Perks!

New Perks! Only 1 available each!


The Impact

By participating in our campaign, you are having a direct Impact in the following ways:

  • Contribution of Permaculture Infrastructure and Education to the people of Nepal
  • Reverse Engineering a Regenerative Model for Tourism which can be shared with the rest of the world through extensive Documentation.
  • This is an equal cultural exchange between global participants and local Nepali people. The experience is designed to inspire all parties involved to take these Life-Abundance giving practices home to impact their own communities. Participants can expect to be impacted as much as they will impact.

The Journey

While a trip through the Himalayas is inevitably life-changing, this adventure presents some highly unique features, setting it apart from other tours.

  • Equal Exchange- Within this co-creative convergence of East and West, our goal is equally to teach and learn, to share skills and learn the traditional ways of Nepal. Our aim in serving others, is not to offer "Aid", or to "fix" anything or anyone, but to ultimately nourish our own growth and collective well-being.
  • Spiritual Inquiry- This journey is designed to be as much of an inner journey as it is an outer journey. 
  • On, yet Off the Beaten Path- Until 1992, this region of Nepal, the Kingdom of Mustang, was closed to foreigners. Though it is now one of the most popular and cherished trekking routes in the World, our program offers a unique opportunity to enter into deep relationship with the land and local-people. Our Itinerary will bring us to experience many gems of the area which are normally unnoticed by the typical passerby.

MEET THE TEAM

Buddhi Ratna Sherchan- "Apple Father" of Nepal. Senior Horticulturist who first introduced Apples, Walnuts, Cherries, Plums, Almonds, Pears, and many other important foods to Nepal. As a native to the area, his guidance, knowledge and charming presence is invaluable!

Brandon Bodhi Denton- Botanist, Permaculture Education Facilitator, and Founder of the PermaculTourism Initiative, Bodhi has served in building a bridge by which diverse global-community can flourish, and essential Earth-Skills can be shared. He will serve as a guide, and facilitator of Permaculture lessons and Yoga practices along the way.

Theron Beaudreau- Permaculture Mentor with Gaia University, Theron is devoted to generating the greatest regenerative impact on this Earth possible. He will play an essential role in the Education, Design, and Implementation of Permaculture in our program.

Thomas Waymouth & Ashley Wright- Permaculture Designers propelled by the power of story to evolve the collective paradigm on Earth. They will be documenting the journey through videography, producing a documentary short to inspire the masses.

Ben Newman- Professional photographer devoted to capturing the essential nature of consciousness provoking projects in the World. 

Matt Evans- A renaissance man of many trades, Matt will be guiding our community of PermaculTourists in daily Qi Gong practices to further deepen our inner-experience of the journey. 

The Documentary

The film will narrate a brief history of the region, it’s stories, ancient wisdom, and challenges in the modern era as well as the hopes of the Nepali people for the future of their community.  This documentary will feature the interactions between Easterners and Westerners at the retreat as well as their co-creations on the land.  As the Nepali people share their way of life and dreams, so too will the Westerners share their perspectives.  We will document the victories and challenges alike and show the impact left on the community.

In addition to being a unique and rich story, this film will be a priceless resource for anyone who wishes to create more sustainable and regenerative tours in any country .


Other Ways You Can Help!

We understand that some people cannot contribute financially, but there are other very important ways to help!

  • Get the word out by sharing our campaign with your friends and contacts!
  • Take advantage of the Indiegogo tools for sharing to Facebook, Twitter, and more!
  • If you have friends with relevant blogs, give them a recommendation to feature us on their blog. 


STRETCH GOAL! 

The money we raise beyond our goal will go towards registering a Non-Profit Organization called GAIA (Global Abundance In Action). The cost of this process is around $3,000, bringing our stretch goal to just over $15,000. The Mission of GAIA is to bring Permaculture Education and Infrastructure to underserved communities, encouraging global abundance through local, grassroots action. The PermaculTourism Initiative is the first phase of this long term, regenerative movement. 


What is Permaculture?

There are many ways of defining this vastly applicable system of design; here are a few of our favorites: 

“Permaculture is defined as consciously designed landscapes which mimic the patterns and relationships found in Nature, while yielding an abundance of food, fiber, and energy for the provision of local needs… More precisely, I see Permaculture as the use of systems thinking and design principles that provide the organizing framework for implementing the above vision.”                 -David Holmgren, co-founder of Permaculture

“Observe Nature thoroughly, rather than labor thoughtlessly.”         –Masanobu Fukuoka

“Permaculture is the art of the Possible”      -Graham Bell

“Permaculture is a Revolution disguised as Organic Gardening”  -Graham Burnett

Our Curriculum

This Practice-Intensive Permaculture Course will provide participants and locals with the opportunity to learn a diverse spectrum of skills and practices including: 

THANK YOU for supporting us by donating, sharing the link (igg.me/at/permacultourism), and for caring about our vision of a healthy, thriving planet!

He will play an essential role in the Education, Design, and Implementation of Permaculture in our program.Thomas Waymouth & Ashley Wright- Permaculture Designers propelled by the power of story to evolve the collective paradigm on Earth.
