story:
This is a flexible funding campaign so we will receive all of the funds even if we don't hit our goal.  

We know we can make a big push over these last 7 days. Can you please chip in and share with everyone you think would be interested in the campaign? Thanks for all your support.

Learn more at www.AidStillRequired.org/Haiti2014

Check out this article about our own Kelly Kruger and the Jatropha program! Thanks Kelly http://cbs.soapsindepth.com/2014/02/soap-stars-team-up-for-good-cause.html
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fund a Jatropha Seed Oil Press for Haiti, Change the Lives of Thousands

For the past three years, 1,000 farmers have been growing hundreds of thousands of Jatropha trees in southern Haiti.  Why?  Because the seeds from these trees produce oil so rich it serves as a straight replacement for diesel fuel.  Yes, that means you can run your car, truck or farm machinery on it. 

These trees are now mature and ready for harvest, and Darin and Kelly need you for the final step – to bring the proper presses to Haiti to extract the oil.

Jatropha doesn’t just produce clean fuel.  It produces jobs – thousands of them – plus, a cleaner atmosphere and dignity for the farmers.  In a nation like Haiti that has struggled for centuries to become self-sufficient, this is huge. 

We are asking you to join with Sirona Cares and Aid Still Required to make this program happen.  Together we can create a new future for thousands in Haiti.

      

Turning these jatropha seeds into fuel can only happen with your help.

“We are getting involved with this project because we know that once a disaster leaves the headlines, people forget about the work that still needs to be done years later. Haiti is no different and we want to do all we can to make sure the people of Haiti have a chance at true, sustainable recovery. Thanks for joining with us.” -Kelly Kruger and Darin Brooks

Today 95% of the people in Haiti live on $2 or less per day.  Almost none of them have electricity, running water, or seemingly a future. 

We can change the course in Haiti.


                    

What we know:

1.  People need jobs.

2.  People need access to energy – clean energy.

3.  People need to protect the environment.

4.  These oil presses will allow all of this to be accomplished, providing enough income for thousands of farmers to provide for their families.

5.  YOU CAN MAKE IT HAPPEN



What's it going to take?

$25,000 allows us to ship oil presses to Haiti, install them, and train Haitians in their operation.  Since there’s a ready market for Jatropha oil, we’ve guaranteed farmers that we’ll buy all the seeds they can harvest.  We then sell the oil for about $3.50/gallon and use those proceeds to buy more seeds from the farmers.

Your contributions give thousands a livelihood they never had.

It's beautiful. It's simple. It’s clean. It's sustainable. 

Awesome. I want to help. Can I get hooked up in return?

Yes. Darin and Kelly are going to make that happen. At different funding levels, you are going to get totally unique, limited edition products, personal emails, letters and phone calls from celebrities, and, for the right price, you are going to get to do something that no one else gets to do.  Check out the kickbacks and dig deep. Your support will go a long, long way towards helping the people of Haiti.

                                                        


                                


          

  

             
Sirona Cares Foundation is a registered 501(c)3 nonprofit, has been working to build sustainable communities for five years by giving the poorest of the poor the ability to create, use and sell alternative energy.  Energy access is empowering.  Our biofuel and solar programs give communities the hand up that they need to become self-sufficient within the context of sustainable business models.


Aid Still Required, “One of 7 Charities to Watch”  (The Huffington Post), is a registered 501(c)3 that refocuses the spotlight on people who have been forgotten after natural disasters. With the help of personalities such as Adam Levine, Paul McCartney, Sting, Kevin Spacey, Kobe Bryant and dozens of others, ASR outreach campaigns have reached 500 million worldwide.

story:
Short Summary

The evocative purr of the European Turtle Dove is disappearing from the UK and Europe as populations decline rapidly.  The UK has lost 95% of its breeding turtle doves since 1970 and if declines carry on at their current rate, the species may be lost as a UK breeding bird within 10 years.

From previous research, we know that turtle doves changed their diet between the 1960s and the 1990s, from the seeds of arable plants to the grains of cultivated crops.  At the same time, the number of breeding attempts per pair of turtle doves per year has dropped.  Over the past four years, we have collected data from turtle doves breeding in the UK that will allow us to see whether this change in turtle dove diet is related to breeding success, and whether by providing food in the right way we can reverse the fortunes of this diminutive dove - but we need your help.


What We Need & What You Get

Since the start of this research project in 2011, new molecular tools have been developed which will allow us to find out what turtle doves are eating by looking at the DNA in faecal samples.  But these state of the art techniques are expensive: £5,000 would allow us to analyse the 144 faecal samples collected over the four years of this research - samples from both adult and nestling turtle doves (92 samples), as well as small numbers of samples from other dove and pigeon species.  As well as what turtle doves are eating, we could then find out:

- whether certain foods help nestling turtle doves grow faster

- whether the switch in turtle dove diet observed in the 1990s has led to turtle doves sharing the same food resources as other (larger and more common) doves and pigeons

- whether certain foods are associated with infection by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas gallinae, which causes the disease trichomonosis and has been linked to mortality in both adult and nestling turtle doves.


Laboratory analysis will take place at Cardiff University, in a laboratory with much experience of this type of research.  Use of reagents and consumables (pipette tips, plasticware, etc) will cost £300.

Firstly, we will need to build a reference library of DNA sequences from seeds available to turtle doves.  This will cost £1,200 for the 139 seed species we have identified. The reference library will be publicly available when we have completed our research so that other researchers can use it in the future.

Second, we will analyse the 144 faecal samples by extracting DNA from each sample, identifying the section of DNA in which we are interested, and submitting the samples to sequence this DNA using Next Generation ion torrent sequencing.  This will cost £3,500 and will allow us to compare the sequences from the faecal samples to our reference library so we identify the species of seed present within each faecal sample.


If we don't reach our target of £5,000, we can still analyse some of our 92 turtle dove samples, providing valuable knowledge - but with your help, we can achieve our goal of analysing all 144 samples.


The Impact

By providing more information about what turtle doves are eating and whether certain foods are 'better' for turtle doves than others, we can recommend ways in which to provide this food.  This could be through large-scale deployment of certain plants within agri-environment options, which will guide farmers to provide good feeding habitats for turtle doves on their land.  It might be that householders can provide the food that turtle doves need, through supplementary feeding in gardens, or through smaller-scale planting of certain plants in a quiet corner of their garden.

The results of this research will be publicised via social media, and through press releases from all partners involved with this work (RSPB, Natural England, Cardiff University).

By funding this research, you can contribute directly to turtle dove research and conservation.


Risks & Challenges

The samples we need in order to carry out this research have already been collected.  The laboratory within which this work will be carried out is the best in the country at carrying out this kind of research. The team involved in this work have the expertise to ensure that the results of the work have the maximum impact on policy, and that the results are publicised in order to reach the widest possible audience.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to this campaign directly, please share the link with friends and colleagues.  By spreading the word, you can still help us fund this important work and increase the chances of conserving this beautiful bird.

story:
J Street U Brandeis is initiating a campaign to raise awareness around the current water crisis in Gaza. Through the end of November, J Street U Brandeis will be fundraising for Friends of the Earth Middle East - EcoPeace and Other Voice- Two environmental organizations working to end the Gaza water shortage. 

The water situation for the 1.7 million Palestinian residents of Gaza was dire before this summer's war. Today, it's catastrophic.

Due to electricity shortages and damage to Gaza infrastructure, untreated sewage is flooding Gaza streets and running into the sea, creating public health risk for Gazans and Israelis alike.

Gazans desperately need access to clean water, and there is an easy solution. One of three water pipelines that run from Israel into Gaza has never been turned on. Israel could literally double the flow of potable water to Gaza today--it's as easy as turning on the faucet.

Come find us tabling in Usdan and the SCC from November 5th to November 20th

story:
The Black Mamba APU is the first of its kind, a female anti-poaching unit! Founded in 2013 by Transfrontier Africa (NPO) to protect the wildlife in the Olifants West region of Balule Nature Reserve and over the past 2 years we have expanded to cover the entire Balule Nature Reserve. Yes, our main objective is the protection of wildlife but we also strive to create a strong bond and educate the communities that live on the boundaries of Balule and the Greater Kruger Park to the benefits of saving their natural heritage. We receive no financial support from the Kruger National Park or the government, and rely heavily on donations. 
Your donation will fund the new equipment we need in order to continue our anti-poaching efforts. The pressure from rhino poachers is increasing and we need help funding the tools we need in order to continue protecting the rhinos in our area of operation. 

By reaching our goal of $4800 we will be able to purchase all the equipment we currently need to continue our operations in the field. All donations received during this campaign will be used to purchase; 3 x Hand held two way Radios, 2 x Mid-band Radios, 5 x ETREX GPS, 3 x VHF Tracking Receivers, 3 x VHF tracking Antennas, 6 x VHF Tracking Cables. If we do not reach our total goal of $4800, all funds raised will be used to purchase the most critical equipment needed from the list above.

We understand that some people are not in a position to contribute, but they still want to help! If this is the case for you, you can still help us by spreading the word, share this campaign with your friends and family.
For more information about the Black Mamba APU visit our website www.blackmambas.org or find us on Facebook.

story:
Our team is united by the passion and excitement we feel about our ability to help create a cleaner, greener future.

                                                   

We need seed capital to build a machine that takes waste biomass and produces a direct substitute for coal. We can showcase a functional model of the process but need funding to build our own commercial unit in Malaysia, tailored to a specific waste source – palm oil plantation waste, in this case empty fruit bunches (EFBs).

We can demonstrate that through torrefaction (thermal treatment, roasting a bit like coffee beans) waste vegetation can be transformed into a fuel able to replace coal.


Not only will our design result in a valuable product that helps to reduce our reliance on fossil fuels, but will also provide an economical way for the palm oil industry to dispose of waste that is currently burnt or left to rot. 


Here's a short film to give you a brief overview of the project and why it is important:



Palm Oil.....Can be Sustainable!


The palm oil industry is widely criticized for having serious impacts on the environment and its native inhabitants. Two of the most serious of these are deforestation to make way for plantations and the associated loss of habitat for endangered species. Other impacts include soil erosion, air pollution, soil and water pollution, and contribution to climate change (WWF, 2014).

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is perhaps the most significant attempt to mitigate these impacts, aiming "to promote the growth and use of sustainable palm oil through co-operation within the supply chain and open dialogue between its stakeholders" (RSPO, 2014). Through their certification system which tackles the issues associated with palm oil, the product can gain a far more favorable image in the marketplace. Follow this link to read the RSPO Principles and Criteria for Sustainable Palm Oil Production (2013).

Whilst our product cannot single-handedly resolve all of the industry's environmental issues, it can go a long way towards helping. Through using the waste EFBs as opposed to letting them rot, methane emissions are reduced, as is potential contamination of waterways. If EFBs are burnt then their valuable energy content is wasted and there is the risk of uncontrolled fires. In the long term, it is hoped that our product can contribute to the reduction of deforestation, due to a change in the mindset of palm oil plantation owners, from profit through expansion, to profit through increased efficiency.


One major contribution we can make now, is to help the palm oil industry become a player in mitigating climate change through its potential to help provide a sustainable and cleaner alternative to fossil fuels.


Coal......Putting Instant Gratification Above the Future of the Planet


The graph below shows investment in fossil fuels continuing to dwarf investment in renewable energy. 'Investors are putting short-term rewards ahead of the long-term health of the planet' (Walsh, 2014). To avoid the potentially catastrophic and irreversible effects of raising the planet's temperature by just 2 degrees Celsius, the International Energy Agency estimates that another $10.5 trillion needs to be invested in clean energy by 2030 (Walsh, 2014).

(Global and U.S. investment in fossil fuels dwarfs investment in renewable energy, Walsh, 2014)

Global coal consumption has never stopped increasing. Since the beginning of the 21st Century, it has been the fastest growing global energy source its use increasing 60% between 2000 and 2012 (International Energy Agency, 2014). Currently, over 40% of the world's electricity is produced by coal and 70% of all steel production depends on coal (World Coal Association, 2014).

This growth has been driven largely by developing economies, in particular China and more generally Asia.This map shows the huge increase in coal use in Asia between 1980 and 2010 (US Energy Information Administration, 2014) (1 short ton = 0.90718 metric tons).

In Malaysia, imports of coal grew nearly ten times between 1992 and 2012, from 1485 KTOE to 14,220 KTOE (Suruhanjaya Tenaga (Energy Commission), 2014, p.23) and coal's importance in Malaysia's electricty generation mix also grew. In 1992 coal provided 13% of total generation. In 2012 it had grown to providing 41% of generation (Suruhanjaya Tenaga (Energy Commission), 2014, p.30).

Despite this, there are still 1.3 billion people across the world without access to electricity (World Coal Association, 2014) and as population continues to rise, as will demand for energy. Pressures on agriculture to sustain the population will mean increasing agricultural waste products and further increasing pressure to enhance its sustainability. This all highlights the already vast, and growing opportunity for our product in the marketplace.


                                     

                              (It's the real deal, BUT....it has a closed carbon cycle)

Although the burning of bio-coal does release carbon dioxide (CO2) it works in a 'closed-loop' cycle. The biomass takes sunlight and CO2 from the atmosphere to grow and create energy. This is then eventually released back in to the atmosphere via decay or combustion. Our process simply speeds this cycle up and so long as the biomass keeps regrowing, the loop remains closed.  This is very different to the CO2 from fossil fuels which have been in the ground for millions of years. If we weren't to use them today, their carbon wouldn't naturally be released. Thus burning them increases the net amount of carbon in the atmosphere.

       

(Our product has a 'closed-loop' carbon cycle)

Whilst the energy content of our torrefied biomass is around the same as coal, it gives off no sulfur emissions and produces significantly less ash. Coal ash contains toxic heavy metals such as lead, mercury and arsenic, whereas biomass ash contains none of these.

As of 2010, it has been calculated that the biomass available from the palm oil industry in Malaysia holds the energy potential of 37,000 KTOE/Y (Kilo-Tons Oil Equivalent/Year, 1 KTOE = energy contained equivalent to 1000 tons of oil).

EFBs alone contribute over 9500 KTOE/Y to this figure (Pei Qin Ng et al., 2012, p.59) which is enough energy equivalent to replace over 13.5 million metric tons of coal every year - that's about two thirds of the coal Malaysia imports.


Just think if we could use all the other kinds of waste too!


(EFBs at a Palm Oil Mill)

Our process takes waste EFBs and uses torrefaction to upgrade them in to a highly calorific fuel source. The substance produced is then pelletised to form a product that is easy to ship, hydrophobic and energy dense.

The bio-coal produced can then be used in place of, or co-fired with coal, anywhere that coal is currently used, for example in power plants, or in boilers to create heat (Kiel et al., 2008). No modifications are needed to switch to this fuel allowing it to replace coal straight away with no additional investment by the end user.

The product has a calorific value of 20-24 Mj/kg, comparable to that of lignite coal (see table below for comparison) and, like coal, it is hydrophobic (Kiel et al., 2008). Bio-coal can be sold and traded on the open market, and has a value similar to that of coal, if not slightly higher due to its sustainable and renewable qualities.

(A Comparison of the Properties of Torrefied Biomass Pellets and Coal)

Neither torrefaction nor pelletisation of biomass is a new concept. The process of torrefaction has been around since World War II but until now has not been an economically viable proposition. 


But we've finally got it! And used in combination with each other we can produce a fuel that could revolutionise the energy market!


With our engineering background and experience in designing energy efficient solutions for businesses we see this project as having far reaching potential once our first unit is up and running.


We need $280,000 to fund the construction of our initial torrefaction unit in Malaysia.  Around $200,000 of this will be used to purchase the actual components of the machine and have it constructed. The remainder of the funding would cover the costs of running the unit for the first few months, including rent of a warehouse and wages for local staff.

This unit will provide us with a turnover through sales of fuel and help us to generate sales of further units by enabling us to show other businesses and investors a commercial operation using their waste to produce a valuable commodity. Based on our conservative estimates, the unit should have a pay back period of just over one and a half years, and a break even analysis suggests we would need to sell around one third of our achievable output.

Any funds that fall short of what we need will still go a long way towards construction. We have the parts ready to be ordered in China where it will be built, and even with partial funding we may still be able to go ahead.

The unit will employ local staff, benefitting local communities and  as sales of units bring new income streams to other businesses, further employment opportunities will be created. We already have a local engineer raring to go!

Previously, our group has successfully designed, built and installed a coconut oil mill in a remote village in Sabah, Malaysia.

(Constructing the Coconut Mill in Sabah)

This has enabled the local people to up-skill and be employed in a small industry that has increased their standard of living. 

(Local Employees at the Coconut Mill)

We have also completed a number of studies on behalf of various NGOs and companies based in Asia and New Zealand. 

Our aim is for this to be the first of many projects, taking us wherever agriculture creates vegetable waste...rice husks, sugar cane stalks, palm oil fronds, empty fruit bunches... and  bringing the world cleaner, sustainable fuels and more efficient businesses.

Even if you cannot donate we would love to have you on board, spreading the news about our project.

We’re excited and we hope you are too!

Find us on Instagram  and Facebook!!

Also check out our website at www.seeperformance.com


References

- International Energy Agency, 2014, Coal. Available from: http://www.iea.org/topics/coal/  [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

- Kiel. J. H. A., Verhoeff, F., Gerhauser. H., Meuleman, B., 2008, 'BO2-technology for biomass upgrading into solid fuel - pilot-scale testing and market implementation', paper presented at 16th European Biomass Conference & Exhibition, Valencia, Spain 2-6 June 2008.

- Pei Qin Ng, W., Loong Lam, H., Yuen Ng, F., Kamal, M., Heng Ee Lim, J., 2012, ‘Waste-to-wealth: green potential from palm biomass in Malaysia’ Journal of Cleaner Production, vol. 34 pp. 57-65, Available from: Elsevier Ltd. [Accessed: 17 September 2014].

- RSPO, 2014, How to be RSPO Certified. Available from: http://www.rspo.org/en/how_to_be_rspo_certified [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

- Suruhanjaya Tenaga (Energy Commission), 2014, Malaysia Energy Statistics Handbook 2014. Available from: http://meih.st.gov.my/publications;jsessionid=2295ADBA1597262422DCB46A22916BDE [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

- U.S Energy Information Administration, 2014, World Coal Consumption by Region 1980 - 2010. Available from: http://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/images/2011.12.20/Coal_World_Consumption.gif [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

- Walsh, B., 2014, 'How Wall Street Really Is Failing The Planet', Huffington Post, 25 September 2014. Available from: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/25/fossil-fuel-divestment_n_5877282.html [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

- World Coal Association, 2014, Coal & Energy Access. Available from: http://www.worldcoal.org/coal-energy-access/ [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

-World Coal Association, 2014, Coal Statistics. Available from: http://worldcoal.org/resources/coal-statistics/ [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

- WWF, 2014, Environmental and Social Impacts of Palm Oil Production.  Available from: http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/footprint/agriculture/palm_oil/environmental_impacts/  [Accessed: 30 September 2014]

story:
Update 1/14/2017

Hoop Compost is in stock and available for purchase at www.hoopcompost.com & here through Indiegogo for immediate shipment upon order placement.  Thanks for your support!

Update 8/1/2016

Now shipping!!

Update 5/29/2016

We're working through the final stages of the injection molds, while everything else is waiting and ready to go.  Speaking with our vendor a few days ago, we expect to start testing the molds in a couple weeks.  Barring any major issues, we should have parts mid June and our expectation is that product will begin shipping soon after that.  Thanks for your support and patience while we work through the details.  Almost there!!

Update 4/14/2016

Quick update on our progress.  But first, thanks to everyone for their contribution in pre-orders and in so many other ways!  We are getting very close and anticipate shipping pre-orders sometime between mid-May and early June.  It was our hope that we could begin shipping in early May, but the last thing we are working through is the injection mold being manufactured and tuned.  We met with our vendor yesterday and so this is the very latest in terms of timing.  The good news is everything else is ready to go!

Our Indiegogo campaign will remain open to pre-orders until we launch officially and it is our goal to continue building momentum in the meantime.  Thank you!

-Nick & Katie

 

Hoop Compost

Frustrated with the traditional method of compost collection like using a counter-top bin, we knew there must be a better way.  Hoop replaces the traditional compost bin and fits the trash can you already have.  It is either out of sight entirely or least not on your counter, and helps improve cleanliness and reduces odor associated with compost collection.  

Did you know 37 million tons of food waste was generated in the US alone in 2013.  Guess how much was recycled... 5%.  We can do better than that, but it has to be much easier.  Hoop was conceived and developed within our own home and shaped by the feedback of our friends and family.  Our mission is to increase food waste recovery by making the process much easier!

We hope you join us!  Sincerely,

Nick & Katie

 

     

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Our goal is to achieve 500 or more pre-orders.  Pre-orders validate demand and the proceeds help cover some initial manufacturing costs.  The most significant cost is associated with the tooling required to produce the product at volume and at reasonable pricing.  If we reach our goal, here is what will happen:

1.  Buy Tooling: We estimate tooling will take 6-8 weeks to produce.  In this case, tooling refers to plastic injection molds that can be used to produce the parts of a Hoop at high volume.

2.  Develop Packaging: Initially, the packaging for Hoop will be minimal in order to avoid creating excess waste.  However, packaging plays a critical role in ensuring the product reaches customers without damage and includes the proper instructions for use.

3.  Produce & Assemble: Hoop is made of about 10 unique parts.  We will place volume orders for each part and setup an assembly line.  Assembly can be as expensive as the parts that make up the product and so our goal will be to streamline this process.

4.  Ship: We expect to ship production version Hoops within 3 months of achieving our pre-order goals.

The Impact

Organic waste collection is a critical step towards sustainability.  Since most organic waste ends up in landfills, diversion for use as compost not only reduces the amount of useless waste we generate, but also provides nutrient rich soil and helps reduce greenhouse emissions that would otherwise occur in landfills.  Need more information: Visit www.epa.gov

For many people, the process of leaving rotting food on your counter-top like with traditional methods is quite challenging.  And unfortunately, the easiest thing to do is nothing at all.  We created Hoop as individuals who knew separating organic waste for compost was the right thing to do, but struggled with the traditional compost bin.  We believe Hoop is an alternative and hope it will lead to a greater percentage of households joining the cause.

Fitting Hoop to Your Trash Can

We’ve designed Hoop to fit the vast majority of trash cans, but there are still some that won’t fit.  The following graphic shows how the brackets of Hoop engage a trash can so you can check the fit of your existing trash can:

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to support our campaign with a pre-order, spreading the word can still make a significant impact.  We’ve found that there are many people who struggle with using a compost bin and who would otherwise separate for compost if there was an alternative.  Please help us reach those people by sharing our campaign with your friends, family, coworkers, etc.  The easiest way to share is by clicking the links provided above.  Thanks very much for your support!

Visit our website at www.hoopcompost.com for more information.

story:
Project Summary

My name is Oksana Lane. For the past 20 years, I have been conducting wildlife research around the world through Biodiversity Research Institute. While working in marine and coastal environments (Mediterranean Sea, Long Island New York, Maine, Massachusetts, and Mexico), I have witnessed firsthand the startling amount of plastic and other trash floating in the ocean or accumulated on the shoreline, and the resulting consequences--dead birds, turtles, and other marine life from the plastic debris and chemical contamination from the toxic chemicals that leach out of the plastic debris.

The 2017 eXXpedition through the Caribbean Islands is the basis for a powerful, important, and timely research project with a strong outreach component. We will travel to five countries including Grenada, Barbados, St. Lucia, Dominica, and Antigua to coordinate meaningful events and activities including beach clean ups, workshops, school presentations, day sails for local residents, and meetings with government officials and conservation groups to work toward a healthier future for the region.

As part of the scientific team on the eXXpedition voyage, I will survey wildlife and collect samples to test for heavy metals and other toxic chemicals. In addition to the research conducted, I will help foster our relationships with local communities throughout the region.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $10,000 for scientific research, lab analysis, supplies, and outreach materials. Our activities on board the boat include: 1) manta trawl sampling and observations for plastic pollution; 2) water sampling to test for persistent organic pollutants (POPs); 3) nano plastic sampling; 4) sampling of human hair and market fish for mercury analysis; 4) surveys of marine mammals and seabirds.

eXXpedition creates the energy for change. The approach of taking novice sailors and a diverse range of skilled women to study ocean plastics and toxics is unique. Participating women on the voyage come from all over the world and will gain the experience to become an eXXpedition ambassador in their own country and community. The benefit to everyone includes cleaner oceans and beaches that we all can enjoy, healthier fish to eat, and greatly reduced wildlife casualties.

If you can't contribute financially, you can help in other ways: clean up your own local beaches, reduce your use of plastic products, spread the word to others about this crowdfunding site. For more details about this project, visit http://exxpedition.com

story:
What's The Problem?

In Tanzania 86% of the population has no access to the grid. In other words, in Tanzania about 38 million people have to live day by day without any electrical power: No light from bulbs, no possibility to charge mobile phones, radios or other electronic devices. Moreover, these people - no matter whether rich or poor - have no chance to store food in the fridge, cool their houses with air conditioners or watch the news on TV.


What Can We Do?

What comes to our mind when we hear "Africa"? Apart from the beautiful flora and fauna we all know that the high amount of sunshine on this continent makes Africa just so African. So why not using the enormous energy of the sun to solve the problem? Yes, why not?
Therefore, we decided to act: African Solar Rise is a German based non-profit organization with the goal to bring solar energy to the rural communities of Africa by empowering local people to start their own social businesses.

Help us to build the Simba Solar Village and we can show the world how to build a self-sustained traditional African village!


What Do We Need?

To build authentic traditional huts we need to come up for the building materials and human resources. Luckily, we have our local genius builder Thomas. It is easier said than done to get all the materials to our premises in Dar es Salaam. The costs for transportation, materials and personnel expenses account to about 1000 USD for a middle-sized hut.

On the picture below you see Thomas building the first hut on our premises.

 


The Simba Solar Village will consist of three different sections. Apart from residential huts, we set up a commercial and an agricultural district, so that we can show as many different usages for solar power as possible.
In our first funding round we want to gather money for the building of the residential section: 3 middle-sized huts with one room and one big hut with multiple rooms.


What Do You Get?

Support us and you get some very exciting gifts!

Get the chance to visit the Simba Solar Village: Learn about solar power, the project or even spend the night in one of our huts; experience the impact of solar power on the daily lives of Tanzanian people.

 

 

But maybe it needs to be more adventurous for you and you want to go back to the roots? No problem, we organize a trip for you to the Maasai land: You get to know these friendly people and you will enjoy a once in a lifetime experience!

 


Hakuna Matata! Explore the "Rhytm of the Savannah"! We share our Dropbox with you and you get original footage of Tanzanian music between Serengeti and Kilimanjaro. Get a foretaste and go to: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rFEx0jY5emc

Are There Other Ways You Can Help?

"A journey with a thousand miles begins with a single step" - of course everybody can help, no matter whether you support us financially or you want to get involved personally: Spread the word and tell the world about our Simba Solar Village. Share us on indiegogo and facebook!

 

Thank you for your help and don't forget:

"Tanzania without darkness is possible!" - Let us prove it!

story:
UPDATE:  After 41 days at sea, Arctic Row rowed 1000 miles across the Arctic Ocean, the longest nonstop row in this ocean in history. The boat is currently being shipped to San Francisco where it will be on display. The movie will be assembled from the many hours of 1080p video footage, photographs and audio recordings that the team made while underway in the ocean and while anchored awaiting Arctic storms.

Thank you for donating to Arctic Row. If you already donate you will soon get your perks--we're busily preparing them now. You should have already gotten your postcard if you donated prior to mid-July.    

 

 

 

Why row the Arctic Ocean:

“Do not go where the path may lead; go instead where there is no path and leave a trail.” -Ralph Waldo Emerson

Because we want to show first-hand the impact that global warming has had on the Arctic Ocean (foreshadow: it's melting fast). Our film will chronicle this record setting expedition and showcase the effects of Arctic global warming. Each member of our team is doing the row for slightly different reasons, but we all agree that the exploratory nature of Arctic Row and the science associated with the expedition make it highly compelling and worthwhile.

Arctic Row's Science: 


For science, Arctic Row has partnered with Adventurers and Scientists for Conservation and Professor Russell Hopcroft of the University of Alaska Fairbanks to conduct research on the role of whale olfaction in feeding habits in the Arctic Ocean and collect plankton samples to increase understanding of this key food source for marine mammals.

For mankind, our team of four will set a Guinness Book Record and complete one of the world's last great firsts: A non-stop, unsupported crossing of the Arctic Ocean by rowboat in July 2012. We will explore the unknown and advance the mettle of man. Arctic Row is a 30-day expedition in July 2012 to row 1,100 miles across the Arctic Ocean.

 

Documentary Themes:

1. Challenging the Impossible: Rowing The Last Unrowed Ocean

2. Inspire a Global Audience: Health, Fitness, & Empowered Living

3. Collaborate with Experts: Studying Endangered Baleen Whales

 

Meet The Rowers:



from left to right: Collin, Scott, Paul, and Neal

 

Rower Collin West: breathes inspiration, eats adversity and smiles in the face of what others call danger.  (He simply calls it opportunity.) As a national champion adventure racer and Crossfit World Games competitor he fills his leisure time with an MBA from the Kellogg School of Management (same as Paul) and was recently awarded the prestigious Kauffman Fellowship. Later this year, Collin is marrying his soul-mate & sweetheart. His bride-to-be is a fellow brainiac and inspirational tour de force…also a Dallas Cowboys cheerleader & Miss Texas winner.  Enough said.

 

Rower Scott Mortensen: is an adventure filmmaker, marketing whiz and social entrepreneur who spearheads profitable ventures for stakeholders, people and the planet — the elusive, triple-bottom-line.  He's worked at orphanages in Russia, shot documentaries in Thailand, built community centers in Fiji, practiced social enterprise in Honduras and joined disaster relief teams in Haiti. Scott thinks that anyone can climb Mount Everest, bike across the US or row across an ocean. He's personally completed two of those three feats.  "The real challenge is to inspire everyone around you while you do it.  Getting people to 'think different' isn't just a tagline, it's my life mission." Scott has only two items left unchecked on his bucket list. One of them is to produce a film/book project that sparks lasting global change. The time is now. And this is the project.

 

Rower Paul Ridley: Our calm, capable, team leader and long-distance rowing mad-man. In honor of his mother, Katherine Raub Ridley, 25 year-old Paul rowed for hope across the entire Atlantic ocean in 87 days. He was the youngest American to ever pull off such a feat. "I'm exhausted. Overwhelmed with all the excitement from my arrival," Ridley told CNN. "Physically feeling good but will be feeling a lot better when the soreness starts to heal and once that happens I will be back to fundraising because cancer research is still in need of funding, so we still have a lot of work to do." Surprisingly, Paul's motto is not, never give up.  It's give it all up.  Leave nothing behind.  Spare no reserve of body, mind or spirit in making this world a better place, right here, right now.

 

Rower Neal Mueller: is the closest thing to a real life Bruce Wayne aka Batman that we could find.  We'd love to tell you more but we can't.  Really, we can't.  Okay fine: Neal lives on one of the most famous streets in the world (Lombard Street in San Francisco).  Almost as famous as he is.  He works a full-time product management job yet was the 120th person in the world to climb all of the 7 Summits, including Mount Everest unguided.  He's also swam the English Channel, rowed from San Francisco to Sacramento and San Francisco to Petaluma.  He has over 3,000 mentions in the press but not one of them tells you who he really is, how he pulls everything off, or most importantly, where he parks the batmobile. He lives with his dog Tenzing.

Arctic Row Boat:


Arctic Row Route:




Our route benefits from expertise from Weather Routing Incorporated.

 

What We Need:
Donate and your tax-deductible gift will us complete our historic and scientific mission. 100% of your money will go to direct expenses of the expedition and documentary. We are raising money two ways: corporate sponsors and individual donations (like yours).

 

$60,000 Boat & Retrofit for Ice
$30,000 Film Gear
$20,000 Boat Shipping
$20,000 Gear
$15,000 Dehydrated Food
$15,000 Travel
========================
$160,000 Total

 

What We're About:

Learn more on our website: www.arcticrow.com

story:
Our Story

About one year ago, Sam Taylor and I were discussing Africa. She was longing to return to Kenya, where she had spent many formative years as a child.  Climbing has been always been a passion of mine, and while Kili is certainly not a technical climb, it's a great introduction to taking on the worlds higher peaks. 

We agreed if we were going to complete such a journey, why not invite other people and raise money for a cause? It was important to me that we didn't simply contribute money to a foundation, I wanted our efforts to result in something tangible. Dominique at Elevate Destinations introduced us to the Francombe Family in Kenya, and the 'mountains for water' concept was cemented.  

I bought the website myempowermentproject.com (it's under development!). I love the idea of people embracing a challenge, and producing a tangible good from their efforts.

In our case, we are taking on the challenge of climbing Kili, and aim to raise $25,000, which is what it costs to build one reservoir in Kenya. This water source will improve and possibly save the lives of people and wildlife for years to come. Now that's a tangible good! We're a small but dedicated team of four, but other groups may take on our missive at other dates in 2012. You can too! We've done the leg work, and are happy to share.

I have been to Africa before as well. While completing graduate studies in science in Montreal, I travelled to South Africa shortly after the fall of apartheid. I was inspired by the incredible lives of Stephen Biko and Nelson Mandela, and appalled by the oppressive social system that was apartheid. I wanted to write about it, and had  several articles published in newspapers after returning. 

We visited several countries that trip, including Malawi, Lesotho, Swaziland, Zimbabwe and Botswana. The people and the beauty of Africa made a profound impression on me, and it has since held a special place in my heart. I'm very excited to go back, really hope I make it to the top, and am extremely grateful to all who support our cause, THANK YOU!

The Impact

"Silango" means 'a place where there is a natural collection of water'. 

Changes in rainfall patterns in Kenya recently have resulted in alternating periods of heavy rains and sever drought. The droughts have lasted up to two years and devastated wildlife and the Samburu people. 

Open Water Reservoirs will literally save the lives of people and animals for decades to come.

You can read about the Francomb family and their wonderful local projects at Olmalo.org. We are specifically helping with their Silango Water Project, which aims to build 60 open water reservoirs over a ten year period, thereby providing clean water within a 30 minute walk of every Samburu homestead.  


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $25,000 to build one reservoir. If we raise $50,000, or if others take on our cause or trip later in the year and raise another 25k, we build another reservoir. The Samburu people are nomadic, and animals like to meander too.  The more reservoirs the better.


Our group is a little smaller than I'd hoped, so we each need to raise as much as possible. I've set a goal of $2500 here, but really I'm hoping to personally raise $10,000. Apparently, it's hard to get people to spend money and time on a risky difficult endeavor and require them to raise money while doing it. Who knew? I did not get that memo!


No matter what you can donate, I will thank you personally. If you can donate $100, you'll be invited to Dumbo for a soiree. $500 will get you a video from the mountain, personally saying 'thanks!"


$1000 is the best deal, it will get you a weekend in Woodstock at one of my lovely rental homes in the spring of 2012. Spring fling!  


Other Ways You Can Help

You can help spread the word by posting our mission on your facebook page, tweeting or emailing or anything else you can think of!

story:
The Problem

As the world population increases and consumption accelerates, there is a significant and growing imperative for society to explore and develop new and innovative ways of constructing our homes and public buildings in such a fashion as to use our limited resources efficiently. Over the last few decades thousands of engineers, architects, designers and private inventors have been refining existing, or creating new, products and methods by which the construction industry overall can move towards more sustainable practices. As the industry moves forward however, the amount of information available grows exponentially and unfortunately many ideas go unnoticed because they can’t find a voice in the general tumult. What is needed is an open centralized source of information that is capable of creating organization where there is none and as a result helping users identify the products or ideas that most closely meet their needs for a new construction or renovation.

The Solution

At its most basic, what we propose to create is a directory listing of home construction products and ideas with links to the manufactures or distributors of those products. More accurately what we propose to build is a directory 2.0. Our website will be an organized listing of products; but will also incorporate informative aspects similar to a wiki site, allow for user reviews and questions similar to commercial sites like amazon.com orbackcountry.com and most importantly incorporate comparative metrics such as cost, warranties, or performance characteristics. Users will be able to filter the listings according to these comparative metrics in order to identify the products that fit their moral, economic, aesthetic and project specific needs.

This idea was born out of frustration with the fact that there is no centralized site where this information can be had. Ultimately we want to see this become a resource that users can use to plan out their homes from the foundation up, take their preferences to a designer and / or architect and have them make all the pieces fit together to create high quality, environmentally friendly and beautiful structures.

The Website

We've been thinking about this site for the last six months putting together the list of features that will make it most useful.  First and foremost we want the information to be easy to access and understand.  That means the site will be only three layers deep.  Put another way, users can find the information they're looking for within three clicks.  Also, once on the product pages, the only information on display will be information about that product and user feedback & questions. 

Another core focus will be on maintaining a “clean” site aesthetic. Banner ads will be restricted to Founder's Messages. For the home page this means that the 10 major categories will be displayed on the left, and as the user moves their cursor over any of the categories a paragraph will be displayed in the center of the page to provide more information about that category along with a scrolling slide show of images illustrating the different products found within that category.  Below is a wirefram of the basic layout.

Finally, we want to make it easy to go from research to design and implementation.  This means customers will be able to tag products and ideas they like and share them with their architects, designers, or contractors.  If the user is a DIYer they'll be able to find a local distributor to buy the product(s) directly.

The Need

So we want to build this site, but we don't have the web development skills to create such a database heavy website nor the graphics design talent to create a truly beautiful and intuitive experience.  The $30,000 we are trying to raise will be used to build the website described above.  We need your help to make that a reality.

How You Can Help

Obviously if you are reading this, the primary reason you are here is to consider contributing to my idea.  If you do contribute; thank you very, very, very much!  I would ask you to go one step further regardless of whether or not you contribute.  Please help me spread the word about this idea so that others can learn about this idea and decide if they would like to donate.

If you dig the idea of my website and would like to make suggestions on features you would like to see, send me an email or post the comment here. If you are a web developer or graphics design artist I’d also like to hear from you.  I have talked with 3 different developers here in my local area but none of them have struck me as “perfect” for this project, I’m on the hunt for talent and vision!

The Future Website (aka Stretch Goal)

If we can raise more than $30,000, the next step in enhancing the site will be to create a simulation model that will use the performance criteria of each product selected to provide life cycle cost comparisons.  I would even like to build in the ability to use location specific data in the comparison.  

For example:  If you live in Arizona, and want to compare expected utility expenses for a conventional stick home with an adobe, or ICF home, all of which have different R-Values and construction costs.  How much will each hom cost initially, and what can you expect to pay in utlitities over the next 10 - 20 years if you keep the house at 70 degrees F year round?  

These estimations will be based on the information in the database and location specific temperature and utility rates.

Similar comparisons can be made for heating and air conditioning units, windows, insullations, even finishing surfaces in a home.  It's this kind of comparison that gets the engineer in me really excited.

In order to include this feature in the website from the get go, we will need hire additional coding / consulting services.  If we can raise $80,000 this feature will be added to the site within 12 months of launching the site.

Additionally, if we are able to hit the $80,000 funding mark, in addition to the perks listed, we will include everyone from the $50 level and up in an homage video where your name is said out loud, in public and / or in remote backcountry locations once a year for the next five years.
story_txt:
The Problem
As the world population increases and consumption accelerates, there is a significant and growing imperative for society to explore and develop new and innovative ways of constructing our homes and public buildings in such a fashion as to use our limited resources efficiently. Over the last few decades thousands of engineers, architects, designers and private inventors have been refining existing, or creating new, products and methods by which the construction industry overall can move towards more sustainable practices. As the industry moves forward however, the amount of information available grows exponentially and unfortunately many ideas go unnoticed because they can’t find a voice in the general tumult. What is needed is an open centralized source of information that is capable of creating organization where there is none and as a result helping users identify the products or ideas that most closely meet their needs for a new construction or renovation.
The Solution
At its most basic, what we propose to create is a directory listing of home construction products and ideas with links to the manufactures or distributors of those products. More accurately what we propose to build is a directory 2.0. Our website will be an organized listing of products; but will also incorporate informative aspects similar to a wiki site, allow for user reviews and questions similar to commercial sites like amazon.com orbackcountry.com and most importantly incorporate comparative metrics such as cost, warranties, or performance characteristics. Users will be able to filter the listings according to these comparative metrics in order to identify the products that fit their moral, economic, aesthetic and project specific needs.

This idea was born out of frustration with the fact that there is no centralized site where this information can be had. Ultimately we want to see this become a resource that users can use to plan out their homes from the foundation up, take their preferences to a designer and / or architect and have them make all the pieces fit together to create high quality, environmentally friendly and beautiful structures.
The Website
We've been thinking about this site for the last six months putting together the list of features that will make it most useful.  First and foremost we want the information to be easy to access and understand.  That means the site will be only three layers deep.  Put another way, users can find the information they're looking for within three clicks.  Also, once on the product pages, the only information on display will be information about that product and user feedback & questions. 
Another core focus will be on maintaining a “clean” site aesthetic. Banner ads will be restricted to Founder's Messages. For the home page this means that the 10 major categories will be displayed on the left, and as the user moves their cursor over any of the categories a paragraph will be displayed in the center of the page to provide more information about that category along with a scrolling slide show of images illustrating the different products found within that category.  Below is a wirefram of the basic layout.

Finally, we want to make it easy to go from research to design and implementation.  This means customers will be able to tag products and ideas they like and share them with their architects, designers, or contractors.  If the user is a DIYer they'll be able to find a local distributor to buy the product(s) directly.
The Need
So we want to build this site, but we don't have the web development skills to create such a database heavy website nor the graphics design talent to create a truly beautiful and intuitive experience.  The $30,000 we are trying to raise will be used to build the website described above.  We need your help to make that a reality.
How You Can Help
Obviously if you are reading this, the primary reason you are here is to consider contributing to my idea.  If you do contribute; thank you very, very, very much!  I would ask you to go one step further regardless of whether or not you contribute.  Please help me spread the word about this idea so that others can learn about this idea and decide if they would like to donate.
If you dig the idea of my website and would like to make suggestions on features you would like to see, send me an email or post the comment here. If you are a web developer or graphics design artist I’d also like to hear from you.  I have talked with 3 different developers here in my local area but none of them have struck me as “perfect” for this project, I’m on the hunt for talent and vision!
The Future Website (aka Stretch Goal)
If we can raise more than $30,000, the next step in enhancing the site will be to create a simulation model that will use the performance criteria of each product selected to provide life cycle cost comparisons.  I would even like to build in the ability to use location specific data in the comparison.  
For example:  If you live in Arizona, and want to compare expected utility expenses for a conventional stick home with an adobe, or ICF home, all of which have different R-Values and construction costs.  How much will each hom cost initially, and what can you expect to pay in utlitities over the next 10 - 20 years if you keep the house at 70 degrees F year round?  
These estimations will be based on the information in the database and location specific temperature and utility rates.
Similar comparisons can be made for heating and air conditioning units, windows, insullations, even finishing surfaces in a home.  It's this kind of comparison that gets the engineer in me really excited.
In order to include this feature in the website from the get go, we will need hire additional coding / consulting services.  If we can raise $80,000 this feature will be added to the site within 12 months of launching the site.
Additionally, if we are able to hit the $80,000 funding mark, in addition to the perks listed, we will include everyone from the $50 level and up in an homage video where your name is said out loud, in public and / or in remote backcountry locations once a year for the next five years.

story:
Marriage is a difficult and vastly rewarding challenge. So is starting a business. We know these things intuitively and by experience, respectively.

As the Santana wedding is approaching, we are receiving queries that culminate on two main topics: "Where will you have your honeymoon?" and "Where is your gift registry?". We didn't have good answers for our friends and family but we knew to search the last half year of our life together to investigate what we wanted, and where we wanted to go. The last several months of 2014 have been for us a focus on turning Alina's creation, SIX Magazine S&E* Fashion and Lifestyle (*Sustainable & Ethical), into a mobile property. The time we've spent and the success we've achieved in publishing the first mobile edition of SIX Magazine speaks to what our ambition and plan for the near term is. To be certain, we are determined to create a follow-up mobile edition of SIX Magazine, the JAPAN issue, as soon as possible. To do this, and as a direction for our friends that wish to commemorate and condone our union, we humbly request your financial assistance to help in funding time in Japan so that we might gather the necessary content for the next edition of SIX Magazine (and have our honeymoon along the way).

  • Our target funds amount is 14,000.00 USD.  This is an amount allowing us enough time and flexibility in Japan to gather the content and contacts needed for the Japan edition of SIX Magazine, while looking forward to the reality of our base of operations in Beijing.
  • If we don't reach our goal within our fundraising period, as long as we can fund our plane fare and housing, we will do our best to attempt the trip anyway by extending ourselves with our reserves. If our campaign only raises a fraction of the required funds, we will scale back our plans for now and use funds toward a shorter trip in Japan. No matter what happens, your contributions will be going toward a Japan trip for us and for the advancement of our shared passion in Sustainability and Ethical operations, SIX Magazine.

Why is SIX Magazine important, and why Japan?

Alina created SIX Magazine almost half a decade ago in London. The lack of *fashionable* publications regarding sustainable and ethical consumer goods and lifestyles prompted Alina to grow the nascent magazine despite the challenge.  Each issue of SIX Magazine has a distinct topic while firmly tracking with sustainable and ethical product ethos. With Japan being one of the leading countries embracing sustainable production and mindset it was only natural it would be the next topic after mainland China, almost the polar opposite of that. 

    Why Japan?  Have you been to Japan?

    We've been to Japan twice together and in that process we've revealed more and more about the inherent conservative side of the Japanese culture. From reclaiming decades old wooden sake barrels to the spinning of sustainable and ethical materials for textile applications, Japan is the perfect match for the next issue of SIX Magazine.  

      Other Ways You Can Help

      IF YOU CAN'T CONTRIBUTE

      • Tell people that you know about the SIX Magazine Japan campaign.

story:
Short Summary:

 Hello! My name is Zach Starcher and I live in Kernersville , NC, USA. Helping neighbors and people around the world has become a huge passion of mine. I plan to use the knowledge I will obtain from the best permaculture institute in the world to travel the globe helping and teaching communities from all cultures and religions to be completely be self-sufficient in abundance, weather you live in an urban environment or in the wilderness, while providing the habitats and ecosystems mankind and wildlife need to survive.

The Impact:

 Self-sufficiant food forests have been found in morocco dating over 2000 years old. One forest supplied absolutely all the needs for a whole village. The best thing about a permaculture food forest is its ability to produce and abundance of recourses every year while being completely self-thriving (once built, no maintenance required) With the amount of disease and poverty around the world, we need change. 

  •  Food Forest will provide all basic needs (food, shelter, fresh drinking water, timber, and more!)

  • Help put an end to disease stricken communities with a bounty of fresh fruits and greens

  • Provide habitats for a large variety of wildlife

  • Stop outsourcing and pollution 

  • It even greens and irrigates the water in the desert

                           This is our only future!

 

Other Ways You Can Help: 

  Please share this with your friends and family! Think about what aches your heart the most and think about what you can do to leave a positive footprint when your gone.   

                                Thanks! :)

story:
Why Become a Maine Guide?

  • I love to fish, I love the outdoors, and I love to teach! Connect the dots and you have a Maine Guide! Becoming a registered Maine Guide will allow me to channel my passion and experience into a career!
  • I've done most of the work already (almost 40 years of fishing, boating, hiking, camping, and reading every book I can get my hands on), and now it's time to get the Maine Guide patch and hang a shingle! Your support will send me to Maine Guide School and help with the first three years of the Guide license and required first-aid certification.
  • Who knows, maybe I'll lead you on your own great Maine Fishing Adventure one day!


What I Need & What You Get

  • This campaign is for four things: Red Cross First-Aid Certification, which is required by the state ($90), Maine Guide School itself ($495), a one-time test fee ($100), and the first 3 years' Maine Guide license ($81)
  • What does your contribution get you? Check out the list of perks on the sidebar! Any amount will earn my most sincere gratitude! 
  • If the funding goal isn't met by the end of the campaign, any funds raised will be put into a savings account, which will be added to until the goal is reached by other means.
  • Any funds over and above the goal will go towards my next certifications, which will be with the US Coast Guard captain's License and a Registered Maine Guide Tidewater license, both of which are required to be a guide in the tidewaters of Merrymeeting Bay.

The Impact

As a Registered Maine Guide I will be able to professionally offer fishing/camping outings to people of all ages, to Mainers and people 'from away'. I'll be able to hang up a shingle, as it were. Initially, I will focus on warm water fishing in Southern Maine (within 50 miles or so of Portland), but ultimately my goal is to establish a base of operations on Merrymeeting Bay, and serve as a guide to the finest carp fishing in New England.


Risks & Challenges

Obtaining the Registered Maine Guide patch requires passing very challenging oral and written tests. With my decades of practical experience, and many, many hours of study, I'm quite confident I will pass these tests.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not in a position to contribute directly, tell a friend, or share this on Facebook or Twitter, or use the IndieGogo sharing tools.
